بیست ساله که بودم زندگیم تمام شد. از آن به بعد فقط رشته ی بی انتهای خاطرات، راهرویی پیچان و تاریک بود که راه به جایی نمی برد. با اینحال ناچار بودم آن را از سر بگذرانم، در هر روزِ تهی زنده بمانم، گذرِ هر روزِ هنوز تهی را شاهد باشم. در آن روزها اشتباهات فراوانی کردم. نه، این حرف درست نیست، گاهی احساس می کنم هر کاری کردم اشتباه بود. احساس می کردم انگار در ته چاهی عمیق زندگی می کنم، یکسره در درونم زندانی شدم، به سرنوشتم نفرین کردم و از هر چیز بیرونی بیزار شدم. گهگاه از خودم در می آمدم و جلوه ای می کردم تا نشان بدهم زنده ام. هر چه پیش می آمد می پذیرفتم و کند و کرخت لابه لای زندگی می لغزیدم. با خیلیها حشر و نشر کردم و حتی یک بار تن به نوعی ازدواج دادم، اما همه اینها بیهوده بود. همه چیز در یک چشم بهم زدن گذشت و چیزی به جا نگذاشت جز زخم چیزهایی که به آنها آسیب رساندم یا نفرتشان را برانگیختم.از متن کتاب

I wrote this long review earlier about how much I enjoyed Kafka on the Shore, about how Murakami is one of my favorite authors, questioning myself on whether I say stuff like that to sound cool and slightly pretentious or if it’s actually true. Honestly, it was probably one of the best reviews I’ve ever written. I put all of this thought into it and looked up big adjectives in the dictionary to give the whole thing an NPR kind of vibe. I mean, it was amazing, but I accidentally deleted it. I thought I saved it as a draft, and I planned to come back to it later, and I did come back to it later. It was gone. So I’m starting over, and this just a shadow of my original review. Just a shadow. Haruki Murakami is one of my favorite authors. Sometimes I question whether I say stuff like that to sound all cool and pretentious or if it’s actually true. I’m still trying to figure all of that out internally, but I did really enjoy this book. I can’t really describe the plot to you, though, not because I can’t remember it and not because I don’t want to spoil anything. It’s just a tough story to pin down into words or even a genre. It’s like literary magical realism with some fantasy, romance, and humor mixed in. It’s basically like taking every genre and baking them into a cake and writing Kafka on the Shore on top, but instead of eating the cake or the book you read it, you cut into the cake and stay to notice all the layers. You introduce yourself to the complexities of the story and start to realize, yeah, you’re gonna have to take your time with this one. There’s just a lot to unpack here, a lot of flavors baked in that you need to savor. You don’t want to eat too fast, read too fast. And beside you is Murakami, and he’s telling you how the book might seem like an ordinary book, but..: He’s standing beside you, and he blows this giant purple mist slowly from the palm of his hand, and it covers your mind and your body and the book, and you can feel your feet lift up off the ground. Your head feels like it’s in the clouds, and it’s like your floating in space, your feet now in line with your head. You’re up there floating around like a perfectly drawn x-axis, up there just straight chillin’ in that northeast quadrant, and you start reading the book. You meet Kafka and he runs away from home. You learn about a mysterious event from the past and an old man named Nakata. He’s out hunting for a cat while Kafka is running away. And it’s back and forth like that between these two worlds and these two characters. New people are introduced. A whole bunch of wild and crazy stuff happens to both of them, things get really weird, but you’re floating in space so it doesn’t seem weird. You got hit by that purple mist, too, so you’re good to go. So much ridiculous stuff happens in this book, but it doesn’t feel that way while you’re reading it. Murakami pulls you into a trance when you read his books. You’re locked in like you’re in a dream, try to wake up, but you have to read like 13 more pages before you can wake up and snap out of it. You can’t get too deep into this stuff because you have a life and responsibilities. You can’t be hitting that purple haze all that time, man. Sometimes you gotta come back down to the real world and swallow a big dose of reality. You’re not in space. People can’t really talk to cats. There is no mist. Nope. You’re 36 and someone from your job needs to talk to you. Why are you reading at 10:30am on a Tuesday? There’s a lot of philosophy and music in this story, too. That may be of importance to someone. Might just sway you fully into reading this book. Man, I was a little unsure with the whole magic and dreams and new age hocus pocus, but I do like music. I like philosophy, too, sure. I mean, I don’t read it, but I know philosophers and all that. I like philosophy just as much as the next guy. And that’s why you should read Kafka on the Shore.

It's a part of you and you're a part of it. Key themes: peaceful revolt, meditation, introspection, body awareness and sensuality, growing by accepting and facing your reality I'm not sure how to describe this and many others seem to be experiencing quite the same quintessential feeling when putting down a Murakami. This feeling could be attributed to the essence of his prose which doesn't seem to be focused on story as much as atmosphere. By no means do I mean that there's no kind of string to bind the whole effort together but I don't get the impression that what comes in the end is necessarily the pivot of all the notions preceding it. To state it more clearly on a subjective level, for me his ideas and how he expresses them trigger a sort of meditative trance through which I can introspect about my place in the universe free from all the deafening buzz of my everyday life worries. It is like a state of slow motion clarity, which is intended to lead to a kind of harmony between the inner and outer worlds or rather perceive them as one. Furthermore, it has its own kind of unique humour and mystery and philosophy, which makes it all the more intriguing. And all these themes are displayed in a wild and cool manner; there aren't many signs of restraint and there's confidence even in doubt. I guess that's how it never becomes stressful in tandem with not losing its appeal. So you can see I've not written even a word about the story so far and I've said a lot of the things I could say about it. But not to seem absolutely irrelevant it should be said that most characters whether cartoonish, dreamlike, or earthly are unbelievably vivid and pictureable; the moment they are depicted and as they open their mouths, you can feel them live and breathe by your side. Others here have described this feeling as dreaming with Murakami or his characters but I believe it totally exceeds that point and becomes a part of your tangible reality. There's the old man who talks with cats and is never bored, the young boy with a hollow inside who burns for something different, the bored truck driver who too eagerly jumps at the chance to join a seemingly absurd wild goose chase, (trying to think of female characters, I believe they've been objectiffied a bit here) ... All I said guarantees that I will definitely pick up another Murakami in a not so distant future.Book excerpts ____________________________________________________________ "And you really will have to make it through that violent, metaphysical, symbolic storm. No matter how metaphysical or symbolic it might be, make no mistake about it: it will cut through flesh like a thousand razor blades. People will bleed there, and you will bleed too. Hot, red blood. You'll catch that blood in your hands, your own blood and the blood of others.And once the storm is over you won't remember how you made it through, how you managed to survive. You won't even be sure, in fact, whether the storm is really over. But one thing is certain. When you come out of the storm you won't be the same person who walked in. That's what this storm's all about." "A dark, omnipresent pool of water. It was probably always there, hidden away somewhere. But when the time comes it silently rushes out, chilling every cell in your body. You drown in that cruel flood, gasping for breath. You cling to a vent near the ceiling, struggling, but the air you manage to breathe is dry and burns your throat. Water and thirst, cold and heat—these supposedly opposite elements combine to assault you." "Sometimes the wall I've erected around me comes crumbling down. It doesn't happen very often, but sometimes, before I even realize what's going on, there I am—naked and defenseless and totally confused. At times like that I always feel an omen calling out to me, like a dark, omnipresent pool of water." "In ancient times people weren't just male or female, but one of three types: male/male, male/female, or female/female. In other words, each person was made out of the components of two people. Everyone was happy with this arrangement and never really gave it much thought. But then God took a knife and cut everybody in half, right down the middle. So after that the world was divided just into male and female, the upshot being that people spend their time running around trying to locate their missing other half." "From the chair I watch how she carries herself, every motion natural and elegant. I can't express it well, but there's definitely something special about it, as if her retreating figure is trying to tell me something she couldn't express while facing me. But what this is, I haven't a clue. Face it, I remind myself—there're tons of things you don't have a clue about."     "The station's packed with people streaming in and out, all of them dressed in their favorite clothes, bags or briefcases in hand, each one dashing off to take care of some pressing business. I stare at this ceaseless, rushing crowd and imagine a time a hundred years from now. In a hundred years everybody here—me included—will have disappeared from the face of the earth and turned into ashes or dust. A weird thought, but everything in front of me starts to seem unreal, like a gust of wind could blow it all away."     "I spread my hands out in front of me and take a good hard look at them. What am I always so tense about? Why this desperate struggle just to survive? I shake my head, turn from the window, clear my mind of thoughts of a hundred years away. I'll just think about now. About books waiting to be read in the library, machines in the gym I haven't worked out on. Thinking about anything else isn't going to get me anywhere." "Most things are forgotten over time. Even the war itself, the life-and-death struggle people went through, is now like something from the distant past. We're so caught up in our everyday lives that events of the past, like ancient stars that have burned out, are no longer in orbit around our minds. There are just too many things we have to think about every day, too many new things we have to learn. New styles, new information, new technology, new terminology... But still, no matter how much time passes, no matter what takes place in the interim, there are some things we can never assign to oblivion, memories we can never rub away. They remain with us forever, like a touchstone. And for me, what happened in the woods that day is one of these." "You have to look!" Johnnie Walker commanded. "That's another one of our rules. Closing your eyes isn't going to change anything. Nothing's going to disappear just because you can't see what's going on. In fact, things will be even worse the next time you open your eyes. That's the kind of world we live in, Mr. Nakata. Keep your eyes wide open. Only a coward closes his eyes. Closing your eyes and plugging up your ears won't make time stand still." Nakata did as he was told and opened his eyes." "Yeah. I prefer being unfree, too. Up to a point. Jean-Jacques Rousseau defined civilization as when people build fences. A very perceptive observation. And it's true—all civilization is the product of a fenced-in lack of freedom. The Australian Aborigines are the exception, though. They managed to maintain a fenceless civilization until the seventeenth century. They're dyed-in-the-wool free. They go where they want, when they want, doing what they want. Their lives are a literal journey. Walkabout is a perfect metaphor for their lives. When the English came and built fences to pen in their cattle, the Aborigines couldn't fathom it. And, ignorant to the end of the principle at work, they were classified as dangerous and antisocial and were driven away, to the outback. So I want you to be careful. The people who build high, strong fences are the ones who survive the best. You deny that reality only at the risk of being driven into the wilderness yourself." "There are a lot of things that aren't your fault. Or mine, either. Not the fault of prophecies, or curses, or DNA, or absurdity. Not the fault of Structuralism or the Third Industrial Revolution. We all die and disappear, but that's because the mechanism of the world itself is built on destruction and loss. Our lives are just shadows of that guiding principle. Say the wind blows. It can be a strong, violent wind or a gentle breeze. But eventually every kind of wind dies out and disappears. Wind doesn't have form. It's just a movement of air. You should listen carefully, and then you'll understand the metaphor.""Blowing a chill breath on my neck, stinging like needles with a thousand eyes. Trying anything to drive this intruder away. But I gradually get better at letting these threats pass me by. This forest is basically a part of me, isn't it? This thought takes hold at a certain point. The journey I'm taking is inside me. Just like blood travels down veins, what I'm seeing is my inner self, and what seems threatening is just the echo of the fear in my own heart. The spiderweb stretched taut there is the spiderweb inside me. The birds calling out overhead are birds I've fostered in my mind. These images spring up in my mind and take root." "...There're these huge whirlpools because it's where the incoming and outgoing tides meet and crash into each other. It goes around and around like when you flush a toilet. If you wipe out there, you get pulled underwater and it's hard to float up again. Depending on the waves you might never make it back to the surface. So there you are, underwater, pounded by waves, and there's nothing you can do. Flailing around's not gonna get you anywhere. You'll just use up your energy. You've never been so scared in your life. But unless you get over that fear you'll never be a real surfer. You have to face death, get to really know it, then overcome it. When you're down in that whirlpool you start thinking about all kinds of things. It's like you get to be friends with death, have a heart-to-heart talk with it."

One of Murakami’s most energetic and irresistible stories, Kafka on the Shore is hard to put down.As you might expect from Murakami, this novel is surreal, allegorical and strange. Get comfortable with ambiguity because there’s a lot here that is never clearly explained. And yet it’s suspenseful, vibrant and constantly intriguing. Kafka on the Shore pulls you forward on the foundation of its own mythology. The main character, Kafka Tamura, is a 15 year old boy who runs away from home because his father appears to be an emotionless psychopath. He runs in the hopes of finding his mother and sister who left their home when he was little and disappeared without a word. Kafka’s path intersects indirectly with another main character, a homeless man who can speak with cats. Along the way, some very odd mystical things happened that might be considered as metaphors for emotional states. I’m not sure it really made sense, in the end. The joy of the story itself made it worth the trip, purely to enjoy the imaginative flower of this novel. That said, this book was not without weaknesses. There was a couple factors that kept this from being a 5-star book for me. Most of these bothersome elements centered around sex, sexuality and gender. First, the sex scenes were strange. Strange in how they came across as borderline pornographic rather than literary. There was something about them that felt out of place within the rest of the book, and I couldn’t tell if they were supposed to “mean” something, as if they were porn satire, or if they were gratuitous like pornography itself. Pornography is functional not metaphorical. There was one scene that presented the stereotypical fantasy of a friendly well-adjusted, beautiful prostitute who loves her work as she pays for college. And further there was a disturbing dream rape-sequence that never gets addressed in any substantial way. There seems to be a lot of potential for exploration of what it would mean to rape in a dream, in fact the Chronicles of Thomas Covenent the Unbeliever in many ways is sparked by the moral and ethical dilemma of Covenent raping a character in the fantasy world that he believes is nothing more than a figment of his imagination. And yet here…not much happens because of it. All of these somewhat blighted scenes left a bad taste in my mouth. Lastly, there was a strange scene that seemed arbitrary unnecessary to the overall plotline featuring two aggressively politically correct females. Frankly, Murakami created a straw horse to beat up on. He makes two rude, obnoxious females criticize this small-town privately held library for not being “gender neutral enough.” They were literally, the PC police. I felt it was a cheap shot to write them so obnoxiously. An author can twist any perspective by putting the opinions into the mouth of an asshole and skewing the way the point of view is presented to make the opinions look bad. After all, the author is the god of the dialogue. For me, this scene made Murakami look small minded not the characters.Despite these misgivings, it’s well worth reading this compelling and mysterious story.

Segunda novela de Murakami y ya puedo decir que me declaro entusiasta de su estilo. Una de las mejores obras que he leído en mi vida, sin duda. Parafraseando al gran [Vicente Ribes], usuario de nuestro querido GR: "libro condenadamente bueno". A la mitad de la novela ya sabía que iba a endosarle las 5 estrellas.Los libros del japonés hay que afrontarlos con la mente abierta, sabiendo que van a haber eventos inesperados, situaciones inverosímiles, y que al final habrá cabos sueltos. Si eres de los que necesita que todo cuadre y se cierre no es tu libro, ni tampoco tu autor. Eso sí, pocos libros tendrán personajes tan carismáticos, interrogantes vitales tan desasosegantes ni la capacidad de trasladarte a otra dimensión como los de Murakami; ni mucho menos sabrán conjugar de forma tan sublime la cruda y anodina realidad con el sentido de la maravilla, la irrealidad. Como siempre una delicia leer todas las referencias literarias y musicales que el nipón introduce en sus historias así como su explícito tratamiento de la sexualidad. Con "Kafka en la Orilla" te divertirás y reflexionarás, pero sobre todo te sentirás desconcertado, apabullado por la propuesta del autor, tan única y valiente. Un viaje vital hecho libro. Autor de culto. Una maravilla.

شاید اوایل کتاب مثل صدسال تنهایی شما رو جذب نکنه اما مهلت بدین تا داستان پیش بره بعدش آنچنان غرق شخصیت ها و و روند اتفاق ها می شین که نمی تونین زمین بذارینش.این کتاب واقعا شاهکار موراکامیه و من نمی تونم بپذیرم که موراکامی پلات رو قبول نداره این همه جزئیات حاضر توی داستان، این ترتیب حضور و عدم حضور شخصیت ها، این چیدمان منظم و همه ی این ها که به هم منتهی می شن مگه می شه بدون یه پلات محکم نوشته شده باشن؟ موراکامی ثابت می کنه که شما بدون یک ایده ی خیلی ناب و بکر می تونین یه رمان فوق العاده خیره کننده بنویسین. مهم پرداخته مهم چگونگی پیش بردنه و به بهترین نحو خودش این کار رو عملی می کنه. قسمت هایی از داستان برگرفته از داستان های معروف قدیمی ان که خودش صراحتا توی کتاب بهش اشاره می کنه به خصوص داستان ادیپ شاه اما تلفیق شخصیت ها و اضافه کردن پاره هایی تازه به داستان باعث می شه که همه چیز عالی دربیاد. موراکامی خیلی خونسرد مثل اغلب شخصیت های داستان، ذره ذره جلو می ره و هیچ باکی نداره که شما بخواین کتاب رو ببندین و کنارش بذارین؛ اون به روش خودش جلو می ره. آروم آروم بسته به نیازِ داستان! و تو توی این هزارتوی داستان قدم به قدم خیلی صبور پیش می ری و از سطر به سطرش لذت می بری.هنرمندی اون توی بحثای خودشناسی و روش و سیر زندگیه که بین تفکرات و دیالوگ های شخصیت هاش به شما یاد می ده. تجربه هایی که شاید بیشتر اونا از زندگی خودش نشات بگیرن. جملات و دیالوگ هایی که توی ذهنت حک می شن و دست از سرت برنمی دارن!برای خیلی از ما نیمچه نویسنده ها لازمه خوندن رمانایی مثل کافکا در ساحل تا بفهمیم چطور یه داستان چند لایه رو شکل بدیم، چگونه جلو ببریمش و از ریتم نیفته. نحوه ی گره اندازی ها، ورود شخصیت ها، اوج ها و فرودها، گره گشایی ها و حل معماها، حذف شخصیت ها و آهسته آهسته به انتها رسوندن داستان.

ما که نفهمیدیم چی شد ولی تجربه جالبی بود. اما نه شخصیت ها برام مهم بودن نه پلات داستان نه هیچ چیز دیگه شاید چون اصلا نمی‌فهمیدم کتاب چی میخواد بگه و هدفش چیه. یه رابطه خاصی هم اون وسط هست که واقعاً رو اعصاب من بود و باهاش اصلا کنار نیومدم. ناکاتا فقط داستان جالبی داشت حداقل تا وسط های کتاب ولی از وسط به بعد خسته کننده شد.قلم موراکامی عجیبه ولی نه اون مدل عجیبی که مورد علاقه من باشه. شاید چون ترجمش خوب نیست، شاید چون من تو ژاپن زندگی نکردم، شاید چون کلا رئالیسم جادویی با من نمی‌سازه.

"Sometimes fate is like a small sandstorm that keeps changing directions. You change direction but the sandstorm chases you. You turn again, but the storm adjusts. Over and over you play this out, like some ominous dance with death just before dawn.Why?Because this storm isn’t something that blew in from far away, something that has nothing to do with you. This storm is you. Something inside of you. So all you can do is give in to it, step right inside the storm, closing your eyes and plugging up your ears so the sand doesn’t get in, and walk through it, step by step. There’s no sun there, no moon, no direction, no sense of time. Just fine white sand swirling up into the sky like pulverized bones. That’s the kind of sandstorm you need to imagine."

أنهيت هذه الرواية بالأمس وحتى ا��أن لا اعرف ماذا أكتب عنها فهي بالفعل من أغرب ما قرأت منذ بدايتها وأنا أتساءل ماذا يريد الكاتب وحتى بعد نهايتها لم اعرف بعد ولكن هل أعجبتني الرواية .. نعم هل استمتعت .. نعم هل شعرت بالملل من طولها .. لأهل أثارت تساؤلات كثيرة داخلي .. نعم هل كانت الترجمة جيدة .. نعم ولهذا أصل للسؤال الأخر هل كانت تستحق القراءة ؟فأقول نعم ونعم ونعم لأ أدري لماذا ولا اعرف كيف أصفها فهي من تلك النوعية من الروايات التي تقف أمامها عاجزاً ولا تستطيع شيئاً سوى أن تحبها رغم اعتراضك على بعض ما جاء فيها هاروكي موراكامي ذلك الكاتب الغريب كيف استطاع ان يكتب عمل كهذا ؟كيف استطاع ان يربط كل الأحداث بهذا الشكل ؟في البداية تستغرب ما الذي يربط هؤلاء الاشخاص وهذه الأحداث ولكن تدريجياً يستطيع ببراعة أن يربطها ولا يترك شيئاً مهما كان صغيراً دون دور ذكرني بما قاله عن أنطون تشيخوف :" إذا ظهر مسدس في قصة ما فسيكون من الضروري في النهاية أن يطلق النار"وهاروكي موراكامي طبق هذا المبدأ في روايته فلم يظهر ولو خيط رفيع إلا وكان له دور ولو بعد حين يعيبها كثرة المشاهد الجنسية وتفكير الابطال فيه كثيراً بطريقة غريبة وكأن القصة تقوم على ذلك استمتعت بالرواية على الرغم من عدم فهمي للكثير ربما تحتاج للقراءة مرة أخرى .. ربما :)

Le palle sulla spiaggia "Poi, quando la tempesta sarà finita, probabilmente non saprai neanche tu come hai fatto ad attraversarla e a uscirne vivo. Anzi, non sarai neanche sicuro che sia finita per davvero. Ma su un punto non c'è dubbio. Ed è che tu, uscito da quel vento, non sarai lo stesso che vi era entrato." "Era un'erezione imponente, come la torre di Pisa fotografata dal basso durante carnevale."Il romanzo intesse elementi peculiari del mondo onirico all'interno del contesto reale; raccorda il profondo retaggio classico dell'autore con uno dei cavalli di battaglia più gettonati all'interno della produzione murakaniana: il percorso di formazione.Se sulla carta il progetto, forte della vena surreale intrinseca alla penna giapponese, poteva davvero risultare un qualcosa di vincente, all'atto pratico viene restituito un accrocco di situazioni che spaziano dall'improbabile all'allucinante (il segone sparato al protagonista per tranquillizzarlo; la sortita in biblioteca delle militanti femministe).Non è il singolo passaggio a fallire all'interno di un contesto magari dotato di vita propria, suggestivo per la forza immaginifica che lo muove; è esattamente quest'ultimo il reale problema dell'opera. Il contesto soffre di una vaghezza profonda, rea di mescolare (rullo di tamburi): un approccio dal taglio quasi giornalistico per gestire un episodio del 1946, oltre all'inserimento notizie strambe ma vere (la pioggia di pesci); un sincero omaggio alla letteratura americana, il quale cerca di coniugare il tema della fuga - caro a personaggi come Holden o Gatsby - con una visione shintoista e meditabonda più tipica della visione orientale (cringe a profusione per i momenti scult); l'abbattimento di alcuni tabù, soprattutto di natura sessuale, ove si minimizza il tutto con riflessioni del calibro di "che gentile, sicuramente è gay" e "ho la vagina, ma ho sempre usato l'ano perché non sono donna ma uomo"; dialoghi ripetitivi e strampalati per rendere il viaggio del duo Nakata-Hoshino carico di significati reconditi; l'ausilio dei miti di Aristofane ed Edipo per tratteggiare il lutto d'amore, nonché la crescita attraverso il complesso edipico (si tira in ballo anche Freud, nel marasma generale).Difficile poter salvare un romanzo in cui l'autore, come si evince da quanto scritto poc'anzi, metta pochissimo di suo perché lui per primo non ha nulla da trasmettere; eppure il Murakami di Norwegian wood mi conquistò nella delicatezza percepibile dietro le righe; per la necessità vera di dialogare con i giovani e instaurare un dialogo, non per forza volto all'elargire risposte (chi le ha, d'altronde?).Cos'è Kafka sulla spiaggia? Avete presente quel pacco regalo vuoto, magari impostato a matrioska con cartaccia riempitiva, che viene dato al malcapitato di turno per il classico scherzo da prete?Pari pari, con una confezione - leggasi: prosa - accattivante.

الرواية محيّرة...جدًّا. ستروق كثيرًا لفئة، وستكرهها فئة أخرى. وأجد نفسي في الوسط (ما شاء الله علي!)تدور أحداث (كافكا على الشاطئ) حول شخصيّتين بارزتيْن. الأولى شاب عمره 15 سنة اسمه كافكا، يقرّر الهروب من منزله في طوكيو، وينتهي به المطاف إلى مدينة أخرى تمامًا فيها مكتبة تدور حولها معظم أحداث الرواية. الشخصية الثانية: عجوز لا ذاكرة قويّة لديه، لا يقرأ ولا يكتب، ولكنّه يتحدّث مع القطط ويستطيع إنزال سمك من السماء! لنعد الآن إلى الفئتين:الفئة الأولى التي ستعجبها الرواية تكون في الغالب مولعة بالروايات غير واضحة المعالم، التي تترك للقارئ المساحة لأن يفسّر الأحداث بطريقته الخاصّة. رواية (كافكا على الشاطئ) تقوم بذلك إلى حدٍّ مؤذٍ. النهاية ليست فقط مفتوحة، بل غير مفهومة. الفئة الثانية التي ستكره الرواية تحب الوضوح. والرواية هذه لا تتسم بهذه الصفّة بتاتًا! إذ أنّها تستفزّك لأن تسأل كمّية كبيرة من الأسئلة دون أن تجيب على أيٍّ منها (صفر مكعّب!).بالنّسبة لي، استفزّتني الأسئلة ونجح المؤلّف في إرغامي على إكمال الرواية بكل فضول. لكنّي وجدت نفسي بعد 600 صفحة أقف وحيدًا مع كمّية لا بأس بها من الأسئلة. أعتقد أن كتاب مثل هذا يصلح لمجموعات القراءة لأنّها ستتسبب في كثير من النقاشات حول تفسير الأحداث. وجدتُ الشخصيات كلّها مثيرة وواضحة المعالم مما يحسب لموريكامي. في الجهة المقابلة بالغ المؤلف في وصف كلَّ شيء لدرجة مملّة. فيخبرك عن نوع الأغاني التي يحب كافكا سماعها، ونوع الرياضة التي يقوم بها، وأيُّ فلمٍ يشاهد، أو كتابٍ يقرأ لدرجة مملّة جدًّا. عالجتُ هذا بقفز الكثير من الفقرات حتّى أسلم من الرّتابة. مما يعيب العمل أيضـًا إكثاره من النقاشات الفلسفية غير واضحة المعالم التي يمررها على ألسن شخصيات القصّة. بعض النقاشات كانت ذات صلة وأخرى (مثل بضعة صفحات عن تحليل لحياة بيتهوفين) لم أجد لها أية فائدة.العمل مثير ومستفز وبالعامّي (يقهر). لذلك أعطيه 3\5

قبل كتابة مراجعتي أود الاعتذار من كل من أحب الرواية ولن يحب حتما مراجعتي، أول قراءة لي لموراكامي كانت جنوب الحدود غرب الشمس، كافكا على الشاطئ هي قراءتي الثانية، والأخيرة حتما.أولا وبما أنني شخص مولع بالأكل أثناء القراءة، فقد أوشكت على التقيؤ مرات غير معدودة أثناء قراءة هذه الرواية، ثانيا المعروف أنني لست من المولعين بالفانتازيا خصوصا إن كانت كهذه التي انتهيت منها حديثا.أردت كثيرا أن أحبها ولكنني لم أقدر على ذلك، يعني بالرواية مقاطع جذبتني وأحببتها ولكن الكل ككل لم يترك بنفسي أي أثر، كما أن العديد من المقاطع مقززة بشدة، آخذ مقطع قتل القطط كمثال.الرواية تتضمن حكايتان متقاطعتان، الأولى لولد في الخامسة عشرة هارب من نبوؤة أو لعنة لكم الاختيار، مفادها أنه سيقتل أباه ويعاشر أمه وأخته، ويمكنكم القول أنه قد حققها، أما الحكاية الثانية فهي للعجوز ناكاتا ذا النصف ظل والذي يبحث عن النصف الثاني.للأمانة فأنا لم أفهم المغزى من كل هذه الغرائبية ولربما ليس هناك من مغزى أصلا، لذلك لا أقدر الغوص في كلام أعبر به عن انبهاري بسحر الرواية وفلسفتها وما إلى ذلك... ما أنا سوى ناكاتا آخر.

I was dumbstruck that the author pushed me into several unfamiliar labyrinths all at once, leaving me to figure out his implications on my own. And I had nothing to motivate me to read on other than the hype surrounding the book. Kafka on the shore is slow paced and vividly descriptive well past the first half. Till then it just seems to be several random elements like an escapade, government files of a war event, zoolingualism, incestuous thoughts, dreams, supernatural possibilities, discussions on literature and music… jammed into one book. Once the story picks pace, you’re on a confusing yet rewarding journey. Pretty frills aside, the plot of Kafka on the shore goes as such:  Kafka runs away from his home in Tokyo to Takamatsu because Koichi, his father professed that Kafka would kill him and sleep with his mother and sister who abandoned them many years ago. Parallelly, simpleton Nakata’s search for a lost cat leads him to an evil cat killer whom he is forced to murder. Koichi has been killed (by Nakata – Kafka’s stand in). Immediately after the murder, Kafka regains consciousness miles away from the scene of crime with a blood stain on his shirt. Sakura, possibly Kafka's long lost sister sleeps with him to calm him down. In a few days he finds a job and accommodation in a private library coincidentally administered by Miss Saeki. Her soul visits Kafka in his room as her 15yr old self and as her 50yr old self. Kafka sleeps with Miss Saeki. Nakata reaches Takamatsu, procures the stone guarding the entrance to the time portal, opens it and dies soon afterwards. Kafka has an incestuous rape dream of Sakura. Miss Saeki dies and Kafka is guided into the time portal by two soldiers. Miss Saeki meets him there, admits to being his mother and convinces him to return to the world in all its intelligible reality before it’s too late. Kafka exits the time portal and plans to return to Tokyo to continue his education. Given his social withdrawal, lack of motivation and habit to respond to what I thought were auditory hallucinations, I had totally diagnosed Kafka with schizophrenia until I realized that it was his alter ego he was talking to. The unpredictable mystery, orderly chaos, pan-dimensional characters, absurdness, conversations with the alter ego, references to art forms from the past and metaphors gives the book a trip-down-the-rabbit-hole feel. One moment you’re rooted to present day Japan and the next moment a subtle nudge pushes you over the edge of time and space without your comprehending that it happened at all. There’s a bit of mind boggling soul wandering, time bending and symbolism in the book. I loved that the characters in the book discuss Arabian nights, Tales of Genji, Yeats, Beethoven, Jazz, Classical and Pop music. Although the feminism and LGBTQ representation felt forced and so out of place, the appearance of Colonel Sanders and Johnnie Walker, were colour bombs that brightened the facade of the story. But by the end, every character and incident make sense and they clarify each other making the story a perfect literary puzzle. Most loose ends were tied but finishing the book felt like waking up from a long surreal dream. And I'm glad I'm awake.

I could write a one-sentence review of this book, saying that it features Beethoven, talking cats and obsessive love and that therefore I couldn't but love it. Or I could write another one-sentence review, stating that it's Murakami and that therefore it's inherently good and interesting. Both of these statements would be true and more or less complete, but all the same I think I'll go into slightly more detail.Kafka on the Shore is a story about a fifteen-year-old bookworm who calls himself Kafka (as you do) and runs away from home, partly to look for his lost mother and sister, but mostly to get away from his horrible father, whose crimes against him are never fully explained. Fate draws him to a town where, among other things, he meets two women who may well be his mother and sister, which doesn't prevent him from having sex with them. His story, which is as Oedipal as they come, is intersected with that of Nakata, a sixty-year-old simpleton who, among many other unique gifts, can talk to cats. It quickly transpires that Kafka's and Nakata's lives are interconnected, but exactly how this is doesn't become clear until the end, if indeed it does then.There is much to enjoy here. As always, Murakami's prose is supremely efficient; every sentence matters and takes you closer to the inevitable denouement. As always, the characters are tremendously likeable and off-beat. One could argue that they're not entirely three-dimensional, but who cares when they have such a story to tell? For theirs is quite a story. Like all of Murakami's 'weird' books, Kafka on the Shore is light on facts and heavy on metaphysical stuff. It's not a book for those who like straightforward stories; many of the questions raised are left unanswered, which I love but which will leave those who are of a slightly more literal bent unsatisfied. Nor is it a book for people who care about realism. What with its curses, entrances to other worlds, mackerel rainstorms, ghosts, concepts assuming human form and heavy emphasis on fate, destiny and reincarnation, Kafka on the Shore has a distinctly fairy-tale-like atmosphere, which is probably why I liked it so much (apart from it featuring Beethoven, talking cats and obsessive love, I mean). Parts of the story were clearly inspired by Japanese mythology. In its own turn, I can see this book being the inspiration for a very good Japanese movie. Maybe it has a little too much violence and incest in it to be turned into an anime film, but I can think of quite a few 'regular' Japanese directors who could do great things with this particular brand of mysterious magic realism. Which begs the question: how come the book hasn't been adapted to the screen yet?Anyhow, to cut a long story short (and to prevent this turning into a panegyric on Japanese cinema), I loved this book. If I'm not giving it five stars, that's because it lacks the emotional resonance of Norwegian Wood (my favourite Murakami book so far) and because Philip Gabriel's translation is a little too American for my taste. If I could give it four and a half stars, though, I would -- for the skilful way in which Murakami weaves together his two storylines, for his haunting descriptions of the power of memories and longing, for the many matter-of-fact weird touches he adds (Johnnie Walker and Colonel Sanders, anyone?), and, naturally, for his throwing in Beethoven, talking cats and obsessive love. It doesn't get any better than that, does it?

3 saoLần đầu tiên mình đọc một cuốn sách có thể loại gọi là "siêu thực", nên cho dù xuyên suốt sách là 2 hành trình song song mang nhiều nét quái dị của 2 nhân vật tưởng chừng như không liên hệ gì với nhau, thì mình cũng rất kiên nhẫn ghi nhớ từng sự kiện một, những mong đến cuối truyện sẽ được giải đáp tất cả. Câu chuyện diễn biến càng lạ lùng chừng nào lại làm mình háo hức đọc chừng nấy, giống như một bài toán càng có nhiều điều kiện thì việc tìm ra đáp án lại càng khó và càng lôi cuốn người giải. Chắc tại mình quen đọc thể loại trinh thám, quen được tác giả nuông chiều, chu đáo lo hết thảy cho đến ẩn số cuối cùng, thế nên đọc đến cuối truyện mà không có một lời giải đáp nào được đưa ra làm mình cảm thấy rất hẫng. Nhất là càng về cuối lại càng nhiều câu văn lời thoại dông dài vô ích, hy vọng tìm ra lời giải của mình lại càng mong manh hơn qua mỗi trang sách được lật.Tất nhiên là truyện cũng có gợi mở một chút gì đó, nhưng nó cũng như những truyện có kết thúc mở. Nói tích cực thì người đọc khi đọc sách phải đặt đầu óc mình vào tư duy chứ không phải chỉ biết những gì tác giả bày ra. Nhưng tiêu cực thì có thể nói tác giả lười biếng, có khi chính ông cũng không tìm ra lời giải hợp lý cho tất cả những thứ lớn lao mình đã đặt vào sách nên thôi cứ để mọi thứ hư hư thực thực, nhiều tranh cãi lại chẳng thành hiện tượng :/. Đây cũng là cuốn đầu tiên của Haruki Murakami mà mình đọc nên mình cũng không dám kết luận. Và mình sẽ đọc thêm một quyển khác thuộc thể loại này của ông, đến lúc đó mới có thể nói là ông có chủ động trong việc kết thúc câu chuyện của mình không, hay truyện kết thúc bởi vì nó đã đi vào đường cùng, chính tác giả cũng không tìm ra lối đi tiếp hay ngay cả quay về.Mình đã từng đọc và xem nhiều phim thể loại tâm lý, kỳ bí với một không khí chung nhiều bức bách, nhiều điều khó hiểu xuyên suốt cho đến tận cuối phim, nhưng sau khi kết thúc lúc nào mình cũng tìm ra được một vài lý giải hợp lý tháo gỡ khúc mắc cho toàn bộ câu chuyện. Kết thúc có thể lửng lơ nhưng cũng ngầm bảo với mình rằng mình có quyền chọn một đáp án nào mình thấy phù hợp. Còn đối với quyển sách này thì mình chịu, không thể nào tìm ra một lời giải nào khả dĩ tạm chấp nhận được, chứ không mong thỏa mãn hết thảy những thách đố tác giả đã đặt ra.Bỏ vấn đề này sang một bên thì cuốn sách còn nhiều điều chưa khiến mình hài lòng. Có 2 nhân vật chính, một cậu bé 15 tuổi và ông cụ hơn 60 tuổi, xét về mặt tính cách thì cậu bé tự đặt tên cho mình là Kafka ấy quá là không thể chịu nổi. Lại một nhân vật hoàn hảo từ đầu đến cuối, với ngoại hình vô cùng nổi bật khiến cậu đi đâu cũng tạo cảm tình cho người khác, khiến người khác -những người không quen biết, chỉ mới gặp lần đầu - phải làm cho cậu những việc mà những tưởng các nhân vật phải thân thiết, gắn bó với nhau lắm thì mới làm được. Ừ thì mình hiểu, các nhân vật này không quan trọng, cuộc hành trình này là của cậu bé đó, chỉ quan trọng là điểm khởi đầu và điểm kết thúc, quá trình ở giữa tự khắc sẽ có không người này thì người khác dẫn dắt để cậu ta đến với nơi đã định. Nhưng điều khiến mình thấy không có thiện cảm với nhân vật này là những suy nghĩ của cậu ta quá gượng ép, quá lớn, quá kỳ dị, nhất là những chi tiết liên quan đến tình dục, quá lạ thường, không hề khiến cho mình thấy ngại mà chỉ thấy kinh tởm. Những thứ này quá lớn so với cái vỏ ngoài 15 tuổi của cậu ta, đến nỗi sau đó lại khiến mình thấy mâu thuẫn với những đoạn cậu lấy cái lý do mình mới 15 tuổi để lý giải cho những cảm xúc gợi nhắc cho cậu ta về tuổi của mình.Nhân vật ông lão Nakata ban đầu được khắc họa khá là dễ mến, nhưng càng về sau cái sự bị động và mâu thuẫn giữa ý thức và hành động của ông cũng làm cho mình không thích ông nữa. Phải theo dõi 2 tuyến hành trình của những nhân vật mình không thích cũng thật là khó chịu.Một điều nữa về quyển sách này là Murakami quá ham phô bày kiến thức, từ nhạc Bethoveen cho đến tiểu sử của người nhạc sĩ này, từ việc đấu tranh nữ quyền, chiến tranh Do Thái đến Napoleon, đều ngẫu hứng được các nhân vật phát biểu khi đang trò chuyện với nhau. Tất nhiên nếu những chi tiết này có đóng góp vào cốt truyện hay tính cách nhân vật thì mình chẳng có lý do gì phàn nàn, đằng này mọi thứ được phát biểu một cách rất ngẫu nhiên, nhân vật nói ra rất đột ngột và kết thúc cũng thế, làm mình chỉ có thể nghĩ một cách thiển cận là tác giả phô bày kiến thức của mình, khi chưa tìm được lời giải thích nào khác hay mối liên hệ của chúng với câu chuyện.Tất nhiên, mình biết những người đọc sách của Haruki Murakami rất nhiều, và người hâm mộ ông cũng không ít. Khi đọc sách của một tác giả như vậy mà cảm thấy có vấn đề gì đó, hẳn ta sẽ nghĩ vấn đề lại xuất phát từ phía mình trước khi dám nói gì về tác giả. Nhưng mình thuộc kiểu đi đến đâu thì gắn một cột mốc ở đó, có khi mình quay lại đây có khi lại không nên mình cũng ghi lại vài dòng cảm nghĩ này, dù nó có nông cạn hay nóng vội, nhưng đó cũng là suy nghĩ mình cho là đúng, nếu có lần quay lại hy vọng mình sẽ có những cảm nhận khác.

When the wind blows, the sea trembles like a shy, little girl. In a far distance, the crimson sun sets. You hear a piano piece playing over and over again. You are not sure if the music is in your head or a pair of expert hands are playing with your consciousness. Your hair dances and you close your eyes with the warmth, forgetting the woes that once defined you. And that's what Kafka On The Shore is, That's what it will ever be.I was drawn to this book for the mood that it presented. It opened my imagination and set my spirit spinning with possibilities and ideas. It's rare to find a story with this effect. The prose, as always by Murakami, it's charming, smooth, and intelligent without being pretentious. An amazing read.Murakami has concocted a contemporary blend of Oedipus and Orpheus, East and West, Freud and Jung, Hegel and Marx, Tales of Genji and Arabian Nights, Shinto and Buddhism, abstraction and action, alternating narratives and parallel worlds, seriousness and play, not to mention classical, jazz and pop music. He doesn't provide much detail but gives you irrefragable operative truths in his written work, the rational closure-seeking mind may not find a welcome place here.As I finish this review, I’m very excited. Yes, I know that I’ve got my memories to look back to, but what I’m excited about are those memories that haven’t been made yet. The future is ahead of me, I’ve got time on my hands. The possibilities are endless.

At times reading this book felt like reading a water color painting the rippling language that connected the reality to the spiritual realm highlighted the connection of western literature (and pop culture) to life in a remote Japanese village. It did have a few WTF moments, well more than a few, actually you could argue this entire book was a what the fuck moment but the poetic language that came out, especially in the dialogue, created a truly profound impact on me as a reader. Whether it be the conversation of free will between Johnnie Walker and Nakata, fate between Hoshino and Colonel Sanders, Memories between Kafka and Miss Saeki, or gender and identity from the lips of Oshima, this work held a western filtered mirror to eastern life in a way that Joyce followed the Odyssey in Ulysses with a tidal wave of Oedipus.Actually Oedupus was the engine, because (SPOILER) Kafka was actively trying to pursue the prophecy, which is fascinating (and WTF) because I've never read a book before that had such a proactive protagonist pursuing such a non-heroic prophecy. Will I read more Murakami? Yes, but I think I need a fucking break and a fucking drink.
