[may contain slight spoilers]My second succesful foray into Murakami opus. After the weirdness of Hard Boiled Wonderland, I thought Kafka was quite tame in the beginning. Sure, there's some Twilight Zone incident with school kids at the end of World War II and a mysterious "boy named Crow" but for almost half of the book this read like a standard angsty teenager running away from home. Superbly written of course, but what's all the buzz surrounding this book?Oh wait: talking cats ! cute ... quirky ... I'm heading into Do'Des Ka Den territory. I couldn't have been more wrong. A couple of chapters later I went into weirdness overdrive with claw out my eyes out bloody horror scenes, leeches raining down from clear skies, hookers quoting Hegel and Western cultural icons giving lessons in Buddhism.Murakami doesn't like his reader to get too comfortable in his armchair and loves to throw a spanner in the works, throwing a linear storyline out of kilter and into uncharted territory - strange landscapes of the subconscious. Still, his violence, overt sexuality and general queerness is never gratuitous. Each supernatural incident has a role in pushing the story forward, and even if by the end some of the weird things will be left unexplained, enough keys to decode the metaphors are provided in the text. Like this line from Chekhov about the rules of dramaturgy : If a pistol appears in a story, eventually its got to be fired  .The whole world is a metaphor in Kafka on the Shore, the author deftly weaving into the narrative the curse of Oedipus, the fable of Hansel and Gretel, Orpheus descending into the land of the dead and much more. Placing most of the action in and around a library is a device used by many authors, probably because it permits deconstructing the surface story and go to the essence, extracting meaning from events and conflicts. It also allows the author to introduce tangential topics like feminism or gay pride, war or consumerism.In a way similar to Hard Boiled Wonderland, the book is structured in two parralel streams, apparently unrelated, developing independently but constanly converging towards a final confrontation / revelation / epiphany that seems predetermined from the start of the book - either by Fate, the Gods or the inability of the human actor to break free of the pattern.Kafka Tamura : "the toughest fifteen year old on the planet" , is the quintessential teenager on the edge of the precipice. Will he be able to leave the nest of family, school and social ties that has ruled his life so far? Will he soar free, self reliant and responsible for his actions or will he crash to the ground under the burden of insecurity, betrayals and loneliness? He is constantly trying to build up his physical body with daily exercises and to flex his neurons with all the books that fall in his hands. In one of my favorite quotes from the book, the answer is to be found inside himself: The strength I’m looking for isn’t the kind where you win or lose. I’m not after a wall that’ll repel power coming from outside. What I want is the kind of strength to be able to absorb that outside power, to stand up to it. The strength to quietly endure things—unfairness, misfortune, sadness, mistakes, misunderstandings Nakata is the protagonist of the second storyline. He's old and poor, he's not very smart, but he has his heart in the right place. An accident in his youth leaves him an "empty vessel" , unable to read or to find a job. He is the one character that reminded me of Kurosawa and his beautiful people living at the outskirts of civilized life. His misfortune has not made him bitter, he is helping his neigbors find stray cats, and his greatest joy is to eat eel from time to time. Fate, in the form of a Johnny Walker alter ego pushes him out of his familiar territory and onto a journey of self discovery and redemption. Along the way, he strucks a friendship with another "hollow" man - a truck driver drifting through life without aim or reason.The two stories, one of a youth at the start of his independent life, and one of an old man man trying to recapture his youth, dance around one another to a soundtrack switching between Schubert, Haydn or Beethoven, and John Coltrane, Prince or The Beatles towards a haunting pop song written by a young girl in love. There's also a well chosen reference to Francois Truffaut masterpiece "Les quatrecent coups" . A better hidden reference points to Jim Morrison and his open doors of perception. You'll know it when you come across it : "Come on baby, light my fire!"Another recurring theme I have identified after only two books, is the revelation of the meaning of life, to be found sitting at the edge of the ocean, in full summer sunshine, eventually with some scattered fluffly white clouds.For all these Western cultural references, Kafka on the shore is at heart a Japanese book. I was lucky to have read recently Kwaidan by Lafcadio Hearn, so I could pick up the source of the traditional ghost stories used as inspiration and foundation for this novel. Murakami offers further reading material suggestions in the text with his references to Ueda Akinari - Tales of Moonlight and Rain and to the novels of Natsume Soseki. I plan to read them, too.A few words about the humor : it's there to be found in the text, and provide a welcome breather from the deeper and darker main themes. Ranging from the absurd conversations with Colonel Sanders of KFC fame, to sarcastic felines or earthy jokes hinting at the best way to lose 5 pounds, the humor serves to illustrate the full range of Murakami abilities. Sometimes the joking is serious : Listen, every object’s in flux. The Earth, time, concepts, love, life, faith, justice, evil—they’re all fluid and in transition. They don’t stay in one form or in one place forever. The whole universe is like some big FedEx box. I could go on with my musings, but really, I'm not worthy. Go read the original.

I wish I could say I enjoyed this more than I did. I don't seem to have read anything I've really liked for weeks now, and I hoped this would break the pattern; the plot sounded appealing, I have a liking for magical realism, and having been intrigued by the hype surrounding Murakami's latest book 1Q84, I thought this earlier novel - which seems to be both very popular and very highly rated on Goodreads - would be a good introduction to the author. I read this over Christmas, and haven't been taking notes or drafting a review, so I can't really give the usual in-depth assessment of it, but here's a summary anyway...It started well, with chapters alternating between two protagonists - 'Kafka', a fifteen-year-old boy who has run away from home to escape an Oedipal prophecy made by his father, and Nakata, an elderly simpleton who can talk to cats and seems to possess other mystical powers. There were elements I really liked - the humour, the mystery, the touches of magic (talking cats that know everything!) and the promise of a complex and interlinked series of fantastical events. So far, so intriguing, but unfortunately I just didn't feel the book ever delivered on that early promise. It explored a lot of issues and theories surrounding philosophy, the power of thought, etc etc, but seemed to have a tendency to touch on these briefly, give a summary of some concept or other (often rather artificially forced into the dialogue) and then move on. Although I thought the sex scenes were actually pretty good, I couldn't help but be a bit disturbed by the context of them (the age gap on its own was pretty weird even without the possibility of Miss Saeki being Kafka's mother). Much of what happened was obviously supposed to be metaphorical, but the blurring of the lines between metaphor, dreams and reality meant I just ended up not really knowing what the story was trying to say. I found Kafka on the Shore interesting and readable, but by the end, I couldn't help but feel that a lot of what I'd spent all that time reading had been completely pointless. There's so much exposition, so many lengthy descriptions of the minutiae of life, so many diversions into characters' histories; not that this has to be a bad thing, but I kind of assumed it was all going to be FOR something, yet hardly any of it had anything to do with the crux and/or climax of the story. I found Murakami's style interesting enough that I DO want to read more by the author, despite the low rating I've given this book. Not so enthusiastic about picking up the epic 1Q84 now, however.

This was my second Murakami and was picked up after much hesistation and mulling over. I was maybe not ready to be hit with something so intense.Kafka on the shore proved to be so impacting and forceful, I lapped up at words and structure of the theme of the book. Murakami had me tight in the folds of his perceptual writing and I couldn't help feeling the weirdness of the characters spread over me. It is not wrong to say that I never wanted the book to be finished and wanted to know the characters of Nakata, Oshima and Hiroshi like I know my skin. I particularly loved the words of wisdom passed by Oshima to Tamura. Having read this, I am definately picking up another Murakami for a a deep dive into the space of emptiness and fullfillment.

~ Imperfection ~Why is it hence— some people are always drawn towards imperfections; broken, shoddy, raw, downtrodden, messy… all constitute beauty for their Imperfection-seeking eyes. Ergo imperfect people, imperfect surroundings, imperfect lives… carry a certain undiscovered charm for a selected few, glossed over by the usual crowd. Isn't Imperfection the hallmark of beauty, after all! Imperfection beauty; Beauty imperfection.Isn't nature itself imperfectly perfect in its propensity! Little by little, glued together in a canvas, these imperfections create a perfect expanse of art. I would patently choose an imperfect life, imperfect man and imperfect book any day over the vast sea of seemingly perfect dwellers unconscious of their imperfections, blinded by obvious perfections satiating their pride.The pertaining metaphysical fiction slowly grows on you and is undoubtedly an acquired taste, earthily elite in its entirety. Thus, the highly flawed and imperfect review— analogous to the book and the author it praises— retains Murakami's beauty and attraction. Consequently, a feeling was reached regarding this book; an imperfect accumulation of events, resulting in an imperfect piece of art, imperfectly executed, imperfectly read and imperfectly reviewed. Murakami, shrouded in his imperfect art, will always stand unique to this flawed being for evoking magic lurking in mundane and ordinary, cradling tenderness amid bizarre, and all in all its mysteries, bringing one a surreal reading experience.Inside the pages of Kafka on the ShoreInitially, to outset with the obvious, Murakami's commendable usage of classical Greek literature and mythology. Foremost, as perceptible, the book is a modern take on Oedipus Rex by 
Sophocles
, as debated in the book by the author's mouthpiece Oshima (if one has read the original Greek tragedy, one could discern many parallel characters). The ensuing classical theme Murikami employs is Aristophanes' response taken from Plato's Symposium. Aristophanes' speech delineates how man was split in half by Zeus and now looking for the other missing half; similarly, the characters are searching for their missing selves. Finally, Cassandra's curse is propounded. (This introvert will suppress her geek mode here and avoid going into mythological details).Moving on, Murakami unhurriedly builds his characters and situations— slowly shrouds them in metaphors before reaching the climax. It is not a simple tale but layered; in order to fully grasp it, one must take a Kierkegaardian 'Leap of faith' to plunge into this metaphorical journey with the author in the land of magical realism and beyond, blurring the boundaries of conscious and unconscious— a land where the former and the latter have no distinct demarcations. Nonetheless, the tale is simple at heart, carrying the weight of the human psyche. Inside emotional traumas collapsing with the external adversaries, sometimes resolving themselves, others complicating— while always preset there, never diminishing entirely or killing one eternally. One faces a limbo of forever mental and emotional labyrinth in the name of what they call 'Life'. 
"But thing in the past are like plate that's shattered to pieces. You can never put it back together like it was, right?"
Furthering to psychoanalytical realms...Aren't we all fighting some psychological battles, leaping roots back to our first memories and hence a never-ending labyrinth extending and shrinking, never vanishing, a beast with a life of his own. Ain't it, each man on the face of earth bearing a scarred child in the womb of his psyche, hiding from the vicious grasping eyes of the world, perpetually flawed and shattered, nonetheless nourishing its sustenance, till last breaths. Death— the real liberator!Oh man— your eternal love,misery, your forever sweetheart, the tantalising past!The ramblings must be halted; hence one must surmise that all of the little 
Freud
 and 
Lacan
 this humble learner read could be applied here and more. By the time the story reached the climax, this being was so high on Murakami and his metaphors that Kafka Tamura was I and I Kafka… (how could I've found common ground with a 15-year boy, well, isn't this where literature stands, finding pieces of yourself). Conclusively, if the sole duty of the author was to craft relatable existential angst for the readers, then Murakami excelled in it and captured the youth at will.Finally, in all his obscurity, Murakami is a didactic man; as propagated, there is no saving but acceptance, one has to accept, and none will be their rescuer. Alternatively, maybe she is overreaching, but readers, let her, as the most depressing situations sometimes, somewhere hide the most sanguine alternatives, a silver lining— as for every hell, there must be heaven.

A captivating and intriguing story intertwining the lives of a troubled teenage runaway with a man who converses with cats. SUMMARY Kafka Tamura is a troubled 15-year-old boy, who runs away to escape his sinister father and to search for his long-missing mother and sister. Shortly after Kafka runs away his father is murdered. Kafka wakes up hundreds of miles away to find himself covered in blood. He finds refuge in a small, private library in a town by the sea where he spends his time reading and contemplating his life and his future. He assists and is assisted by two librarians, the welcoming Oshima and the the remote Miss Saeki in becoming “the toughest 15-year-old in the world.”Satoru Nakata, is an aging simple man, who has never fully recovered from a childhood incident. This mysterious incident caused him to lose all his memories, as well as his ability to read and write, but he gained the ability to communicate with cats. This skill earns him a little extra money when he is occasionally hired to find his neighbors missing pets. It is in his search for Goma the cat, that Nakata encounters Johnnie Walker, a cat soul-stealer and things don’t go so well between these two men. Nakata is later befriended by a truck driver, Hoshino who takes him on as a passenger. Hoshino become very fond of the old man who reminds him of his grandfather. Nakata and Oshino’s ride turns into quite an adventure. “It's not just that I'm dumb. Nakata's empty inside. I finally understand that. Nakata's like a library without a single book. It wasn't always like that. I used to have books inside me. For a long time I couldn't remember, but now I can. I used to be normal, just like everybody else. But something happened and I ended up like a container with nothing inside.” REVIEWWhat an intriguing book that is both imaginative and inventive! The book raises more questions than it answers, which is precisely what makes it so intriguing. Author Haruki Murakami says the key to understanding this book is to read it several times. I have only read it once so can’t claim to understand it but I certainly enjoyed it. There is so much to appreciate in this book with references to pop culture, magical realism. alternate reality, mystery and humor. The writing is lyrical, captivating and engaging. My absolute favorite part of the book was Nakata’s character. His manner of speaking was charming and his conversation with cats was just amusing. Overall, Kafka on the Shore is a complex, riddle filled, delightful read. “Closing your eyes isn't going to change anything. Nothing's going to disappear just because you can't see what's going on. In fact, things will even be worse the next time you open your eyes. That's the kind of world we live in. Keep your eyes wide open. Only a coward closes his eyes. Closing your eyes and plugging up your ears won't make time stand still.” Publisher 	Random House AudioPublished 	August 6, 2013Narrator	 Seán Barrett, Oliver Le SueurReview	 www.bluestockingreviews.com

بعضی از رمان ها انگار که دارند با مغز انسان بازی می کنند. موراکامی رمانی نوشته است که در آن خیلی راحت می شود با گربه ها حرف زد، از آسمان زالو و ماهی ببارد و شما نیز انگار نه انگار که چیزی غیر واقعی اتفاق افتاده است، باید که بخوانید و لذت ببرید.رمانی که نمی شود همه ی داشته هایش را یکجا بیان کرد، رمانی سیال، با دو داستان موازی و شخصیت هایی منحصر به فرد، پسری که فقط اسم مستعارش را می دانیم ��کافکا تامورا»، مردی تهی و خالی از همه ی احساسات انسانی که می تواند با گربه ها حرف بزند، پسری دگرباش، زنی میانسال مرموز، گربه هایی سخن گو و ...، انگار که همه ی اینها را خواننده در خواب می بیند یا بهتر بگویم مثل این است که تمام داستان رویایی است مرموز.استفاده ی بسیار عالی موراکامی از موسیقی (جاز و کلاسیک)، فلسفه (بخصوص هگل)، ادبیات کلاسیک ژاپن و دنیا (نمونه مدرن افسانه ی اودیپ)و بسیاری ریزه کاری های دیگر از این نویسنده، داستانی را به ارمغان آورده است که خواننده را دچار بهتی همراه با لذت می کند.

I would never understand the underlying meaning of all the mystical overtones Murakami weaves throughout the book. Maybe it is never meant to make sense. In the midst of all the heavy magical realism I was left starving for meaning throughout the read hunting down for symbolisms, allegories that would tie this all together petering out in a anticipatory satisfaction. But it never did. It disappointingly goes along with characters' whims with no end in sight.But it built an innocuous frustration brewing in the aftermath. A frustration that pulled me from a lull, a lethargic limbo of dormancy. A dormancy I currently find difficult to get myself out of. But this dormancy is beautiful and so is the frustration it is was being sourced from. Not once in the book I felt like abandoning and starting off with something new. It is something I don’t understand but wonder about at the same time. I wonder if this can be termed as appreciation or a mere inkling of confusion.Murakami builds these characters carefully in spite what his careless logic would fool you into something else. This I guess is my new venture into the unexplored realms of magical realism. It is those intricately woven situations which come out to be brazen and absurdly sticking out with heavy visualizations. As for the intelligent references, Oedipus complex, the prophecy and the yin-yang polarities between the characters are something which don’t stand out in a way to hinder the flow of the mesmerizing fantasy.Murakami’s work are termed as simple but profoundly complex. Complex I believe is not the complex bit and pieces tied together building up towards a bravado that blows you away in a temporary ecstasy. It is the never ending journey of myriad of emotions, of twisted logic, a tantalizing absurdity that leaves a bit of it with you and stays. It is inexplicable yet unavoidable.It’s like the bursting of vivacious firecrackers into the dark quite sky in the night of harmless sadness. This vivacity is probably a testimony to our unresolved urge of bending the rules of logic and reason. It is not meant to make sense in the short term.Come to think of it, this is a celebration of madness that resides in our subconscious. What may seem to be vacuous on surface, an intelligence resides in the choices made by the characters. The freedom they chose to explore, the choices they are free to exploit is something any reader trying to satisfy the temptation of getting out of touch with reality would relate to.

Με διαφορά το πιο μεγαλεπήβολο και σουρεαλιστικό βιβλίο του Χαρούκι Μουρακάμι που διαβάζω, από τα τέσσερα βιβλία του που έχω διαβάσει μέχρι στιγμής. Η αλήθεια είναι ότι μου έλειψε πολύ το υπέροχο και άκρως ευκολοδιάβαστο στιλ γραφής του, καθώς και η θεματολογία του. Μιλάμε ότι πέρασαν πάνω από δύο χρόνια από την τελευταία φορά που έπεσε βιβλίο του στα χέρια μου. Θα φροντίσω να μην ξαναπεράσει τόσος καιρός μέχρι το επόμενο βιβλίο του. Για την πλοκή τι να πω; Δύσκολα μπορεί να γράψει κανείς μια ικανοποιτηική περίληψη. Ουσιαστικά η ιστορία χωρίζεται σε δυο μέρη, τα οποία συνδέονται με ιδιαίτερο τρόπο: Από την μια παρακολουθούμε τον συμπαθητικό και μοναδικό δεκαπεντάχρονο Κάφκα Ταμούρα, που παρατάει το σχολείο και την κάνει από το σπίτι του για όσο πιο μακριά γίνεται, σ'ένα ταξίδι φυγής και συνάμα ενηλικίωσης, έχοντας ως σκοπό να βρει την μητέρα και την αδερφή του, που έχουν εξαφανιστεί από χρόνια. Από την άλλη έχουμε τον άκρως συμπαθητικό και παράξενο γεράκο ονόματι Νακάτα, που λόγω ενός περίεργου ατυχήματος όταν ήταν μικρός, έχασε την ικανότητα να διαβάζει και να σκέπτεται σύνθετα πράγματα. Τώρα έχει ένα σκοπό στην ζωή του, να βρει τον χαμένο εαυτό του. Αυτά, σε μια παντελώς απλοποιημένη περίληψη, που δεν περιγράφει την τρέλα του βιβλίου... Λοιπόν, το βιβλίο είναι ένα άκρως σουρεαλιστικό και φανταστικό παραμύθι, γεμάτο γρίφους, συμβολισμούς, μεταφορές και φιλοσοφικές αναφορές. Δεν υπάρχει περίπτωση ο αναγνώστης να βρει όλες τις απαντήσεις στα ερωτήματα που ανακύπτουν κατά την διάρκεια της ανάγνωσης, τουλάχιστον όχι με την πρώτη φορά. Ακόμα και οι απαντήσεις που ίσως βρείτε, μπορεί να μην είναι οι μοναδικές "σωστές". Το θέμα είναι ότι ναι μεν η ιστορία ασχολείται με περίπλοκες έννοιες και ιδιαίτερα θέματα, όμως, διάολε, η γραφή είναι τόσο υπερβολικά ευκολοδιάβαστη, ξεκούραστη, υπέροχη, απίθανη, που σε κάνει να βυθίζεσαι στο σύμπαν του βιβλίου, ξεχνώντας την πραγματικότητα γύρω σου. Και όχι μόνο αυτό, οι χαρακτήρες είναι ιδιαίτερα καλογραμμένοι και ενδιαφέροντες, που νοιάζεσαι για την τύχη τους, γίνεσαι ένα με τα προβλήματά τους. Ειλικρινά, μπορώ να πω ότι ενθουσιάστηκα από την γραφή του Μουρακάμι και, φυσικά, από την ιστορία. Σίγουρα δεν "έπιασα" τα πάντα, όμως απόλαυσα μια μοναδική και ιδιαίτερη ιστορία, γεμάτη φαντασία και σύνθετα νοήματα. Πρόκειται για μια άκρως ευκολοδιάβαστη και απολαυστική ανάγνωση, που πιστεύω ότι έχει να προσφέρει πολλά στον αναγνώστη, αρκεί να έχει το μυαλό του ανοιχτό και δεκτικό σε σουρεαλιστικές και ονειρικές καταστάσεις.

“There’s a chance something strange might happen.”“Are you kidding me? Everything’s been strange enough already.”This was my second Murakami, and though it didn’t delight me quite as much as The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle, which I read earlier in the year, I still loved it. Again we have screwy World War II history, playfulness regarding time and memory, dreams and other alternative states of being, cats in peril, and quite a bit of sex. But here myth and symbol take on greater significance. There’s an Oedipal prophecy over 15-year-old Kafka Tamura’s life, and doubles/substitutes and portals to other worlds also play a major role. Kafka takes refuge in a library, where he is taken under the androgynous Oshima’s wing. Meanwhile, Nakata, a simpleton who finds lost cats and can communicate with them (“Strangely enough, with cats he never ran out of things to talk about”), has gotten caught up in a dark situation he doesn’t understand, and sets off on his own journey. Kafka’s first-person chapters alternate with third-person chapters about Nakata, which makes you eager to keep reading and get back to each story. I can’t pretend to get everything that goes on here, especially how Nakata and Miss Saeki are connected and what exactly the Boy Named Crow is supposed to signify. I also thought the last 60 pages or so were rather sluggish, and Hoshino’s slang was annoying. But I love diving into Murakami’s strange fictional worlds, and it’s great knowing I have so much of his back catalogue to discover next year.

You know how sometimes you're reading a book and you think "God, this is weird and not great" but you're already like halfway through so you've invested far too much of your time in this to just give up on it? So you trudge on, hoping against hope that it gets better. Well... this book just doesn't get better. So if you're in the first 100 pages and you're thinking, "boy, this is getting strange in a weirdly uncomfortable way," I suggest you just stop reading and save yourself the trouble.So here are the parts of the book that literally just did not need to exist: HALF THE BOOK (maybe more)But let's get a little bit more specific. There were a couple of scenes in the book that were just so beyond unnecessary that I don't even understand. (TW for rape and sexual abuse I guess) 1. The scene in the library where Oshima tells off the "feminists." I get that the entire thing was obviously there so that Kafka could find out about Oshima's gender orientation (what is Oshima's gender orientation? Is he transgender? Because he refers to himself as a man and then calls himself sexless, and a gay woman. What. And then everybody else describes him as all of these things too) but it was so beyond unnecessary and was absolutely the scene where I knew that I would absolutely NOT enjoy this book. 2. Every sex scene. I mean, other than the fact that they were all super incest-y and rape-y and downright weird, they were just not good sex scenes (Why did every woman want to drink semen? Women don't want that. STOP.) The first sex scene with Kafka and Ms. Saeki was well, not a sex scene, it was a rape scene because she was sleep walking and he thinks "maybe I should stop her" but then doesn't because he's a horny 15 year old apparently. Cool. Then there was the dream rape-scene with Sakura a.k.a his sister. And that wasn't bad enough but dream-Sakura says "hey, you're raping me but it's okay as long as you can accept that we won't see each other again." Um, okay. Great. None of this is fucked up at all.Then there was the scene with Hoshino and the prostitute when he's trying to find the entrance stone that literally had zero purpose. Why was that there? WHY? Also the letter that the primary school teacher writes near the beginning about how she hit Nakata before all the kids fainted. And she went into explicit detail about her sex dream with her husband and how turned on she was for the entire day. Again... WHY?3. Mr. Nakata's backstory. I mean, I get it, he was the person who was taking care of the entrance stone and he had to kill Kafka's dad because Kafka left but the whole fainting thing was never explained, neither was the half a shadow thing. It was just stuff thrown in there to say "whoah, look how weird!" Considering the whole fainting thing is what got me interested in the book to begin with, I was very, VERY disappointed.After finishing the book, I also have a LOT of questions because literally nothing was answered and absolutely nothing made sense. - Was the entire book supposed to be a reference to some Greek mythology full of incest? Because all I know about Oedipus is really from studying a bit of Freud and reading Hamlet. - Why did Kafka's dad prophesize weird incestuous things about him? Nothing about this made any sense whatsoever. - How is Ms. Saeki Kafka's mother and Sakura his sister when he is also Ms. Saeki's dead lover?- Why did the Colonel Sanders character need to exist? (alternatively, why did Murakami use a load of random characters that were basically all-knowing omniscient in order to explain away the lack of motivations of every single character in this book?) - Why did Kafka always think about women being related to him just before jacking off/sleeping with them... while running away from him dad because he didn't want to fulfill an incest prophesy? Did he not see the irony? Does nobody see the irony?- What was the entire point of the fish and eel raining from the sky other than to say "hey, this book is really weird and quirky and strange things happen"? - What was the point of Johnnie Walker? Why did we need to read a scene about him torturing cats? - Was Crow just Kafka's weird alter-ego who was also in reality a crow? etc etc. The list of questions are probably endless because the book did such a poor job of explaining anything. Murakami is also a pretty sloppy writer a lot of the time. He has passage after passage, describing very banal things (in a very banal way) that contributes nothing to the story. His prose isn't bad but it's not great either. Basically, unless you're a fan of incest, rape, bad sex scenes and having absolutely nothing explained, then I would suggest that you don't pick up this book.

Let's all be honest with ourselves. Murakami never writes anything remotely tame, so always expect mind-fuckery from his books. Even Norwegian Wood which is his most "normal" story with a chronological story line, has its "what in the ever living fuck did I just read?" moments. So if I had a mere 10 seconds to describe this book, I'd say it's Oedipus meets Flowers for Algernon with plenty of unsolved questions by the end. Sound weird? It really is.light spoilers aheadWe follow 15-year-old Kafta Tamura whose father has prophesied a dark nightmare where he will kill his father and sleep with his mother and sister. So he runs away from home and eventually ends up working at a library far from home. His father is murdered, but he has an alibi, but he still wakes up with blood on his shirt after blacking out. He also meets Miss Saeki, the woman who runs the library. He has a strong suspicion that she is his mother but also sees her 15 year old ghost in his room at night, which begs the question - do living people have ghosts? Obviously he develops a bit of an Oedipus complex with Miss Saeki. Things get weird from there but I'll let you explore it yourself.Our other main character is Mr Nakata, a man who became mentally disabled after falling unconscious along with other children in his class during WWII. He was the only one who did not wake up, and when he did, he knew nothing of the world, his family or himself. But he get a bonus - he can talk to cats. And he tracks down cats for a living. more light spoilersThere's a lot of philosophy in this book which is focused on more than the actual story. The conversations between characters is what really made me slurp up this book. The writing is beautifully translated and I wish I knew Japanese just to experience Murakami in all his glory. some men talk with stones, and some sleep with other menWhat I really wasn't expected was Oshima, a wonderfully represented gay trans man who works at Ms Saeki's library. Him being trans is stated once or twice, its not the focus of its character but you can see how it has shaped him. He's the most articulate and thoughtful of all the characters and he's the kind of diversity we need. I was pleasantly surprised since I don't see trans characters very often in Japanese media of any kind. If we reverse the outer shell and the essence - in other words, consider the outer shell the essence and the essence only the shell - our lives might be a whole lot easier to understandAny who, you expect Mr Nakata and Kafta to meet, but it goes it a totally different direction I didn't expect. The ending was open-ended, which I'm not a fan of but it is about the journey of a 15 year old so it makes sense that he has his whole life paved in front of him.I'd recommend this to fans of his other work, but not as a starting point for someone who wants to start reading his work. It's not very newbie friendly.And you really will have to make it through that violent, metaphysical, symbolic storm. No matter how metaphysical or symbolic it might be, make no mistake about it: it will cut through flesh like a thousand razor blades. People will bleed there, and you will bleed too. Hot, red blood. You'll catch that blood in your hands, your own blood and the blood of others. And once the storm is over you won't remember how you made it through, how you managed to survive. You won't even be sure, in fact, whether the storm is really over. But one thing is certain. When you come out of the storm you won't be the same person who walked in. That's what the storm's all about.

"Y es que hay obras que poseen cierto tipo de imperfección que cautiva el corazón de las personas justamente por eso, por ser imperfectas…"
 5★¡Alucinante! Haruki Murakami nos ha regalado un libro único, sorprendente y muy bizarro. Kafka en la orilla no sigue ninguna regla conocida, es una historia donde la lógica no tiene mucha cavidad y eso, exactamente, me gustó muchísimo. Al principio, no sabía qué estaba leyendo, no tenía ni idea de dónde me estaba metiendo. Pero cada capítulo resultó ser una enorme y maravillosa sorpresa.
"Sólo los cobardes apartan la vista de la realidad."
Este libro nos cuenta la historia de Kafka Tamura, un joven que, al cumplir quince años, abandona su casa y termina viviendo en una peculiar biblioteca al sur del país; y, Satoru Nakata, un amable anciano con dificultades para comunicarse (excepto con los gatos) que debe emprender una extraña y atípica misión… Ambos protagonistas me conquistaron a su manera, Tamura con su sensibilidad y dramatismo (aunque, a veces, no lo soportaba), y Nakata con su forma de expresarse, dulce y conmovedora. Amé demasiado la sinceridad e inocencia que derramaba Nakata.Los demás personajes tampoco se quedan atrás, sobre todo Hoshino y Ôshima, esos dos se robaron el show en varias ocasiones. Definitivamente, Ôshima se ha convertido en uno de mis personajes literarios favoritos de todos los tiempos. Cabe decir que esta novela tiene el toque de fantasía perfecto, nos deja muchos enigmas y nos ofrece una perspectiva única acerca de la vida y la muerte.
"Las tinieblas del mundo exterior han desaparecido, pero las tinieblas de nuestra alma continúan inalteradas."
Algo que también me ha gustado mucho es el estilo narrativo del autor, surrealista y a la vez tan natural, sin ningún tabú. Haruki Murakami utiliza muchas referencias musicales y literarias, las cuales nos permiten conocer y conectar mejor con los personajes. A mí, particularmente, me encantaron. Cada vez que mencionaba una canción que no conocía, la buscaba y la escuchaba; siento que, de alguna extraña manera, una entabla simpatía con el autor.Además de mitología y música, a través de los libros de  Murakami también podemos apreciar más acerca de la simbólica e interesante cultura Japonesa. A muchos les gustará este libro, a otros no tanto. Yo lo amé y podría hablar sin parar de él. En definitiva, es una historia que no olvidaré, entra a mis favoritos. Si les gusta la literatura Japonesa o ya han leído al autor, les recomiendo esta impresionante obra.
"Eres joven, eres fuerte. Tienes flexibilidad. Lograrás que cicatricen tus heridas, lograrás levantar la cabeza y seguir adelante."

كافكا على الشاطىء أو رقصة أستربتيز.بعد مائتي صفحة من الرواية أي قبل منتصفها بقليل (قرأت نسختها الإنجليزية) شعرت بأنني أشاهد رقصة أستربتيز، التماثلات بين الرواية ورقصة الأستربتيز عديدة وكانت تزداد قوة كلما تقدمت فيها.لماذا استمر في قراءة رواية بها كل هذا القدر من الملل والتكرار والكلام الفارغ والإحساس الطفولي نحو الأشياء، لأنني أريد أن أصل للنهاية، لا أعرف ما الذي سيحدث رغم أنني أتوقعه إلى حد ما. كحال مشاهد الأستربتيز يظل يتحمل الموسيقى المزعجة وسخافات الحضور ونظرة البلاهة على وجه الراقصة من أجل القطعة الاخيرة التي سترميها لتكشف ما ينتظره الجميع بعد خمسمائة صفحة. ما الداعي لأن يحدثنا "هوشينو" عن علاقاته النسائية و"ناكاتا" ميت في الحجرة المجاورة والحجر أمامه في انتظار أن يغلقه، ويا ليته أكمل حكايته، كحال راقصة الأستربتيز، لماذا تبذل جهد في خلع قفازيها والجميع في غنى عن رؤية يديها ولماذا ترميه في النهاية بكل هذا الاستهتار. كيف تعجب الرواية كل هؤلاء القراء، إنها الحالة الطفولية، ليس من الناحية العمرية ولكن من الناحية النفسية، فكما أن الجنس في مخيلة الطفل يتمركز حول الأعضاء الحميمية للمرأة وفقط فالبعض يظن أن الرواية هي حكاية وبعض ألغاز ومناقشات فلسفية وفنية سطحية ولغة في منتهى البساطة ال��ي وإن دلت على شيء تدل على سخافة الكاتب. بالله عليكم كم مرة وصف موراكامي ملابس شخصياته وطعام إفطارهم وتمارين كافكا الرياضية، لماذا؟، ما هذه القدرة على الحشو والإبداع في خلق الملل. نأتي للنهاية التي تؤشر بوضوخ لتفاهة الكاتب وإفتقاده لمبادىء الحكي، ما معنى كل ما حدث؟ سيقول البعض أن جمال الرواية في غموضها وهو أمر مردود عليه لأنه يكون مقبولا عندما يكون الكاتب - على الأقل - يعلم معنى ما كتبه وهو أمر أجزم بعدم تحققه في حالة موراكامي الذي اكتشف أن الرواية كبرت وأن خيوطها تاهت منه ففبرك نهاية سخيفة.في النهاية يمكن القول بان الفرق بين ميشيما وكاواباتا وإندو وغيرهم من روائيي اليابان الكبار وبين موراكامي هو الفرق بين رقص الباليه ورقص الأستربتيز.

"Sometimes fate is like a small sandstorm that keeps changing direction.”I wish fate has taken a direction towards Murakami soon in my life. Although, better late than never. Haruki Murakami is a name that has earned its place in the literature world with full dignity. I have read many authors to date ( though still feels like I just started) but Murakami has such a vivid imagination that while reading him, you will find your imagination floating into a whole unforeseen universe, something that you know cannot exist but it feels like it does. A man name Nakata can talk to cats and knows there exist an entrance stone that opens up to a parallel universe. Then there is a boy named Kafka ( toughest fifteen-year-old) who runs away from his home just to avoid the prophecy declared by his father but ends up being following it. Also, keep in mind that- Kafka talks to crow and his father kills cats to steal their souls for making a flute that carries harmonious music.So now you can imagine how creative Murakami’s stories can be. I loved each character and felt an instant connection with them. Not for once did I feel that the story is becoming dull or slow. It was a story that challenges your vision and makes you visualize things that might not have come to your imagination by itself ever. Also, the lessons that you can learn are worth reckoning."From my own experience, when someone is trying very hard to get something, they don't. And when they're running away from something as hard as they can, it usually catches up with them, I'm generalising, of course."I will surely recommend this to everyone who has an equally powerful imagination as that of Murakami. Besides, I am also very open to anyone’s recommendation of any other masterpiece by Haruki Murakami.

My second Murakami… I didn’t hate it but was not impressed either: more perfectly slim girls, questionable sex scenes, primal fantasies and fabricated narratives, all marked by a fetishistic vibe. These seem to be fixed, integral parts of his protagonists’ psycho-sexual journeys—essentially heterosexual, in this case, since Oshima seems to be… lacking, a companion bound to be left behind in Kafka’s maturity.Although a little on the nose, the conversations with Oshima were by far the most interesting aspect of the novel. The foreshadowing and halfshadowing of Nakata’s storyline began to bore me halfway through and kept waiting for it to intersect with that of Kafka. I was hoping to get a more thought-provoking take on childhood trauma and fatalism in fiction rather than the over-used oedipal complex and chance discoveries that conveniently, clumsily move the plot forward.

Kafka on the Shore is my second Murakami book. While I didn't like it as much as the first one I read, I still enjoyed it. How to describe it? Bizarre, magical, disturbing, thought-provoking, most definitely not predictable, and like nothing else I've ever read. Nakata - the simpleton who talks to cats was my favorite character. I loved his chapters more than Kafka's. I don’t know if I will ever fully grasp the meaning of his books, but I will keep trying. 3.5 stars rounded up.TW for any animal lovers - just skip the Johnnie Walker chapter. I skipped it and had no trouble following along afterwards.

H. Murakami personifies metaphors and lets his characters enact the literal Oedipus play, and then calls it a metaphor too while throwing in Hegelian wholeness and some dream Inceptions in a surreal eerie world with talking cats and mackerel rains, all of which leading to an unresolved yet satisfying tale. I seriously appreciate, but can't think very high of it, i.e., 3.5 in goodreads terminology.

رواية تحمل طابع وجودي، ذات أحداث جنونية فيها يستطيع احدهم التكلم مع القطط والسماء تمطر سمك. الكاتب يترك الغازاً مفتوحة للقارئ ليفسرها على طريقته. إذاً هي لا تثير الأشخاص الذين لا يفضلون القصص المفتوحة النهاية. أما الكاتب فلديه أسلوب مميز وطريقة جميلة تضيف نوع من التشويق والتحفيز في نفس القارئ. تتحدث الرواية عن قصتين مختلفتين تتقاطعان في النهاية. الرواية تضوي بطريقة غير واضحة عن تأثير الصدمات النفسية في نفس الإنسان. الكاتب يستعرض ثقافته الأدبية والفنية ولكن بطريقة غير مملة

Първа и в никакъв случай последна среща с Мураками. Толкова ми хареса, че вече си поръчах още 3 негови книги. Абстрактен, фантасмагоричен, ирационален, емоционален - настани се в читателското ми сърце. Едни от най-любимите ми моменти са разговорите между Кафка и Ошима и Наката и Хошино. Заобичах всички странни герои и всичко, което им се случи по пътя.

روعة ما بعدها روعة، هذا الموراكامي يجعلك تعيش قصته، تتفاعل مع أحداثها، واقعية كانت أم خيالية ...قصتان متوازيتان لكنهما متقاطعتان ( نطلب المعذرة من الرياضيين ) لكل من كافكا، المراهق ذو الخمسة عشر سنة الفار من أبيه، وناكاتا العجوز الذي لا يعرف حتى القراءة لكنه يحظى بأحداث رائعة وشيقة، قال الكاتب هاروكي إن ناكاتا هو شخصيته المفضلة، وأنا كذلك يا فذ.

بداية جميلة ، مشدود بها والتهم الصفحات التهاما

Mr Murakami, I'm delighted that I found my way back to your writing. I hadn't intended a re-read, and indeed I had forgotten that I had read this novel, (it’s not your writing, but my failing memory!) but as soon as I started reading I remembered, and I simply could not put the book down.Where does one start reviewing a novel that offers so much? It brims with Greek mythology, Japanese and Western literature, Western music, and it explores several ideas.The chapters of the novel alternate (more or less) between the parallel stories of fifteen year old runaway Kafka (a name he chooses for himself) Tamura, and of an old man, Nakata. Each one has a quest. Each one acquires a helper. Kafka receives help and advice from the librarian Oshima who works at a magnificent private library. Nakata accepts a lift from Hoshino,, a commercial truck driver, who continues to assist Nakata. In addition, Kafka creates for himself an alter ego called Crow, whom he consults when confronted with a problem or a question. In fact, we learn that Kafka means crow in Czech. Crow constantly affirms: ”“Remember, you’re supposed to be the toughest 15-year-old on the planet.”” And so begin the connections, because besides the obvious connection to Franz Kafka the author, there is also a connection to a painting and a song titled Kafka on the Shore, as well as many other connections. Nakata, on the other hand, had an unusual experience as a child which has left him, in his own words, “dumb” and “empty”. However, he has the remarkable ability of being able to talk to cats, as well as causing various incongruous items to rain from the sky. He even talks to a stone…Rather than discussing the plot, I’ll focus on a few random aspects that delighted me - there are far too many to discuss here.Kafka & OshimaAt the library mentioned above, Kafka and Oshima discuss the books that Kafka spends his days reading. Kafka, having finished reading The Arabian Nights, tackles the complete works of Natsume Soseki. This leads to a discussion of The Miner vs Sanshiro, and on a later occasion they talk about Schubert’s Sonata in D Major which is then compared to the books just mentioned. And Kafka listens over and over to the song Kafka on the Shore…Nakata & HoshinoLater, whilst Nakata is sleeping, Hoshino drinks coffee in a coffee shop where the owner plays a CD of Beethoven’s Archduke Trio. “Hoshino closed his eyes, breathing in quietly, and listened to the intertwining of strings and piano. He’d hardly ever listened to classical music before, but it was soothing and put him in an introspective mood.” Hoshino knows nothing about classical music, but he starts asking questions, and before long the owner tells him about the current performance (Rubinstein, Heifetz and Feuermann) as well as other famous interpretations such as the Oistrach Trio’s version. The proprietor also explains how it came about that the piece was written, and Hoshino becomes so entranced that eventually he even reads a biography of Beethoven. “And now look at me, he thought, I’m into Beethoven – can you believe it? A pretty amazing development.” Hoshino again visits the coffee shop, and on this occasion ”Something with stringed instruments was playing on the stereo. “Haydn’s first cello concerto. Pierre Fournier’s playing the solo,” the owner explained as he brought over his coffee.” So naturally a discussion of composer Haydn and performer Fournier follows. And Mr Murakami doesn’t confine himself to classical music; there are bits about jazz, the Beatles, etc. Not surprisingly, one of the ideas probed in the novel is the transformative power of music. Kafka and Oshima’s conversation about Schubert’s Sonata in D Major leads to a discussion of the perfection of imperfection. Elsewhere the following ideas (amongst many others) are explored:what is boring and what isn’tappreciation and acceptance of those who are different to usintolerance and people without imaginationwhat would induce a kind, peace loving person to kill another?does resposibility begin with the imagination?can nothingness increase?fate - does man choose fate, or does fate choose man?the origin and nature of labyrinthsetc.Kafka’s discovery of the forest also enchanted me. There is mystery and inherent danger, but there is the wonder of stars and silence or birdsong. The forest also serves as a metaphor for what Kafka needs to experience in order to mature and reach the next stage of his life.And there I thought that I’m the only one who talks to cats - not so! Only in this novel the cats talk back, albeit only to a very select audience. But then cats are very discriminating by nature. Discover for yourself some delightful cat conversations. So yes, I haven’t even scratched the surface of what is in this novel, but the above is a sampler of tidbits that appealed to me. #####Quotes: (not in chronological order)“The library was like a second home. Or maybe more like a real home than the place I lived in.”“When I open them, most of the books have the smell of an earlier time leaking out from between their pages – a special odour of the knowledge and emotions that for ages have been calmly resting between the covers.”“Compared to those faceless hordes of people rushing through the train station, these crazy, preposterous stories of a thousand years ago are, at least to me, much more real. How that’s possible, I don’t know. It’s pretty weird.”“I like to linger over each sentence, enjoying the style. If I don’t enjoy the writing, I stop.”“‘A life without once reading Hamlet is like a life spent in a coal mine.’”“But still, no matter how much time passes, no matter what takes place in the interim, there are some things we can never assign to oblivion, memories we can never rub away. They remain with us for ever, like a touchstone.”““Memories warm you up from the inside. But they also tear you apart.””“I trudge along. I’m walking by the shores of consciousness. Waves of consciousness roll in, roll out, leave some writing, and just as quickly new waves roll in and erase it. I try to quickly read what’s written there, between one wave and the next, but it’s hard. Before I can read it the next wave’s washed it away. All that’s left are puzzling fragments.”“All these millions of stars looking down on me, and I’ve never given them more than a passing thought before. Not only the stars – how many other things haven’t I noticed in the world, things I know nothing about? I suddenly feel helpless, completely powerless.”“My head was completely empty, like a bathtub after you pull the plug.”“Silence, I discover, is something you can actually hear.”“The stone was – not unexpectedly – speechless.”“The stone maintained its stony silence.”““Do you think music has the power to change people? As though you listen to a piece and go through some major change inside?” Oshima nodded. “Sure, that can happen. We have an experience –l ike a chemical reaction – that transforms something inside us. When we examine ourselves later on, we discover that all the standards we’ve lived by have shot up another notch and the world’s opened up in unexpected ways. Yes, I’ve had that experience. Not often, but it has happened. It’s like falling in love.””“”… A dense, artistic imperfection stimulates your consciousness, keeps you alert. If I listen to some utterly perfect performance of an utterly perfect piece while I’m driving, I might want to close my eyes and die right then and there. But listening to the D major, I can feel the limits of what humans are capable of – that a certain type of perfection can only be realised through a limitless accumulation of the imperfect. And personally, I find that encouraging. Do you see what I’m getting at?””“People soon get tired of things that aren’t boring, but not of what is boring. What’s that all about. For me, I might have the leisure to be bored, but not to grow tired of something. Most people can’t distinguish between the two.”“Having an object that symbolises freedom might make a person happier than actually getting the freedom it represents.”“All that was visible was the rear of the building next door. A shabby, miserable sort of building. The kind where shabby people spent one shabby day after another doing their shabby work. The kind of fallen-from-grace sort of building you find in any city, the kind which Charles Dickens could spend ten pages describing.”“Nakata had met many cats up till this point, but never before one who listened to opera and knew models of cars.”“Nakata stored this information away in his head, carefully folding it all away in a front drawer so he wouldn’t forget it.”““Listen, every object’s in flux. The earth, time, concepts, love, life, faith, justice, evil – they’re all fluid and in transition. They don’t stay in one form or in one place for ever. The whole universe is like some big FedEx box.””#####Perfect for Murakami addicts like myself!

عندما هَممت بكتابة قصة الرواية العامة توقفت للحظة ثم ابتسمت ابتسامة خافتة وقلت لنفسي: "موراكامي الخبيث!"، لماذا؟ لأنني وجدت نفسي في نفس الموقف الذي وقع أكثر من مرة في الرواية عندما تريد أحد الشخصيات (مثل هوشينو سائق الشاحنة الذي يرافق ناكاتا العجوز) أن تروي الأحداث الغربية والسيريالية التي وقعت له، تتردد للحظة، ثم تقتنع بأن ماحدث لايمكن وصفه للناس مالم يعايشوه بأنفسهم. وهنا المفارقة، رواية موراكامي هذه بشكل خاص يصعب التحدث عنها، وأي حديث سيبدو سخيفاً للسامع، هذه القصة المجنونة التي شعرت وأنا أقرأها بأن حتى الكاتب نفسه لايعرف أين ستتجه حكايته، لازلت حتى اليوم لا أعرف كيف ألّف موراكامي روايته هذه؛ لذا سأتحدث عن الرواية من زاوية أخرى، عن بنية الرواية النظرية -إن جاز التعبير- . موراكامي يُعتبر أحد أبرز رموز رواية ما بعد الحداثة (ذًكرت لفظة ما بعد الحداثة في الرواية بشكل عَرضي مرة واحدة على الأقل) ويٌصعب حقيقة الحديث عن ما بعد الحداثة في سطور قليلة، لكن يمكن أن أذكر مميزاتها بشكل مخل، وعن ماذا يخطر على بال الشخص عندما تذكر لفظة "مابعد الحداثة"، في الغالب ما ترتبط ما بعد الحداثة بتحييد -إذا اخترنا كلمة لطيفة لـ"نفي"- الحقيقة المٌطلقة، والتأكييد على الحقيقة الذاتية عوضاً عنها، أي "الذات" عوضاً عن "الموضوع" وتٌعتبر "كافكا على الشاطئ" -الأغنية التي ألفتها الآنسة ساييكي وعنوان الرواية نفسها والتي يمكن سماعها من هنا - مثالاً جيداً على ذلك : تجلس على حافة العالموأنا في بحيرة بركانية مبددةكلمات بلاحروفتقف في ظلال الباب.نور القمر يشعّ على سحلية نائمة والسماء تمطر سمكاً صغيراًوخارج النافذة جنوديسرقون أنفسهم لكي يموتوا كافكا جالس على كرسي الشاطئءيفكر في البندول الذي يحرّك العالميبدو أنهعندما ينغلق قلبك،يصبح طائر الفينيق الجامدسكيناً يقطع أحلامكأصابع البنت الغارقةتبحث في حجر المدخل، والمزيد.ترفع طرف ثوبها اللازوردي،عيناها تحدقانفي كافكا على الشاطئمن الوهلة الأولى تبدو هذه الكلمات هلوسات مخرّف تسعيني حاول أن يكتب الشعر، لكن كلّما تقدمنا في الرواية نعرف أكثر بان هذه الكلمات متعلقة (وذاتية) بشكل كبير بحياة الآنسة ساييكي -مؤلفة الأغنية- تارةً تنفتح الكلمات وتعطينا بعض المعاني، وتارة تنغلق ونتمتع بموسيقها الجميلة فحسب، وربما هي مجرد "كلمات بلا حروف" . الأدب المابعد حداثي يُسأل بعض مسلمات الأدب الحداثي ( بداية - نص - نهاية مغلقة - ومغزى قصة واضح) فلايعتبر بأن هناك "قواعد" أو "نماذج" يجب السير عليها، وفهم الحكاية يرجع للقارئ نفسه؛ فهي حكاية تبدو وكأنّ لاحدود لتأويلها (ومن علائمها: النهاية المفتوحة - الأحداث غير المُفسرة). أيضاً كثير ما ترتبط ما بعد الحداثة بنقد الإرث الحداثي التنويري، وتعتبر محرقة اليهود نموذجاً لهذا النقد، من حيثية فكرة "التنظيم" "والقواعد" التي سار عليها الفكر الحداثي، وكيف أن المحرقة كانت "مُنظمة"، عندما نعرف هذا، يمكننا فهم لماذا موراكامي جعل كافكا يقرأ كتاباً عن أيخمان (مسؤول من مسؤولي المحرقة) بالذات من بين جميع الكتب، في الواقع، الكثير من الأمور التي تظهر وكأنها هامشية في الرواية مرتبطة بوجه من الوجه بهذه البنية النظرية المابعد حداثية ( جنس أوشيما غير المحدد - بعض اقتباسات الكتب - معزوفات بيتهوفن وأن لكل شخص فهمه الخاص لها مثلما حدث مع هوشينو - مطابقة الداخلي (الذات) للخارجي (الموضوع/العالم) مثل ماحدث لكافكا في الغابة -إلخ) كل هذه الأمور تفصح عن هذه البنية التي دفعها موراكامي لأقصى حدودها.لا أزعم بأنني قمت بشرح هذه البنية النظرية بشكل واف، لكن أتمنى أن يصل ما أردت قوله.بطبيعة الحال طريقة التأليف هذه ستواجه بعض المعارضات ( مثل هذه الآنسة الغاضبة ) لكن في المقا��ل ستقابل ببعض القراءات الثرية والجميلة ( كقراءة محمد عمر الذكية والمُثرية ) . في النهاية، أظنني أمام تحفة كلاسيكية معاصرة

মুরাকামির লেখালেখি একটু ভিন্নমাত্রার। পুরো উপন্যাস জুড়ে যেসব ঘটনা ঘটেছে, সেগুলোর কোনো যৌক্তিক ভিত্তি নেই। আপনি লজিক্যালি এইসব জিনিস যাচাই করতে গেলে বিফল হবেন। চরিত্রগুলোও রহস্যময়, কিন্তু সেইসব রহস্যের জট ছুটানো একজনের পক্ষে বাস্তবজ্ঞান দিয়ে সম্ভব নয়। উপন্যাসটি পড়ার সময় মোটেই ধারণা করা সম্ভব নয় পরের লাইনে কি হতে চলেছে, কারণ এই উপন্যাস নির্দিষ্ট কোনো প্যাটার্ন মেনে সামনে এগোয় নি। অনেকটা স্বপ্নের সাথে তুলোনা করা যেতে পারে, স্বপ্নে যেভাবে একের পর এক অযৌক্তিক ঘটনা ঘটতে থাকে, এই উপন্যাসেও জিনিসটা অনেকটা সেরকম৷ অনেক সময় আকাশ থেকে জোঁকের বৃষ্টি হয়, তো অনেক সময় বিড়াল হয়ে উঠে মানুষের থেকেও বুদ্ধিমান জীব, তো আবার চরিত্রগুলোর পক্ষেই নিজেদের স্বপ্ন আর বাস্তবতা আলাদা করা সম্ভব হয়ে উঠে না। উপন্যাসটির সবচে' গুরুত্বপূর্ণ জিনিসই হচ্ছে এই স্বপ্ন আর বাস্তবতার সহাবস্থান। স্বপ্ন আর বাস্তবতা মিলেমিশে একটা ঘোলাটে দ্রবণ তৈরি করে, এই ঘোলাটে জিনিসটিই প্রকৃত মেটাফর। মেটাফর? হ্যা, উপন্যাসটি খুব বেশি রূপকীয়। গল্পের প্রধান চরিত্র তামুরা কাফকা নিজেও আশেপাশে কর্মকান্ডে মেটাফর খোঁজতে যেমন ব্যস্ত, পাঠককেও ঠিক তেমনই তাতে ব্যস্ত থাকতে হয়। তবে, প্রতিটি জিনিসকে আলাদা আলাদা মেটাফর হিসেবে নিলে উপন্যাসটি কি আমাদের সামনে অর্থবহ হয়ে উঠে? এই প্রশ্নটিও পুরো উপন্যাসের মতো ঘোলাটে। মেটাফরগুলো উপন্যাসকে অর্থবহ করে না বলেই আমার মনে হয়, মুরাকামি এই উপন্যাসে মূলত কিছু টুকরো জুড়ো লাগিয়েছেন। লিখতে গিয়ে নিজের ইচ্ছেমতো একটা স্বপ্ন তৈরি করেছেন, শেষে গিয়ে এই উপন্যাস কোনো অর্থ ফুটিয়ে তুলবে কি না, তা নিয়ে তাঁর মাথাব্যথা ছিল বলে মনে হয় না। মূলত প্রত্যেক পাঠকেরই, নিজের জীবন এবং চিন্তাভাবনা থেকেই এইসব রূপকের নিজস্ব নিজস্ব অর্থ খোঁজে নেয়া সম্ভব। উপন্যাসের একটি পার্শ্বচরিত্র, ওশিমা এর মুখ থেকেই মুরাকামি ব্যখ্যা করেছেন যে আমাদের জগতের গোলকধাঁধা আমাদের ভিতর থেকেই সৃষ্ট। আমাদের পেটের নাড়ি ভুড়িই বিশ্বের সবচে' বড় গোলকধাঁধার সমতুল্য। সুতরাং, এই উপন্যাসের রূপকগুলোর মানে মুরাকামি নির্দিষ্ট করে দেন নি। প্রত্যেক পাঠক নিজের ভিতরের প্যাঁচ অনুযায়ী আলাদা আলাদাভাবে ইন্টারপ্রেট করবে, এবং এটাই স্বাভাবিক। তামুরা কাফকার নিজের মায়ের কবজি থেকে ঝরে পরা রক্তপানের ঘটনার সম্পূর্ণ আলাদা একটা অর্থ খোঁজে পেয়েছিলাম অন্য একজন পাঠকের সাথে কথা বলতে গিয়ে। আমার দৃষ্টিভঙ্গির সাথে ঐ পাঠকের দৃষ্টিভঙ্গি মিলে নি...আর এটা এই উপন্যাসের আরেকটি সুন্দর দিক। এতো ঘোলাটে একটি উপন্যাস, স্টোরি লাইন নিয়ে ভাবতে গেলে প্রচন্ডরকম বিরক্তিকরই মনে হয়। কিন্তু এরপরেও এই উপন্যাস মাত্র তিন বসায় শেষ করেছি(বাংলা অনুবাদ ��টশো পৃষ্ঠার)। এখানে পুরো কৃতিত্ব মুরাকামির অনবদ্য স্টোরি টেলিং এর। এতো ডার্ক একটা টপিক নিয়ে লেখা বই, কিন্তু বিরক্তি আসা দূরে থাক। একবার শুরু করলে হাত থেকে রাখা যায় না। দুর্দান্ত!আমি মূলত অভিজিৎ মুখার্জি- এর অনুবাদে উপন্যাসটি পড়েছি। প্রথমদিকে একটু কষ্ট হচ্ছিল, তবে সে দায় অনুবাদকের নয়। মুরাকামির লেখার ধরণটা বুঝে ফেলার সাথেই সাথেই আর আটকাতে হয় নি। আটশো পৃষ্ঠা ধরে এরকম একই তালে অনুবাদ করে যাওয়া নিশ্চয়ই কঠিন কাজ। অনুবাদকক��� এজন্য সাধুবাদ দিতে হয়। একদম তোফা অনুবাদ, তবে ইংরেজী শব্দ আরেকটু কম ব্যবহার করলে হয়তো আরও ভালো হতো। সমুদ্রতটে কাফকা, মানবমনের একদম গহিনে নিয়ে পাঠককে অন্ধকারে ডুবিয়ে মারে এই উপন্যাস।

Once upon a time lived in Theben a young man called Oedipus.As most young men at that time – and nowadays too – he had a father and a mother. When he was just a baby it was predicted that he was destined to one day kill his father and marry his mother. Even in ancient Greece such behavior was frowned upon – but on the other hand you don´t just kill a son of royal blood to prevent disaster.As fate would it, because fate is a very important ingredient in folklore, the boy lived and went on to fulfill the prophecy.Murakami builds a very long and complicated tale with basis in the tale of Oedipus Rex.There are some other elements as well; coming-of-age, sexual identity, road tripping, finding piece of mind, classical music, coming to terms with your mortality etc. etc. and a lot of sphinxes in the forms of cats and a weight-changing stone.Johnny Walker and Colonel Sanders plays important roles as well, though not in a way you would have anticipated Ooooh my freaking Goodness. There is too much of everything crammed into the 615 pages of my edition.Not that the storyline doesn´t hold or can´t be followed without going back and forth and nothing Murakami produces is not technically well written, but …I just fail to see the purpose. Even if we agree that this is a case of “The Journey, not the Destination” and I do appreciate the journey in the company of the characters it is a road to nowhere.

It’s my third time of reading this novel and again I cried at the end. I, too, have read about how people describe it as fantastical, metaphysical, gripping, but incomprehensible and inconclusive. Yes, it’s a book in which humans talk with cats, fish and leeches fall from the sky, and soldiers missing in action from the time of World War II reappear alive and well. I recognize that the Greek myths of Oedipus and even Orpheus are key players and that there is a whole discussion of metaphor within its pages. Like when Kafka suggests, “There’re a lot of odd things going on—but I feel like I’m slowly getting closer to the truth.” And Miss Saeki asks, “Actually getting closer to a metaphorical truth? Or metaphorically getting closer to an actual truth?Every page is a mysterious path to go down, but I believe it should be read as a young boy leaving home and fighting with his own demons. Follow that path, and you will see everything else as potentially shedding light on that battle. You, too, might even cry at its conclusion
