رواية موراكامي الأجمل والأكثر إثارةً للجدل. ولكن.. من قال إن الأدب عليه أن يقدم إجابات؟؟!!.. عليه أن يطرح الأسئلة ويثير التساؤلات ويحرك الفضول .. وموراكامي يفعل ذلك بأفضل طريقة ممكنة.

The feeling I have after the last page was turned over is akin to what I would have felt after taking a plunge into a rather cold and deceptively deep pool of water. The surface appears calm and the bottom of the lake appears within sight before you take the leap but this changes once you are in the water. There are areas which have pristine and divinely rich water, areas where the muck oozes into the pool and also garbage floating on the surface at other places. Murakami is at my first observation, a shaft of light that lights up the nooks and crannies in the attic of the human mind.A quest, that is is what the story is all about. There are two people going about this quest and in two glaringly different ways but in the end it all ties together. On the one side of the path we see Kafka Tomura, a 15 year old runaway with an Oedipus complex and a completely befuddled state of mind. The other side of the quest is Mr. Nakata, a polite-to-a-fault sexagenarian who can converse with cats and finds lost cats for aggrieved pet owners !Kafka goes through a process of growing up which while being painful, finally puts him at the threshold of a world better than the one he tried to run away from. Mr.Nakata while appearing to be a simpleton has more to him than meets the eye. I must say that the traits this character embodies are the ones that can evoke sympathy in many a reader. There are areas where in the naivete of the character worked on me as well. Other than the principal characters, my interest was perked by the character of Oshima who unlike many people in the real world knows the right thing to say at the right time. Plus, he talks philosophy while driving a Mazda Miata at top speed on a mountain road with Schubert's sonata as a backdrop. Interesting sort of chap !There are two locales that I fell in love with in the book. One is the Komura memorial library. Deep,spacious, filled with light and choke full of books this would have been a wonderful place to spend days lost in the grasp of books. The second and the more seductive of the two is the mountain cottage of Kochi where Kafka spends a few days. Imagine a log cabin hidden deep in the mountains where you can cook and eat your meals. All around you is the forest and the mountains. There is no electricity and no mobile phone to disturb your reverie. It has shelves crammed with books. Well,now I have a fair idea of how I should spend my post retirement days !Well so much for the good things. There are parts in the book that make no sense or adds no value to the path which we walk. There is a particularly graphic chapter which to me was pretty much an avoidable one. Not that violence affects me but it feels out of place in a book like this. There are a lot of loose threads that dangle and shift in the breezes even after I finished the book which is not a very satisfying thing. There is a lot of power in Murakami's writing. As you go on reading, you can feel the trapdoors in your mind open to let in the light for maybe the first time & at the same time many a passage will make you feel the windows of your mind bolt shut to keep the wind out. The book is like a song that does not touch you at first but starts growing on you each time you revisit it.

رواية " كافكا علي الشاطيء " كُتبت باليابانية كما ترون!و باليابانية : 海辺のカフカ و تُرجمت للعربية .. من أجلي :D ولا استطيع كتابة مراجعة عنها ولا بالعربية ولا باليابانية :3لكن لا بُد منه... كـ رواية باليابانية ؛ أنا لم اقرأ مثلها من قبل ولم اقرأ ياباني من الأساس. ما اكتشفته هنا: هو أن أسلوب الكاتب، تفكيره، قلمه.. جميعهم يتلونوا على حسب البلدالّذي نشأ و ترعرع فيه الكاتب.. و كان ذلك واضحٌا هنا -وضوح الشمس- خاصةً في تلك الرواية ! كاتب يكتب بِروحه من الطبيعي أن يخرج من بين يديه رواية بهذه الروعة.عندما تأخذ قرار قراءة رواية/كتاب مترجـم تكون متخوفًا ومنتظرًا أن تجد مهزلة. رواية مفككة ومعاني لا يجمعها أي صلة و حروف مبعثرةبإختصار تفقد الرواية جمالها.  وهذا كله دارّ في رأسي عندما وجدتها يابانية(حالها هيتشقلب!)لكنها و لله الحمد جاءت عكس كلّ توقعاتيشعرت و كأنها كُتبت بلغتها الأصلية من شدة سلاستها !تدور الأحداث هكذا... فتي يدعي (كافكا) اشتهر بهذا الاسم في الرواية ولكنّه ليس إسمه الحقيقي،يختار أن يهرب من النبوءة الأوديبية لأبيه، و يسير في طريق أخر ويعتمد على نفسه فيهبعد أيام يقابل فيها شخصيات كُثُر منهم: أوشيما - سايبكيفيتبدل حال كافكا ، والأحداث أيضاً. يعرف ذلك من عاش مع الرواية وتجسد في احد شخصياتها.ويقابل أيضاً العجوز ناكاتا الّذي يصف نفسه بإستمرار بأن ذكائه محدود.الطفل الوحيد الّذي غاب عن وعيه عددًا من الشهور و ربما السنوات بعد أحداث الحرب العالمية الثانية باليابان. وعندما استعاد وعيه كان قد فقد الذاكرة، وأصبح أقل ذكاءً، وأميًا لا يعرف القراءة والكتابة. هذا الطفل هو الذي سيصبح في الرواية فيما بعد العجوز ناكاتا -عجوز ببراءة طفل-،كان يستطيع التحدث مع القطط ويفهم لغتهم وإشاراتهم.. فأصبح يساعد الناس على إيجاد قططهم المفقودة.وما توصلت إليه في النهاية هو إن ناكاتا يكمل كافكا بشكلٍ ما! و تتوالى الأحداث ويبدأ ناكاتا في البحث عن حجرٍ ما ليفتحه ويفك طلاسم وأسرار وألغاز مدهشة.. مثلًا :-بإمكانه أن يجعل السما تمطر سمكًا !أو يتنبأ بالطقس !.و سيقابل الأخير هوشينو فَـ يرتبط مصيره بناكاتا إلي أن يموت ناكاتا. الرواية تسبح في عالمٍ مدهش وساحر فعلًا.رغم أنها لا تخلو من الأحداث المبهمة. أحداث كثيرة لم أفهم لماذا حدثت؟ وأين؟ وكيف تخدم الأحداث؟!و النهاية، وجدتها مرضية جدًا لخيالي، خطفتني من الواقع بفلسفتها الحلوةرغم أن أسلوب الكاتب لا يخلو من المجازات إلا أنها لا تخلو من البساطة.بس النهاية مُرضية إلي حدٍ ما .. و كمُجمل الرواية خاطفة و فلسفتها حلوة ولا تخلو من البساطة والمجازات.عرفت فيما بعد أن هذه هي طريقة موراكامي في الكتابة، وروايته لا بد أن تُقرأ أكثرمن مرة واحدة حتي تحصل على إجابات لكل ما يشغلك حيالها."القدر بارع في رسم مسار حياتنا."الواحد مش هيبطل قراءة لموراكامي المجنون :D

کافکا در کرانه یک کتاب به اصطلاح متافیزیکی یا داستانی دور از واقعیت نیست. نابهنجاری درون داستان و اتفاقات غیر طبیعی چیزی نیست که خواننده کتاب رو وادار به تصور جهانی با ویژگی های خاص کنه. کتاب روایتی از دو جهان به همراه داره، جهانی زنده و جهانی مرده. نحوه ارتباط این دو دنیا با همدیگه‌ست که شما رو به یک تجربه فوق‌العاده از کتاب‌خوانی دعوت می‌کنه. هیپنوتیزمی که باعث اعتراض ش��ا بر منطق های موجود در ذهنتون می‌شه، کاری که موراکامی در اون تبحری زبان‌زد داره!داستان درباره پسر پانزده ساله‌ای به نام کافکا تاموراست که از خانه فرار می‌کند و خود در جایی به نام تاکاماستو می‌یابد. در آنجا کتابخانه‌ای خصوصی و جذابی را پیدا می‌کند که می‌تواند باقی روز های بلاتکلیف‌ش را در آن بگذراند. در این میان معلوم می‌شود که وقایع زندگی او و حتی جسم‌ش با مردی به نام کاناتا در ارتباط است. کاناتا پیرمردی بی‌سواد و کم هوش است که بر اثر سانحه‌ای در جنگ جهانی دوم در کمایی چند روزه می‌رود و پس از آن ذهن‌ش به‌طور کامل پاک می‌شود. کاناتا اگرچه بی‌سواد و از نظر ذهنی دچار مشکل است، اما استعداد های دیگری مانند صحبت کردن با گربه‌ها دارد. در انتها معلوم می‌شود که زندگی و راه کاناتا و کافکا به یکدیگر مربوط ‌می‌شود.شروع پر قدرت کتاب انتظار کشیدن برای پایانی فوق‌العاده ‌رو هم به همراه داره، هرچند که این انتظار در انتها به مفهومی که می‌خواستید نمی‌رسه اما به هرحال پایان ماجرای کافکاست. واضحه که موراکامی این قسمت از کتاب رو به قوه تخیل خود خوانندگان واگذار کرده که بعد از اتفاقاتی که برای کافکا رخ داد کار چندان سختی هم برای شما نیست.به جرعت می‌تونم بگم پیوستگی کتاب با اساطیر جهانی، غرق شدن در موسیقی و اهمیت به آثار هنری، ویژگی هایی از این کتاب هستند که هرکدوم به تنهایی خواننده رو مجذوب کتاب می‌کنه. هاروکی بدون شک یکی از کاربلد ترین نویسندگان تاریخ خودش محسوب می‌شه! حقیقتی که بعد خوندن هر کدوم از آثار این نویسنده، انکار ناپذیره.

انا قبل ما اتكلم عن الرواية لازم اتكلم عن عبقرية واختلاف هاروكي عن اي كاتب قراءت ليهانا عموما لما اقرء لكاتب وخياله يزيد بضايق وبقول مش طالبة افورة ...يعني احب الواقعي اكتر وده يمكن اللي مخليني مش حابب قوي الواقعية السحرية.. لكن هاروكي مختلف جدا ازاي يكتب فانتازيا واقعية بالجمال ده.. . ازاي يكتب اكتر من ستمائة صفحة ومفيش ملل... وازاي بيحكي عن قصص عادية جدا زي هروب شاب من عائلته وقصة حب وتقرأ وانت مشدود ومبهور بالقصة بتقرا صفح عن ناكاتا الشخصية العبقرية في الرواية وهو بيكلم قطط والقطط بتحكي وانت مبسوط ومش بتمل ولا بتقول ايه الهبل ده.. لا عايش جوا في خيال هاروكي ومنبهرهاروكي ده كأنه رجل كبير بيحكي لطفل قصة وقاعد بيسرح بخياله ويألف احداث والطفل قاعد فاتح بوءه جنبه ومبهور ومبيساءلش هو مستمتع وخلاص.. هو ده اللي حسيته في كافكا انا مبسوط من الرواية بالعالم الخيالي ده ومش عايزه يخلصفي الرواية ده خلق عالم خيالي غريب يبدأ بقصة لحدث مبهم في اليايان في الحرب العالمية الثانية ووقتنا الحالي لشاب بيهرب من البيت.. . في احداث الرواية الخيال بقي وماغ هاروكي شغالة... قطط بتتكلم..أحداث في حلم ولا حقيقية محدش عارف سماء يتمطر سمك. غراب بيحارب.. ..كون البطل بيحب الكتب والأحداث جزء منها في المكتبة زود حلاوة القصة.. كلامه عن الموسيقي والفن وتاريخ اليابان.. شخصية زي ناكاتا اللي مضايق اني مش هقرأ هنه تاني عبقرية مش عارف اتكلم عن الرواية غير اني اقول اقراوءها وهتعيشوا كام يوم مبسوطين ومتحاولوش تضايقوا نفسكم بفهم قصة هاروكي انبسطوا وهتطلعوا اكيد منها برسالة.. هو مش كاتب قصة بوليسي هو كاتب فانتازيا واقعية تسحرمن اجمل ما قراءت في حياتي لولا المشاهد الجنسية الزيادة لكانت خمس نجوم بجدارة.. تقييمي 4.5

Στα πρώτα κεφαλαία με συνεπήρε. Ήμουν σίγουρος ότι θα γίνει το αγαπημένο μου του Μουρακάμι. Μου άρεσε πολύ η πρωτο-πρόσωπη αφήγηση που χρησιμοποιεί σε αρκετά αποσπάσματα. Οι χαρακτήρες του, όπως σε ολα όσα έχω διαβάσει του ιδίου, μετεωρίζονται στο λίγο πριν ή λίγο μετά του αυτισμού. Αυτή τους η εσωστρέφεια σε αφήνει να τοποθετηθείς μέσα τους χωρίς κρίση, σαν άχρωμος παρατηρητής του κόσμου επιτρέποντας έτσι την αναγνώριση της πηγής οποιασδήποτε πινελιάς καταφέρει να αποδώσει έναν χρωματισμό. Κάνοντας ένα βήμα πίσω από τα πράγματα, αναστοχαζόμενος τα πώς και τα γιατί, σου επιτρέπεται να καταλήξεις στον τόπο που η συνθηκολόγηση έρχεται σε μια διαλεκτική με οποιαδήποτε τάση για αλλαγή. Αυτήν την εσωστρέφεια είχα ανάγκη όταν ξεκίνησα να το διαβάζω. Φαίνεται πάντως ότι στο συγκεκριμένο βιβλίο τα εξωπραγματικά στοιχεία με αποσυντόνησαν με έναν τρόπο που δεν συνέβη με οτιδήποτε άλλο εχω διαβάσει από αυτόν. Είχει πολύ ενδιαφέρον την ώρα που διάβαζα ψυχανάλυση να διαβάζω παράλληλα και Μουρακάμι. Φαίνεται πως η γραφή του εχει τουλάχιστον επηρεαστεί από κείμενα του Φρόυντ και του Γιούνγκ, εξού και η γραφή που προσιδιάζει σε όνειρο, η χαρακτηρολογική δομή του μυθιστορήματος, η αναφορά στο οιδιπόδειο και η αναζήτηση της μάνας. Τα τελευταία δύο κεφαλαία με επανέφεραν στο τόπο και χρόνο του "πραγματικού" δίνοντας μου την αγωνία των λογικών συνειρμών που παράγεται μέσω της ταύτισης.

این سومین اثری بود که از موراکامی خوندم و قطعا بعد از این هیچ کتابی از این نویسنده نخواهم خوند. یک سرگشتگی عمیق در ساختار و محتوای داستان هست که از اول تا آخر ادامه داره. هرجا محتوا شکل میگیره ساختار داستان از اون باز می‌مونه و هرجا ساختار منسجم می‌شه، محتوا پاک به فراموشی سپرده می‌شه و در نهایت خود نویسنده هم در این کلاف سر درگم نتونسته حق مطلب رو ادا کنه البته اگر حق مطلبی وجود داشته باشه!!! یک جمله ی  اساسی در صفحات آخر کتاب، تمام داستان رو خلاصه میکنه:«این چیزی نیست که بشود آن را در قالب کلمات ریخت، پاسخ واقعی چیزی است که کلمات نمی‌توانند بیانش کنند._دقیقا!، وقتی نتوان چیزی را در قالب کلمات ریخت، بهتر است ازش صرف نظر شود. “این کتاب فقط اِلمان های رئالیسم جادویی رو روی دوش حمل می‌کرد بدون اینکه سمت و سوی خاصی بگیره.کتاب از نظر من مخلوطی ناهمگن از این سه مورد بود:اول، ایده های جالبی که عمیقا بهشون پرداخته نشد، مثل وجود دنیای موازی با ما (بی مکان و بی زمان) / سنگ مدخل /مفهوم ماورا الطبیعه ی فاقد گوهر... البته این موارد از صفحه ی 320 به بعد وارد داستان میشن! دوم، جملات بسیار زیبا و مفهومی که هر صد صفحه با یکی از اون ها برخورد می‌کنیم،و شاید فقط همین عامل باعث شد کتاب رو تا انتها ادامه بدم. سوم، توضیحات مبسوط در رابطه با برخی از قطعات موسیقی و زندگینامه ی موسیقی‌دانان... در مجموع اگر روزی به این نتیجه رسیدید که تمام آثاری که ارزش خوانده شدن رو دارن رو خوندید، و دیگه ترسی از اتلاف زمان برای ششصد صفحه ی بی سر و ته ندارید! پیشنهاد میکنم حتما به سراغ این کتاب برید.

هذه رواية ملحمية، وراااائعة فعلاً ... يجب أن نشكر المترجمة "إيمان رزق الله" فالترجمة جعلت النص وكأنه مكتوبًا بالعربية :) رحلة في البحث عن الذات في جانب منها ورحلة في عالم غرائبي مدهش وشيق في ناحية أخرى مزج بينهما الراوي ببراعة وإتقان  . حسَّنت أيضًا هذه الرواية من علاقتي بالأدب المترجم بشكل عام، وعرفتني على الأدب الياباني الذي يبدو أصيلًا وأصليًا هو الآخـر ... لا أحب أن أضيَّع على القارئ استمتاعه باكتشاف عوالمها، ولكنها ممتعة وشيقة فعلاً .تتميز رحلة البحث عن الذات هنا أنها لا تقدم حلاً أو حلولاً بشكل مباشر، ولا تضع في طريقك معانِ مجانية مباشرة (كما يفعل باولو كويلو) مثلاً ، ولكنها رحلة حقيقية جدًا تؤمن بها وتتتفاعل مع كل أحداثها الحقيقية والغرائبية بشكل كامل  أيضًا يعد إنهائها في 6 أيام فقط إنجازًا في حد ذاته  وأعتقد أن لذلك دلالة مــا اقرؤوا عنها http://fadl2008.maktoobblog.com/90800.... ونقد لااااذع لها هنا http://www.n-dawa.com/articles.php?ca...

موراکامی به لطف زندگی در شهر چند ملیتی (کیوتو) شدیدا تحت تاثیر فرهنگ های مختلف قرار گرفته. آثارش در تلاشند در وهله اول فرهنگ ژاپن سنتی را با فرهنگ معاصر کشورش پیوند دهد و در وهله دوم آن را با فرهنگ غرب آشتی دهد. هاروکی شیفته سبک سورئالیسم است. طوری که در در جایی از کتاب از زبان اوشیما می گوید: "آنچه بیشتر مایه انزجارم می شود، آدمهایی هستند که قوه تخیل ندارند. همان جور آدمهایی که تی اس الیوت به آنها میگوید، انسان پوک." در جایی دیگری می گوید: "مسئولیت ما از قدرت تخیل شروع می شود. درست همانطور که ییتس میگوید: مسئولیت از رویا آغاز میشود." شخصا وقتی کتاب را باز می کردم، از دنیای واقعی دست می کشیدم و غرق در دنیای کافکا و ناکاتا می شدم. حجم کتاب اصلا دلزننده نیست. و تک تک جزییات با ه�� در ارتباط هستند. اوایل خوانش کتاب چون با تخیل شدید نویسنده شروع میشود، شاید برای خواننده نا آشنا و حوصله سر بر باشد ولی در ادامه به این نتیجه خواهد رسید که موراکامی چطور مفاهیم اصیل انسانی را با مفاهیم مهم دیگر مثل روانشناسی پیوند داده است.

Just finished this book about 10 minutes and have that post Murakamifeeling of what do I do now!!!This book was just so unusual and captivating and beautifully writtenthat it's difficult to know what to read next.Murakami's books are very easy to read but you need to be prepared for something very unique and just go with the flow.Even though the story is very different to anything else I have read andthe characters are really unusual it just all seems so logical andanything that happens in the story after a while seems to make perfectsense.Every character in this book will stay with me for a long time.Murakami makes you feel like you know them personally and someparts of the story are quite sad and moving.So basically I just loved this book and recommend it to anyonewho wants to read something unusual and challenging.

إذا كنت تبحث عن رواية لها بداية ونهاية واحداث متسلسلة فهذه الرواية ليست لك،واذا كنت تتوقع ان يجيب الكاتب عن اسئلتك فيما يخص سياق الرواية وشخصياتها واحداثها فايضا انت اخترت الكاتب الخطأ..اما اذا كنت تريد ان تذهب لعالم مغاير لعالمك،عالم لكل قيمة فيه معنى مختلف عن ما تعودت ان تفهمه،فاهلا بك فى عالم موراكامي ا��ساحر العجائبي،موراكامي لا يشبه غيره لانه يكتب فى عالم وعن عالم لا وجود له الا فى مخيلة من يبحث عن معنى مغاير لكل ما وجد عليه العالم،فالحب والموت والذكريات وحتى الجنس داخل عالم موراكامي مختلف،عجيب،وآسر..شخصيات موراكامي كما عرفناها دوما ليست طبيعية بالمعنى المعروف لتلك الكلمة،معظمها شخصيات متوحدة،انعزالية،تبحث عن معنى لحياتها..موراكامي من كتابي المفضلين وسيظل دوما ،لانك لا تصبح كما كنت بعد الدخول لعالمه..

Murakami me ha hecho percibir la vida de una manera más profunda y sensorial, encontrar belleza y magia incluso en la cotidianidad, la soledad, la rutina y la incertidumbre. Me siento retratado en sus personajes (sumergidos en el mar de sus miedos, dudas, recuerdos y anhelos) que en busca de respuestas y sentido a su vida encuentran consuelo en los libros, el arte, la música, la naturaleza y perciben una luz cálida de esperanza y amor en quienes sin interés alguno los ayudaron en su camino.

اصلا با کتاب‌هایی که توش اتفاق‌های عجیب می‌افته مشکل دارم. اما تویسنده از اتفاق‌هایی که برای این هولدن این کتاب می‌افته اون‌قدر ساده رد میشه که صمیمانه کتاب رو باور می‌کنی و چاره‌ای هم جز این نداری. کتاب از اون کتاب‌هاست که کم کم جون می‌گیره و به کسایی که نخومدن توصیه می‌کنم به رمان فرصت بدن که خودش رو پیدا کنه.خوب یا بد این تجربه‌ي عجیب و غریب از دست‌دادنی نیست.

كتب الصديق محمّد عمر (@omarmoh60) قراءةً تحليليّةً مثرية للرواية إبّان قراءته إيّاها قبل أربعةأعوام: كنت مساء أمس وبعد انتهاء التدريب استعجل العودة إلى البيت للانتهاء من رواية هاروكي موراكامي "كافكا على الشاطئ"...كان المطر النازل خفيفا على عمّان يغري بالمشي. ولقد سرت مشيا من الدوار الخامس حتى منزلي في الشميساني.وصلت البيت ولا زلت على حماسي لإنهاء الرواية التي كنت بدأت في قراءتها قبل يومين...اعتقد أنني لم اقرأ رواية أفضل منها خلال الخمس سنوات الأخيرة، ولم اقرأ رواية بنفس المتعة والاستفزاز الفكري والتدقيق في كل سطر وكلمة كما قرأت هذا العمل الروائي الجبار.تتكون رواية الياباني موراكامي من 672 صفحة من القطع الكبير ومع ذلك لم اشعر بالملل في أي صفحة..يعمل موراكامي ليس على "رواية" بالمعنى الروائي البحت، بل على إعادة قراءة تاريخ اليابان بعد الحرب العالمية الثانية من منظور فلسفة "هيغل"، الذي يقول يجب :" أن ننظر إلى التاريخ بعين العقل، التي هي وحدها القادرة على اختراق السطح المبرقش للأحداث اليومية"، ويستعين موراكامي بهيغل في جدليته المعرفية في بناء : الأطروحة (الفرضية)، النقيض، التركيب أو " Thesis, antithesis, synthesis ".لكن موراكامي، المأخوذ في "ثلاثيات" فلسفة هيغل : المنطق، الطبيعة، الروح/العقل. وكل الثلاثيات الاخرى المتفرعة عنها، يقود سرده في خط مواز، فيعمل على تشريح "أزمة هوية اليابان" والجرح النرجسي لها بعد هزيمتها في الحرب العالمية الثانية من منظور التحليل النفسي، مستعينا بمسرحية سوفكليس "الملك اوديب" كحبكة في الرواية، و بـ"الثلاثية الاوديبية" أي بـ "عقدة اوديب" عند سيغموند فرويد في التحليل النفسي لأزمة الهوية التي يعاني منها الشباب الياباني.تستشكل رواية موراكامي بشدة على القارئ العربي لعدة أسباب، لكن السبب الأساس يعود إلى ما يعتبره عالم النفس العربي عدنان حبّ الله من أن المجتمع العربي، من منظور التحليل النفسي، لا يزال يخضع للأشكال القبلية ما قبل "العقدة الاوديبية الثلاثية". هذا إضافة إلى "المجاز" والرمز والواقعية السحرية واللغة الشعبية التي يكتب بها موراكامي وسعة ثقافته الموسوعية أو الشاملة تماما كما هو هيغل آخر الفلاسفة الشموليين، فيلسوف موراكامي المفضل.والحال الثلاثي نفسه في المنظور الثقافي لموراكامي، فهو يستعين أيضا بمقطوعة بتهوفن "ثلاثية الارشيدوق"، يطلق عليها ثلاثية لأنها تعزف على بيانو بمصاحبة الكمان والشيلو، وعمل موراكامي على: الثقافة اليابانية الكلاسيكية من خلال شخصية تاناكا، وثقافة جيل ما بعد الحرب، ثقافة الأب النحات (جوني ووكر) والأم "ساييكي"، وثقافة الجيل الحالي المشتت بين سلفية تائهة منفصلة عن الواقع، عند الشخصية الرئيسية الفتى كافكا تامورا، وثقافة التغريب والعولمة الثقافية المحصورة في الإعجاب بنمط الحياة الأميركي لدرجة نسيان تاريخ البلد بما في ذلك الحرب العالمية وهزيمة اليابان فيها عبر شخصية الشاب هوشينو.كما كان هيغل مثالي في جدليته يرى ان العقل البشري يعمل على المجاز في المادة والوعي للتوصل الى الحقائق المطلقة في الكون، فان رواية موراكامي هي رواية "المجاز" بكل ما في الكلمة من معنى : الأحداث التاريخية كحالة الإغماء التي تصيب طلبة الصف في فسحة دائرية وسط غابة خلال الحرب العالمية الثانية وبعد مشاهدة القاذفة الأميركية الـ "بـ29" ثم الغيبوبة الطويلة للفتى تاناكا وعودته للوعي المفقود، او اسم البطل كافكا تامورا، او ترجمة موراكامي لاسم كافكا "الغراب" او الفتى كرو (الغراب) او الجنرال "ساندرس" صاحب ماركة "دجاج كنتاكي" أو الإشارة إلى الف ليلة وليلة أو سجائر المارلبور وعصابات الياكوزي، والحجر، ولوحة وأغنية "كافكا على الشاطيء"، وازمة القروض، والماركات التجارية الاميركية، والادب الياباني، والمكتبة، والديانات والموسيقى، أو مغني البوب الاميركي "برينس" وأفلام فرانسوا ترفو وفيلم صوت الموسيقى وغيرها، إجمالا فأن كل رواية موراكامي هي "مجاز هيغلي"، ان جاز ليّ التعبير، سواء في السرد نفسه والحبكة أو في الرموز والإشارات والعلامات والأحداث الظاهرة للتاريخ. لكن في مجاز موراكامي يصعب فصل الحلم عن الحقيقة في أحيان كثيرة ويصعب فصل الخيال عن الواقع، ذلك ان موراكامي يعمل على واقعية سحرية كتلك التي عند ماركيز لكنه موراكامي هنا يقدم رواية "معرفية" أيضا. رواية بها كم معرفي هائل في الأدب والتاريخ والموسيقى وعلم الجمال والأخلاق والفلسفة والسياسية والفن وغيرها.لكن موراكامي ليس كاتبا عربيا مهمته الندب واللطم والكآبة، هو كاتب "هيغلي"، يعتبر ان التاريخ مهما بدا مجنونا وشريرا وغير عقلاني الا ان صيرورته تتجه دوما نحو مزيد من التحرر من الضرورة ونحو فهم أفضل للذات أو وعي للذات والى مزيد من العقلانية والحرية والأخلاق وهو ما حصل مع الشخصيات الرئيسية في الرواية كافكا تامورا الذي يغادر سلفيته وغرقه في "طبيعية" عدمية رافضة للحضارة وهوشينيو الذي يغادر جنونه وولعه بحياة تسطحية وفردية نفعية تصل حد "الكلبية" ليعي ان مساعدة الآخرين والذهاب عميقا فيما وراء الظاهر هو تحرر وانعتاق حقيقي.وفي النهاية فان ما يفضل ايضا عند موراكامي هو "الثقافة" فالمكتبة هي الشيء الوحيد الذي يبقى بين كافكا تامورا المنفصل عن واقعه وامه ساييكي ابنة الهزيمة...على صعوبة حل الغاز موراكامي في "كافكا على الشاطئ"، مع انه يقدم في صفحات الرواية مفاتيح كثيرة لفهمهما كلما تقدم السرد، إلا ان روايته تقرأ وتقرأ بشغف لجمال السرد وخيال الروائي العبقري وثقافته الموسوعية وجمال ترجمة إيمان حرز الله ومراجعة سامر ابو هواش...

THIS is a book to reread that's for sure. I feel like I understood what happened but I think reading it a second time at a later date would cement that for me. The themes in this book are similar to Murakami's other work- isolation and change. I really loved the way our two main characters dealt with the changes in their lives. They both grew throughout the story. The writing in this was beautiful and although it isn't my favourite Murakami book I can see why so many people adore it. I need some time to think about this because it is kind of a lot to take in, especially that last 20%. Highly recommend though.

Phew! "You have the right to remain silent; anything you do or say will be held against you..." Should I remain silent, or should I go for it?That's my immediate reaction to this book. If ever I was confused about an ending, this is it. Am I correct in thinking that the reader is suppose to conclude the story, because the author had everything so mixed up that he was unable to do it himself? Or perhaps an ending in the real world would simply demolish the fantasy of this metaphysical journey through Greek mythology - especially Orpheus and the Oedipus complex, the classical music composers and literature? This tale becomes a metaphor for all of the above elements in the book.Well, three characters are definitely dead. That's a fact. The others are hanging around between childhood memories, reincarnation, and pure fantasy and I simply don't know where to bury them! Should it be in an alternative reality or reality? I simply do not know.Facts: Fifteen-year-old Kafka Tamura runs away from home-he wants to find his mother and sister-and decides to travel to Shikoku, since it is the opposite direction of where anyone would search to find him. He lands up in a private library, meets Oshima who, finally, understands the young man's thoughts, experiences and fantasies. Oshima understands the deeper dimensions of Kafka's troubled mind. After looking at a painting in the library, and listening to Miss Saeki's song 'Kafka on the shore' he finally realizes that it was his destiny that brought him there. Mysterious Miss Saeki was much more than he ever bargained for. The song was the riddle he needed to resolve.An old misunderstood man, Nakata, lives his life as a simpleton, talking to cats, and does not fight his destinies of illiteracy after a mysterious accident, as a nine-year-old boy, wiped out his memory completely. He is like a library without books. He does not understand desires, nor destiny. Yet, he meets Johnie Walker and the next moment there's blood everywhere, and nobody wants to believe his version of the story. He doesn't know why leeches, fish and sardines rain down from the open, cloudless skies when he opens his umbrella, but he does know the timeline of his future. He needs to leave Tokyo and head out to Shikoku, over the big bridge but doesn't know why. He only knows he should go.He hitch-hike there and at one of the truck stops he finally meets up with Hoshino, a truck driver, who never thanked his late grandfather for not giving up on him. So when these two characters meet, Hoshino decides to help this helpless old man reach his destiny to honor his grandfather's memory. Never in his wildest dreams would Hoshino have imagined that he would meat finger lickin' good Colonel Sanders who acted as a pimp, as well as reveal himself as God in a human conceptual disguise. A mystical bond between Kafka and Nakata plays itself out through the tale in a confusing, yet riveting drama, sprinkled with philosophical, as well satirical moments. Colonel Sanders had a weird sense of humor. It lightens up the drama considerably.To make the events work, the characters must be able to become "ghosts while they are still alive.”The book starts out with a totally different possibility, when nine-year-old Nakata, as a member of the school group, walks into the woods with their teacher, in 1944, almost at the end of WWII, to collect mushrooms, and witness a strange flash in the sky, a silver flash, looking much like a reflection coming from an American B-29 bomber. While in the woods, all seventeen children fell unconscious and could not remember what happened. Sixteen recovered completely. Nakata, the seventeenth boy, did not regain consciousness and was moved to a military hospital where he eventually, after three weeks, woke up, his memory completely wiped out. He never regained the ability to read or write either.There is therefor never in indication in the beginning of the book that the story would venture off in a totally different direction and that the silver flash-event will never be fully developed or explained. There is no plausible solution to it. Perhaps it was used as a red herring?A murder is committed, the police are searching for the killer, which brings the suspense and drama alive and kept me reading. The characters were beautifully developed, each embedded in their absurd life stories. Dreams, fantasies and reality blend into an almost impossible, surreal, bizarre story with a strong sexual overtone. All the characters are likable. They are all lonely people who create their own realities to survive on their own. They all have different triggers for their cocooned, emotional-devoided lives. They are all searching for either the other half of their shadows, or the love they never find. Most of them want acceptance. They are all endearing, good people who were dealt a nasty hand and found the courage to take up the challenges. There is one common evil connection who held the strings of their lives in his hands. One of them had the ability to end it all, and he did.It is a good read. A masterful manipulation of the reader. A confusing, but exciting adventure. The reader is challenged with the existence of God. There is brutal violence and sexual innuendos and magical descriptions of the modern Japanese landscape. I felt deep empathy for all of the characters. Simply loved them all, except for the 'baddy'.If you don't mind finding the answers to all the unanswered questions left at the end, you will enjoy the book. But you've got to believe in ghosts, myths, and metaphysical magic. I will consider reading this author again. And I might consider rereading this book to come to a better understanding of the ending. However, I do not appreciate the clumsiness in leaving so many elements unresolved.I am not disappointed. Just highly confused. I enjoyed the experience though.

"Kafka on the Shore" by Haruki Murakami is a puzzling and captivating novel that enlaces multiple narratives, blurring the lines between reality and dreams, and exploring themes of identity, loneliness, and the search for meaning. The premise is brilliant: Kafka Tamura, a teenage boy who runs away from home to escape his father's curse, and Nakata, an elderly man who lost his memory in a childhood accident and possesses the ability to communicate with cats. Filled with mysterious occurrences, symbolic imagery, and philosophical musings, Murakami's prose is richly atmospheric, drawing readers into a surreal world where magical realism and mundane reality coexist seamlessly while inviting the reader to ponder the nature of existence and the interconnectedness of all things. It’s strength is that it does not provide easy answers or neatly tie up its narrative threads. Murakami revels in ambiguity, leaving many questions unanswered and encouraging interpretation of the story's events in a unique and immersive way.

1.5 StarsThe title was intriguing but the story was meh. Crow decides to run away from home when he turned 15. He takes his necessary stuff and a photograph of him and his sister as there were no other photos available. He had been very distant from his dad so mostly he was on his own reading books and training. Changed his name to Kafka and traveled to Takamatsu so that no one is able to find him. Stayed at a hotel and went to the Komura Library and gym to pass his time. One day he found himself outside a shrine covered in blood but didn't remember anything. The next day he went to the library and shared his problem with the librarian, who decided to help him and took him to his outhouse in the mountains until he arranged his job at the library as an Assistant. Kafka got the job and shifted in the library. His father was killed the night he had blood on his clothes but he didn't do it. The library was owned by Miss Saeki whom he started liking. She wrote a poem for her boyfriend who was killed; the song became a massive hit. She even told Kafka about her story of the lightning survivor interviews she took when she was in Tokyo. Kafka also remembered that once his father also survived lightning and it was then he started his profession as a sculptor seriously. The police tried to connects dots between Kafka and Nakata for the murder. Nakata was the one who confessed about the murder and was now headed towards Takamatsu. Nakata was the boy who lost his ability to read and write after the incident which took place during the second World War in the mountains where his teacher took him and others for an outdoor activity. The teacher later confessed that Nakata was a bright student but she slapped him before the incident and was very guilty of doing that. When he came back to his senses after many weeks he couldn't write or read hence his parents sent him away to his grandparents. There he learnt how to craft wood at a furniture shop and worked there for many years. After the furniture shop closed down he moved to the city where he got subsidy from the Governor and a special ride bus pass which covered his expenses. He had the ability to talk with cats so people came to him when their cats went missing, he found them and got paid. Once he was searching for a cat named Goma and got to know that a man kept stealing cats from the abandoned lot. He started staying at the lot for look out but didn't find Goma. A dog led him to Johnnie Walkers house who killed cats and in order to save Gome, Nakata stabbed him. Then went to the police to confess the murder but the police officer didn't take him seriously. Nakata was looking for a stone which he found and opened the entrance and met Miss Saeki at the library. She gave him a pile of stories of her life and told him to burn them, which he did. Miss Saeki was later found dead in her office. Nakata also died whereas Kafka decided to go back to Tokyo, complete his education and face the police. 4,5 estrelasQue livro! "Kafka à Beira-Mar" é diferente de tudo o que já li e, apesar, de não me ter agarrado logo no início, revelou-se um livro genial que me transformou numa fã do afamado autor nipónico!Esta história foca-se em duas personagens distintas e sem conexão aparente: - Kafka Tamura (nome falso, escolhido pelo próprio), um rapaz que decide fugir de casa no dia em que celebra 15 anos, devido a dramas familiares (em especial uma maldição lançada pelo pai) e - Nakata, um idoso de 70 anos, que sofreu um acidente misterioso na infância onde perdeu capacidades cognitivas, mas ganhou a habilidade de falar com gatos e de prever acontecimentos meteorológicos bizarros.Os capítulos vão alternando entre Kafka e Nakata, culminando no ponto em que os seus destinos se acabam por cruzar.Adorei as personagens principais (Kafka e Nakata) e os seus companheiros mais próximos (Oshima e Hoshino), que sempre tiveram papéis relevantes e essenciais para a história. Visto que Nakata não sabe ler, Hoshino tem um papel fulcral na história do ancião e gostei muito do destaque que esta personagem foi tendo. Também gostei bastante da presença d' "O Rapaz Chamado Corvo", uma espécie de conselheiro espiritual de Kafka, que analisava os seus comportamentos e pensamentos, ora o julgando e repreendendo, ora o consolando e compreendendo.O livro está pontuado com inúmeras referências literárias (algo que me agrada sempre), musicais (gostei especialmente da de jazz) e de cultura japonesa, mística e bem diferente da europeia. Adorei a escrita e marquei inúmeras passagens, que me deixaram a refletir sobre várias questões relativas à indentidade e condição humana (especialmente graças aos diálogos entre Kafka e Oshima, uma personagem extremamente culta e com uma mente ampla e sagaz). O surreal é uma componente sempre presente no livro e, apesar de haver partes muito estranhas, quase cómicas de tão absurdas, o quadro geral é muito interessante e agradou-me de sobremaneira. É incrível como Murakami construiu um livro tão complexo e intrincado, partindo de personagens e de uma premissa tão simples. E é também incrível como o fez em cerca de 600 páginas que passam por nós a voar, tal a vontade que o leitor sente em prosseguir com a leitura para chegar a um ponto de reencontro (porque a verdade é que nos perdemos neste livro e, tal como as personagens, também saímos um pouco da nossa zona de conforto).Recomendo veemente e vou querer ler mais livros do autor, sem dúvida!!P.S. relativo à edição que li: Gostei muito das notas de rodapé desta edição e de todas as informações relativas à cultura japonesa! Contudo, infelizmente, reparei que nesta tradução abundam expressões portuguesas como "cai o Carmo e a Trindade" - uma alusão à queda destas igrejas durante o terramoto de 1755 em Lisboa e, como tal, muito dificilmente uma expressão que Murakami teria usado no original... Claro que as traduções incluem sempre adaptações e alterações, mas fiquei triste por não ser muito fiel e quis deixar essa ressalva, pois acaba por afetar a leitura.

This book was great, though confusing and deeply philosophical at times. It is about a 15-year-old boy who runs from home and tries to create a life for himself in another city. All his life he's been tormented by his past, due to his mother and sister abandoning him and his life with a strange and distant father. He ends up working at a mysterious bookstore filled with collections of rare books, meeting the enigmatic bookkeeper, Oshima, and head of the library, Miss Saeki. The story is filled with strange occurrences of slipping out of the self to perform tasks such as murder, over realistic dreams of sex, unlocking the portal to a netherworld between life and death, and so on.This story challenges the preconception of time, reality, and dreams. It reconfirms our (mis)understanding that this world is full of mystical things beyond comprehension. It questions the meaning of freedom, forcing us to ponder our consciousness and our relationship to the larger universe.

4,5 sao Giờ hiểu sao nhiều người trên Goodreads không biết ghi cảm nhận gì cho quyển này rồi :v Quyển này thực sự rất choáng ngợp luôn ấy, có rất nhiều thứ xảy ra trong 500 trang sách này. Mình thực sự speechless với quyển này... Thiệt giờ mà phân tích đầy đủ quyển này chắc cũng dài mấy đôi giấy...Nói ngắn gọn thì chuyến hành trình này như một chuyến thiền định nửa mơ nửa thực đào sâu vào những góc tâm tối nhất của tâm hồn. Đúng như lời mở đầu quyển sách, đọc xong nó cảm tưởng như vừa đi qua một tâm lốc xoáy, mọi lo lắng đều sau lưng, trước mắt chỉ là bầu trời trong xanh và một cảm giác thanh thản.Trừ bớt 0.5 sao do có rất nhiều chỗ mình không thích cách Haruki viết về tình dục và cách xây dựng nhân vật nữ. کتاب را تمام کردم اما هنوز پر از سوالم.در سیر خواندم دائم به نسخه اصلی مراجعه می‌کردم تا سانسور، مانع فهمم نشود. وقتی که رمان رو تموم کردم فکر می‌کردم مشکل از من بوده که نفهمیدمش اما بعد‌تر با خوندن مصاحبه موراکامی فهمیدم که این اتفاقا همون چیزیه که این ذهن داستان‌سرا می‌خواسته. خود موراکامی میگه بعد از سه یا چهار بار خواندن رمان یک سری از معما‌ها و سرنخ‌های داستان قابل تشخیص می‌شوند! که ادعای عجیبی هم نیست!شاید عبارت رئالیسم جادویی برای توصیف کافکا در ساحل خوب باشه. تجربه خوانش این داستان مثل ایستادن و گذاشتن پا روی شن‌های گرم ساحله. شخصیت‌ها دائما از واقع به خیال و از خیال به واقع سفر می‌کنند؛ مثل آب دریا که موج اون رو به ساحل میاره و بعد چند ثانیه باز چیزی که می‌مونه پاهای لخت تو روی شن‌های گرم ساحله.به نظرم همه شخصیت پردازی ها به یک اندازه خوب نیستند اما در مجموع میشه گفت موراکامی از پس ساخت شخصیت‌های متعدد بر اومده. بیشترین نقاط ابهام برام مربوط به شخصیت جانی واکر، کلنل ساندرس و گذشته ناکاتاست...متوجه نشدم که گزارش‌هایی که از گذشته ناکاتا داده می‌شد به کجا رسید و چرا...قسمت‌های اروتیک کتاب کم نبود و می‌شد که حداقل به طرز رقیق تری بهشون پرداخته بشه و این شکل روایت می‌تونم ادعا کنم به ذائقه من نزدیک نبود...در مجموع باید بگم تجریه به شدت متفاوتی بود خواندن کتاب موراکامی. من بعد از مقایسه، ادعا می‌کنم ترجمه گیتا گرکانی رو به دیگر ترجمه ها ترجیح می‌دهم.
Vor 10 Jahren gelesen.

Voleli ga ili ne, u svim Murakamijevim delima, prepoznaje se autentičnost kako u maniru pisanja tako i u atmosferi koju pisac nedri neobičnim likovima i zagonetkama na koje njegovi junaci traže odgovore na svom putu samospoznaje. Za razliku od ranije pročitanih Murakamijevih dela, koja mi se jesu svidela, Kafka na obali mora je prva njegova knjiga koje me je u potpunosti oduševila i očarala. U glavi mi se vrzmala ideja kako bi ova knjiga bila izvrsna potka za Mijazakijev film. Čudno i jedinstveno putovanje.5/5

Kafka On The Shore is definitely the weirdest book I have Ever Read In My Life!!! I have literally more than 100 questions about this book. So I searched for internet articles on Kafka On the Shore and Guess what I have found? In Haruki Murakami's own website--"Kafka on the Shore contains several riddles, but there aren’t any solutions provided. Instead several of these riddles combine, and through their interaction the possibility of a solution takes shape. And the form this solution takes will be different for each reader. To put it another way, the riddles function as part of the solution. It’s hard to explain, but that’s the kind of novel I set out to write."Really Mr Murakami??😒 *Goes to build my own theories*Murakami recieved more than 8000 questions in 3 months about this book and he answered 1200 of them personally. Now you can think of how many riddles this book contains. Book covers the story of Two Characters Kafka Tamura(15yo boy) and Mr Nakata(60yo man) in alternate chapters. But their stories somehow intertwined with each other.The characters on this book are best part. They are really diverse to each in every aspects of the life. You will learn a lot from them.Book is full of weird elements from Sprit World to Talking Cats, Flute made up of cats soul to Falling fish from the sky!I literally can not define the weirdness of this book in words. While reading this book, every once in a while I was like what the heck did just happened?? This book contains various western culture refrences. You will get a lot of musical refrences from The Beatles to Beethoven's Archduke Trio. It is 615 pages long but you will not drift off while reading. This book confuses reader and make them think way too much but don't let them abandon the book that's the real beauty of book. Kafka on the Shore makes sense but also doesn't!One thing I can say about Murakami, his way of describing things is just Wondrous. It literally feels as though you are living in that world with those very characters. He's truly a genius. 
"Everyone of us is losing something precious to us. Lost opportunities, lost possibilities, feelings we can never get back. That’s part what it means to be alive. But inside our heads, there’s a room where we store those memories. And to understand the workings of our own heart we have to keep on making new reference cards. We have to dust things off every once in a while, let in fresh air, change the water in flower bases. In other words, you’ll live life in your own private library."

https://www.vintagestories.gr/o-kafka...Η πραγματικότητα με τη φαντασία ενώνονται για ακόμη μία φορά.«Θα ήθελα και άλλο». Έτσι αισθάνομαι κάθε φορά μετά από ένα βιβλίο του Χαρούκι Μουρακάμι. Ο Κάφκα στην ακτή, ήταν ένα από τα βιβλία που περίμενα εδώ και πολύ καιρό να διαβάσω και μόλις προς τα τέλη του 2015 κυκλοφόρησε από τις εκδόσεις Ψυχογιός.Η αίσθηση που είχα διαβάζοντάς το, μου θύμισε Το κουρδιστό πουλί (εκδόσεις Ωκεανίδα, 2005) που μαζί με το Νορβηγικό δάσος (εκδόσεις Ψυχογιός, 2012) είναι από τα πλέον αγαπημένα μου του Μουρακάμι. Ο Κάφκα στην ακτή τελείωσε και οι χαρακτήρες του ήταν για πολύ καιρό μέσα μου, με συντρόφευαν κάθε στιγμή της μέρας: Ο μικρός Ταμούρα, ικανός να σου θυμίσει οποιονδήποτε νεαρό στο δρόμο ή στα μέσα συγκοινωνίας· θα ακούσεις όμως και τον Νακάτα σε μια γωνιά του δρόμου να μιλάει με έναν γάτο· θα κοιτάξεις ακόμη και τον ουρανό γιατί αν περιμένεις μπορεί και να βρέξει ψάρια…Έχουμε να κάνουμε με ένα μυθιστόρημα ενηλικίωσης. Ο δεκαπεντάχρονος Ταμούρα, αποφασίζει να φύγει από το σπίτι του θέλοντας να αποφύγει την προφητεία του πατέρα του, ότι θα τον σκοτώσει και ότι θα «κοιμηθεί» με την μητέρα του και την αδερφή του, οι οποίες έχουν εξαφανιστεί από το σπίτι τους απ΄όταν ο Ταμούρα ήταν ήδη τεσσάρων. Ο Κάφκα, γιατί αυτό είναι το ψευδώνυμό του, δεν είναι ένας απλός έφηβος, είναι λιγομίλητος, συνεσταλμένος και λατρεύει τα βιβλία. Σε πολλές περιπτώσεις τη δύναμη τη βρίσκει από τον Κρόου, το άλλο του μισό, που είναι πάντα εκεί, είναι η εσωτερική φωνή του…Παράλληλα γνωρίζουμε και τον Νακάτα, έναν ηλικιωμένο που από ένα πολύ ιδιαίτερο γεγονός του Δεύτερου Παγκοσμίου Πολέμου, θα χάσει μέρος από τις μνήμες του αλλά και την εξυπνάδα του. Από τότε είναι που απέκτησε το ιδιαίτερο χάρισμα να μιλάει με τις γάτες.Οι δύο ιστορίες τους αναπτύσσονται παράλληλα, αλλά θα μπερδευτούν με τρόπο απρόσμενο οδηγώντας μας στην εκπλήρωση της προφητείας. Το μυθιστόρημα Κάφκα στην ακτή, είναι μια αναζήτηση στο χρόνο και στο οποίο γεγονότα του παρελθόντος μπορούν να γίνουν γεγονότα του παρόντος αλλά και στιγμές του παρόντος επηρεάζουν ακόμη και το μέλλον.Από ένα σημείο και μετά γινόμαστε κι εμείς ο Κάφκα Ταμούρα, ζούμε τη δική του «αρχαία ελληνική τραγωδία», με την εκπλήρωση της προφητείας που τον έκανε να το σκάσει από το σπίτι και να προσπαθήσει να ανακαλύψει τον εαυτό του. Όνειρα, Τραύματα, σεξ, είναι μόνο λίγες από τις έντονες στιγμές του.Συνέχεια > https://www.vintagestories.gr/o-kafka...

To read Kafka on the Shore is to weave through the malleable boundary between reality and fantasy, to meet philosophical prostitute, talking cats, and characters like Johnny Walker and Colonel Sanders, to dream of the dialectics of Hegal and the continuous time of Bergson converging with the Oedipal complex, to journey into Haruki Murakami’s imagination. I want to know whether Kafka killed his father, whether the librarian was his mother, and whether he was dreaming when he met his mother. I want to know whether Nakata was just fantasizing that he could talk to cats. But as in Murakami’s other two novels, The Wind Up Bird Chronicle and Hardboiled Wonderland and the End of the World, reality and dream synthesize into a world that transcends truth or illusion. And Murakami takes us along his wonderland and shows what we too could imagine if we free our minds from the biases, the limits, and the cannots we have accepted as truth. Reality almost seems sterile when we immerse ourselves in Murakami’s surrealism. And I invite you to dream along with Murakami on a shore far into the sea of imagination where a song’s lyrics echo back into reality.  Haruki Murakami

Είναι τα βλέφαρά μουδιάφανες αυλαίες.Όταν τα ανοίγω βλέπωμπρος μου ό,τι κι αν τύχει.Όταν τα κλείνω βλέπωμπρος μου ό,τι ποθώ.Lynchian MetamorphosisThe vague feeling of an upcoming tragedyThe transparent world of dreams and fantasy and their consequencesKafka and Oedipus meet only to make things greater and complicated. The unity of action, place and time it’s something essential in Greek Tragedy according to Aristotles, but Murakami present his story with an elusive and hallucinatory way. A puzzle, a labyrinth, a profoundly moving yet complex tale of fate, adulthood and responsibility. Sometimes the allegories, the situations and even the feelings can’t always be explained or occasionally seem a bit forced . Also the dialogues seem weird and forced but that bizarreness is what I enjoy most. Nakata and Oshima are so great characters that I can’t even put it in words. The trip was intriguing and completely fantastic. Murakami make his worlds with his own rules but so close to reality, that seem only a version among thousand others. And his version always get under your skin somehow as if it was completely tangible. His storytelling is what I love the most about this author but there are a few things here or there that put me off. Something is missing as the pieces of the puzzle are not in their place, at least not all of them. But it doesn’t have to everything make sense, doesn’t it ?

Mai avrei pensato di leggere un libro così onirico, surreale . Un libro dove i gatti parlano , dove pesci e sanguisughe cadono dal cielo come pioggia , maledizioni, profezie , sogni e realtà che si fondono in un’unica dimensione . Con Murakami mi sono lasciata trasportare e mi sono fidata della sua bellissima scrittura e ho deciso di seguirlo , di non farmi troppe domande e lasciarmi coinvolgere da queste sue atmosfere così intime e delicate , forti e misteriose . Murakami è stato molto abile a creare fin dalle prime pagine una forte tensione , una sorta di suspense che mi ha spinto a continuare ad andare avanti , quasi fosse un giallo da risolvere . Il protagonista ,Tamura, compie un viaggio con direzione per la formazione del proprio io , infatti nonostante le sue arie da adulto resta comunque un quindicenne alla ricerca di se e del proprio posto nel mondo . Nakata il coprotagonista con la sua storia parallela seguirà il destino del protagonista , ed è l’esatto opposto, un uomo totalmente privo di interiorità , avvolto da una luce e da una storia misteriosa , capace di cose al tempo stesso ingenue e sovrumane . Il romanzo ha una struttura talmente ben congeniale nei tempi narrativi da rendere il lettore impossibilitato a staccarsi dalle pagine . Un libro affascinante e magnetico .

Умее грациозно да предизвиква читателя, приканва го да търси отговори, да тълкува, да разплита фините нишки на мистерията.„Кафка на плажа“ е книга, в която има всичко – два паралелно преплитащи се сюжета, загадки и съвпадения, интересни и дълбоки разговори, библиотека, странно пророчество, дъжд от риби, философия и метафори, предположения и спомени, котки и интимни фантазии, една особена песен – простичка, но проникновена, с красива мелодия и почти сюрреали��тичен текст, който дума по дума намира отклик в сърцето и още…Мураками те повежда през един лабиринт от мисли и илюзии, копнежи и преживявания, в търсене на 
входа
 към друг свят, където времето е спряло и никой не може да те открие...

رمان ششصد صفحه ای "کافکا در کرانه" نوشته موراکامی در واقع اثری سورئال سرشار از استعاره، تمثیل و اسطوره است. رمان از دوداستان موازی با دوقهرمان دوست داشتنی تشکیل شده است که در عین حال مستقل از یکدیگر نیستند. یکی از قهرمانان داستان پسری پانزده ساله به نام کافکا است که منتقدان وی را نمونه ی شرقی هولدن در رمان ناتوردشت می نامند و در این رمان قهرمان بیشترسفری درونی دارد واقعیت و خیال، رویا و بیداری و حتی اتفاقات غیرواقعی با حوادث معمول در این اثر چنان آمیخته است که خواننده باریدن ماهی ساردین از آسمان را چون اتفاقی طبیعی قلمداد کرده و به ادامه رمان می پردازد. این اثر سرشار از استعاره و اسطوره، سیر داستانی بسیار گیرایی نیز دارد که خواننده به سختی می تواند کتاب را کنار بگذارد. قسمتی از کتاب:هر یک از ما چیزی را از دست میدهیم که برایمان عزیز است، این قسمتی از چیزی است که به آن می گویند زنده بودن. اما در درون کله ی ما جای کمی است که این خاطرات را در آن بیانباریم. اتاقی با قفسه هایی نظیر این کتابخانه و برای فهم کارکرد قلبمان باید مثل کتابخانه فیش درست کنیم، بگذاریم هوای تازه وارد شود و آب گلدان های گل را عوض کنیم. . به عبارت دیگر همیشه در کتابخانه ی خصوصی خودت بسر می بری...حال محض پیشروی گذشته ای دست نیافتنی است که آینده را می بلعد. در حقیقت هر احساسی اکنون خاطره است.

Kafka on the Shore is in many ways a typical Murakami novel. It contains parallel narratives, long philosophical passages (mostly in a form of monologues and dialogues), warped time, numerous music and literature references, talking cats and dream sequences. Not to say that if you have read one Murakami novel, you have read them all, for I find them all worthy in their own way. Nevertheless, it is worth noting that this writer does employ an unique and recognizable writing style that might feel repetitive to some. Once you have read quite a bit of Murakami, it will be easy for you to notice distinct patterns in his writing. Not that I'm complaining. I've been a fan of his writing for years. I find his prose mesmerizing and powerful and only occasionally a bit repetitive and overwhelming. I would say that my feelings for Murakami's writing are similar to what I feel towards cats and coffee- an intense liking. You could say that his novels are something I can never get enough of. I don't care if his plot are sometimes clumsy, convenient or/and illogical (not referring to surreal elements obviously, I don't expect logic from that, just from the regular parts), because you know his books would be worth reading for those wonderfully philosophical passages alone. If there weren't for the philosophy and wisdom that can be found in them, his books would be worth reading just for the lyrical prose or the brilliant culture references. What I'm trying to say is that one can really learn a thing or two by reading his books. I get that Murakami is not everyone's cup of tea, though. If you like high paced novels filled with active protagonists, without digressions but with logical plots twists and written in a simple narrative style, well then Murakami is NOT for you. I'm a reader that loves ambiguity but I must admit that Murakami's ambiguity is at times a bit too much even for me. I don't see how someone who hates ambiguity and magic realism could like him at all.  I borrowed Kafka on the Shore from the library yesterday and read it in one setting. I found it absolutely mesmerizing and have basically eaten both lunch and dinner with a book in hand. What makes this novel different from the other Murakami's books I read? Hm, there seems to be more of a Oedipus motif in this one. Incest is a big part of this novel and even if it is not certain has it really happened or not (much of it remains a mystery), it is definitely present. If that particular subject is something you can't bear yourself to read about, this is not a book for you. Sexuality is definitely a part of Murakami's writing, but in this one there is more of a focus on the Oedipus complex (albeit it is not the central theme). In addition, this novel has a number of references to Greek tragedies. Now, references to Western literature are always present in Murakami's writing, but I don't recall the Greek tragedies being as important to other novels as they were for this one. Coming back to the Oedipus myth, I found this passage from an interview with Murakami very interesting because he seems to say that the Oedipus myth was not something he had in mind when he set to writing:What made you want to retell the Oedipus myth? Did you have a plan to do this when you started Kafka On The Shore or did it come about during the writing?The Oedipus myth is just one of several motifs and isn’t necessarily the central element in the novel. From the start I planned to write about about a fifteen-year-old boy who runs away from his sinister father and sets off on a journey in search of his mother. This naturally linked up with the Oedipus myth. But as I recall, I didn’t have that myth in mind at the beginning. Myths are the prototype for all stories. When we write a story on our own it can’t help but link up with all sorts of myths. Myths are like a reservoir containing every story there is.I do believe that Murakami didn't plan to write another Oedipus myth, but it is hard to escape the similarities both plot wise and style wise. Whether we like it or not, our sexual development from a psychological perspective is always under the influence of parental figures. The Oedipus complex is just a normal phase of a child's development, or so the psychologist say. It is not a disease or a disorder, it's just a phase. However, when a child lacks a parental figure or has issues with it (as our protagonist does), then things get more complicated. What I want to say is that while Murakami's writing does expand to this myth, it is also because myths are a big part of who we are as humans and as such reflect our psychological and emotional being. The whole Oedipus motif isn't perhaps central to this novel but it is an important part of it as are the themes of growing up, sexuality, isolation and so on. Isolation and individuality are perhaps more important as motifs then the Oedipus complex, but perhaps we could say that they all tie together. How to keep one's individuality but still develop meaningful relationships? How to let go of past tragedies and keep one's sanity in this crazy violent world? How to escape isolation in the modern world? Those are the questions that I feel this novel asks and perhaps even tries to answer. The protagonist of this novel is named after Kafka (or rather named himself after Kafka). Murakami admits to his love for this author. However, Murakami never tries to copy Kafka and that's something worth acknowledging. There are references to Kafka's works but also to other works of literature so if you're expecting this book to be all about Kafka, it is not. There is so much more I could say about this novel, but my goodreads review has to end sooner or later and this seems as a good place to end it as any (I will probably publish a longer version on my blog).  What follows is another passage from Murakami's interview that caught my eye:...Before “postmodernism” became a buzzword, Franz Kafka explored that particular condition of isolation associated with a post-nuclear, new-millennium world. Did you name your protagonist after him to draw out these themes, or were there other reasons?It goes without saying that Kafka is one of my very favorite writers. But I don’t think my novels or characters are directly influenced by him. What I mean is, Kafka’s fictional world is already so complete that trying to follow in his steps is not just pointless, but quite risky, too. What I see myself doing, rather, is writing novels where, in my own way, I dismantle the fictional world of Kafka that itself dismantled the existing novelistic system. One could view this as a kind of homage to Kafka, I suppose. To tell the truth, I don’t really have a firm grasp of what’s meant by postmodernism, but I do have the sense that what I’m trying to do is slightly different. At any rate, what I’d like to be is a unique writer who’s different from everybody else. I want to be a writer who tells stories unlike other writers’.*SOURCE FOR THE INTERVIEW WITH MURAKAMI THAT I QUOTED: http://www.harukimurakami.com/q_and_a...

First, let me try and put it in simple terms. This book from the beginning to the end just had me going "What the actual F***??" In complicated terms (still simple, I'm just going with the rhythm here). this book left my brain muddled, making me rethink the whole existence of my life, looking back to see what is reality and what is not. All in all it just left me as a pile of confused goo. goo because I cannot think of anything else to describe myself. I am as attractive as a pile of goo but now I am a confused one to add to it. Imagine me as the emjoi with a question mark above it. Enough of this, now to the review.Although I have reading for the majority of my life, this year was the year I finally picked up Haruki Murakami. Mostly due to the fact that I had a weird sense where I wanted to start with Norwegian Wood and I could not find a decent copy anywhere until recently. Finally I did and as most of the Murakami fans, I was left with a certain befuddled sense of satisfaction at the end of the book. That is the best way I can explain all of the times that I finished a Murakami book. It is without doubt that during any translation much of the essence of the book is lost in it. Thus I am always skeptical of translations. Many translators try their best to give it to us as it is but sometimes it is just lost. Still Murakami's books manages to shine through. the certain warped yet straight forward aspect of Murakami's writings always manages to shine through in the translations. Murakami's books are never the normal sort of book you would pick. It is the type of book that you should pick up when you know you have enough time to thoroughly enjoy it, without any interuptions because in my opinion, Murakami has that innate ability to pick his readers up and transport them to the other world where no one is quite sure how they got there. In a certain aspect I do not think even our characters know how they got there, better yet I don't think Murakami knowa either. This in a way seemed to be the running theme in Kafka on The Shore. Every chapter just made the story more tangled than really giving a certain sense of conclusion. I am still trying to wrap my brain around the fact of what is the actual plot of the story, what was the meaning of all the events and like I said in the beginning, more than anything I feel as if I am trapped in a limbo where I cannot figure if I am living a dream or if this is all reality. This my friend, was the moment that I knew Murakami is true genius in a weird convulated way, but a genius nonetheless. At least in my eyes. Truth be told by the end of the novel, I was left with a headache, partly by too much reading and partly by the fact I forgot to blow dry my hair and I felt my nose clog reaching towards a headache at the end. Whatever the reasons were, this book left me with an addled brain. I felt as if everthing I knew was taken out of my brain and rearranged within. Which I still don't know if it was good or not. This by any chance does not mean I disliked the book. As a matter of fact it is quite the opposite or something in the middle. I loved it in the most weird manner but it was almost as if I was in a toxic yet addictive relationship. It gave me satisfaction but in the back of my mind I always wanted to leave it and at the end when I did, it felt rather good. The memories built during that time was worth the memories of a life time. So yes Mr. Murakami, you are forever going to be that toxic lover for me that I will keep going back to despite knowing that you will leave me with scars.

To date I've read 13 books by Haruki Murakami in translation. I find his works to be a mix of the passable, the very good, and the mediocre. Kafka on the Shore belongs squarely to the last category. I was unimpressed by this long novel about incest, animal cruelty, music, destiny, and growing up. The translation by Philip Gabriel reads well but Murakami comes across as an minor writer, a mere crowd-pleaser. The repetitions of sentences and phrases are irritating. Granted that repetitions are used to imitate a piece of music, the flat Hemingway-esque prose can't save it from sounding contrived and didactic. The title refers both to a musical composition and a painting. But references to these art forms cannot help this piece of fiction approach the level of a good read. The plot just plods along, the disparate themes woven into a pointless puzzle. The puzzle is laid on a Scrabble board, the pieces being letter tiles sharply cut at the edges. There's no challenge to deciphering it, no net benefit to be had. His novel Norwegian Wood is, I think, more worthwhile pointlessness than this. The novel is, moreover, a poor example of a "magical realist" novel as magic here is utilized without "logic." My benchmarks for a good magical novel are One Hundred Years of Solitude, where fantastical elements are tightly integrated into the story, and The Literary Conference by César Aira, where magic is uncontrollable, wreaking havoc as it escapes from the grasp of the writer. The magic of Murakami is neither mysterious nor crude. It is just plain dry old magic. A multitude of fishes falls from the sky, period. Leeches fall from the sky, period. The surreal worlding of magic and mystery is here not to be accepted as inevitable but unbelievable. Very unlike the stifling nightmare world of its namesake writer Kafka, or the logical labyrinths of a Borges, or even the sustained suspension of disbelief in Murakami’s own A Wild Sheep Chase. The magic of Kafka on the Shore is without flair or drama. In its pure form, wry and deadpan, magic redounds to an unintended humor. Finally, the novel suffers from overkill: too much explanation trying to “justify” the incest, too much self-help crap undermining the characters’ consciousness. This self-help streak is prefigured in Dance Dance Dance but reached a young adult fever-pitch here. Save for some interesting scenes with the old man Nakata, the book is otherwise overrated.

Yesterday, today, tomorrow - they'd all blur into one. Like an anchorless ship, time floats aimlessly across the broad sea.3.5* to the author Murakami on what was my first Japanese novel. Reflecting back on the book has provided me with mixed feelings. The story was strange and confusing and parts didn't make sense, however the book is a beautiful and melodious read.Kafka On The Shore has a very philosophical feel to it due to the protagonist's character. Kafka is an adolescent with the world on his shoulders, every thought pondered, every action has the consequence considered. In terms of thought pattern alone, I felt really connected to Kafka.The story itself is appealing from the start, there's a sense of mystery for each story within. The issue was tying all of it together and satisfying the reader with the outcome. Although it was an enjoyable read, this was purely down to the authors writing skills and not the story itself.Murakami toys with the past, the present, the reality and even the astral plane, it's all considered and connected. The irony stems from the fact that every character within the book appears to be independent and disconnected from everyone around them.To summarise, the book highlights challenges we all come across in life as we develop as individuals and does so in a relatable way. That being said, the story has some very strange parts which I couldn't really get my head around.If any of you fellow Goodreads friends have read any Murakami/Japanese novels, what was it like?Thanks for reading

Murakami's novels are always a little hard to get through, because they are rather long, and more often than not, very little actually happens throughout them. They are full of a myriad of tedious details, illogical plot twists, and unbelievable happenings. However despite all of this, I find them to be amazing novels that affect me on a level very different than the average book. Kafka on the Shore was no exception, and listening to it in audiobook form only helped to enhance the experience.I feel that Murakami takes a combination of both a Shinto and Zen experience, and spins it into a tangible form. The large amount of detail used to describe the scenes, settings, and actions of the characters creates an amazing sense of reality. It's almost as if the plot and the things that the characters learn are inconsequential, while the experience and sense of the present is of utmost importance. I'm not sure exactly how to relate the hypnotic spell that Murakami weaves, but the temperature, quality, smell, sense, and taste of the world we live in is reflected in his writing. It's as if the book presents all of these mundane details so that they can be noted, experienced, and appreciated.I'm not sure if anyone else gets the same thing out of his writing. It is a bit weird, quirky, and sometimes even disturbing. Not everything is meant to be taken logically in the book. Plot, characters, and themes don't always play out in a logical fashion, but I think the everything is meant to be taken in a more spiritual, less causual sense.

My third Murakami and it becomes clear that he always falls back on almost the same ingredients: main characters that are like unwritten sheets, they become involved in mysterious, often surreal events and go on a quest, in a environment with magic realistic elements; also many references to western high culture and to Japanese culture, a few sadistic scenes and regularly explicit sex, and finally also a very floating, natural style (like running water, I wrote earlier). It remains a compelling mix but in this novel the chemistry doesn’t really work. First of all, the pace is very slow: only after the middle of the book (after 300 pages!) the story picks up pace; Murakami occasionally fits in beautiful philosophical considerations, but in the end he does little with them; also the whole intrigue bogs down a bit especially because of some strange passages that seem to have no function whatsoever (the cruel cat killer for instance). In short, it still is fun to wonder around in Murakami land, but this book does not reach the level of the previous ones. (2.5 stars)

Il primo libro che ho letto di Murakami è stato, pochi mesi fa, L'incolore Tazaki Tsukuru e i suoi anni di pellegrinaggio, il secondo è questo. Ho voluto dargli una chance, perché non capivo il motivo per cui un autore tanto apprezzato da molti a me desse quasi fastidio. Del precedente ero stata irritata da tante domande che non trovavano risposte, da personaggi che spuntavano dal nulla per poi scomparire senza spiegazione e da un viaggio interiore troppo lento e assurdo. Tutti questi elementi sono presenti anche in questo romanzo e per gli stessi motivi mi è piaciuto! Eh sì. Anche in questo percorso di formazione ci sono dei personaggi assurdi e i protagonisti compiono azioni altrettanto illogiche, ma questa volta si giustifica tutto in un ambito onirico (la parola più usata da tutti per questo libro, ma azzeccata).Il linguaggio è lieve e delicato e la storia incuriosisce.Un ottima lettura.

Metaphor. The whole book is a metaphor. For what? You decide. Love, loss, music, beauty. Life. It reads like a journey to self, and away from self, and back to self again, seen through the eyes of a 15-year-old boy. It’s almost like a melody, like Beethoven’s Moonlight in C Minor, only written with words. There are no explanations to the strange and forbidden and at times bloody things that happen to Kafka, the boy who leaves home to find home and finds himself instead, him, his body and his mind, the only home he’ll ever get. There is the life of an elderly man who is not very smart, the man who can talk to cats, the man whose path crosses with that of Kafka. There are murders, horrific scenes of things torn apart, things you know, things that will scare you, and things you can’t imagine. And woods, dark scary woods. And ghosts. And cats, of course. And plenty of cooking dinners and eating udon noodles and discussing beautiful music and books and libraries and chirping birds and murders, bizarre murders that leave you in the dark until you see that it’s all a metaphor, a play on Oedipus complex. The boy. His mother. His jealousy. His father. His sister. I was wondering what kept me glued to this book. Nothing much happens there, really, not in the sense of urgent things like crazy chases or horrifying antagonists pursuing characters with sharp shiny knives. The pace is slow, rather leisurely, and yet it grips you and holds you in the throes of what life is about. Confusion. Feelings. Thoughts. Search for love. For good. For meaning. Any kind of meaning. And then the understanding that there is no meaning to any of it. Only what we make of it, out of fear. I must say, the book is a delight because it’s the only one I’ve read that is narrated in first, second, and third person. A treat for any writer to read and study. You’ll find fantasy here, and magical realism, too. A touch of horror. Suspense. Sly quiet humor. And lots of sexuality, tender and violent and taboo. Beautiful. Read it. It reads like music.

أجواء غرائبية وعجيبة في هذه الرواية، تجربتي الأولى مع موراكامي وبالتأكيد لن تكون الأخيرة.لا أعرف لما تأخرت كل هذا الوقت لقراءة هذه التحفة، لكن لابد ان هذا الوقت كان الوقت المثالي لقرائتها، لو قرأتها في وقت آخر انا متأكدة بانها لم تكن لتعجبني، او لم أكن لأفهمها.بالتحدث عن فهمها لا أستطيع أن أقول اني فهمتها بالكام�� بالتاكيد، شيء واحد واحد عليك أن تعرفه عن هذه الرواية، لا تحاول التفكير بمنطقية، فقط اقرا واربط الاحداث وضع نظريات كما تشاء، لكن لا تبحث عن المنطق، فانت بالتاكيد لن تجده هنا.قص��ان متوازيتان، تلتقيان بطريقة غير متوقعة، ناكاتا الرجل العجوز الذي فقد قدرته على القراءة في عمر التاسعة، ناكاتا لا يقرأ، ناكاتا غبي، ناكاتا يتحدث مع القطط، خلال بحثه عن القطة الضائعة جوما، يتقاطع طريقه مع طريق جوني واكر، ومن هذه اللحظة يتغير ناكاتا فيصحبنا في رحلة عجيبة، لفتح حجر المدخل بصحبة هوشينو.كافكا تامورا، أقوى صبي في الخامسة عشر في العالم، عاش في لعنة أبيه، لكنه لن يبقى، سيهرب، يريد أن يهرب، أن يجد أمه وأخته، أن يعرف لم حرم من حنان هذا العالم، لم عاش في خوف، ما ذنبه، ما هي الحياة، وأسئلة كثيرة جنونية لا تحصى، لكن لن يستطيع صبي في الخامسة عشر أن ينجو في هذا العالم القاسي لوحده، فيأخذه القدر إلى مكتبة كواميورا حيث يلتقي أوشيما، والآنسة سايكيي، وهنا حيث ستبدأ الأحداث في أخذ مجرى غير متوقع، مجرى جنوني، لن تستطيع التوقف عن القراءة.ما هي الحياة؟ هل هي الذكريات؟ هل هي المستقبل؟ أم الحاضر؟هل هي الزمن؟هل الذكريات مهمة؟ هل أنت ستبقى أنت دون ذكرياتك؟ هل أنا سأكون أنا دون ذكرياتي؟رواية عميقة وجنونية بالتأكيد لا تمت للمنطق بصلة، لكن ستجد فيها أجواء دافئة وممتعة وغريبة

"Can nothingness increase?"Devastatingly beautiful, profound and affecting exploration on identity and compassion.Murakami writes of a hauntingly surreal inner reality of the human condition, evoking a sense of otherworldly beauty and anguish within a soul; infused with compelling philosophical questions, existential contemplation and search for self.This kept me completely transfixed; at times moved to tears, both by the sheer overwhelming pathos or by how closely the presented experiences touched.The unassumingly progressing story is carried by a cast of charming and amiable personalities, from interactions of astuteness and hilarity, to arresting moments of dejection and ferocity.This was my first (fully engaged) Murakami, and I am left profusely better for it. Grateful to have this to add to my list of all time favorites, and can't wait to get to experience more of Murakami's entirely entrancing perception.(Barrett's and Le Sueur's narrations were excellently expressive. And there's more immediate thoughts in the reading updates below.)._____Edit 31/08/2022: having read several more works from Murakami's oeuvre since, this still remains a lone shining star above all the rest of them. "Peak Murakami".

I went on a Murakami reading binge in 2009, and suddenly found myself hitting a wall. What I had started out loving started to overwhelm and suffocate me. I knew I needed a break from him for a while.I did take a break from the break to read 1Q84, which I really enjoyed. As I listened to the audiobook of this novel, I found myself wishing I'd read this prior to 1Q84. Some of the themes are the same, and I don't just mean the silly themes like cats and pasta and music, but shifting realities and not being sure about who you are on many levels. They seem more concise in this novel, and I think having this experience first would have made 1Q84 even better.I enjoyed the audio. The two narrators bring completely different feelings to the different sections, and the novel shifts back and forth between the narratives of Kafka and Nakata. I enjoyed the haven of the library and the very helpful librarian, but that might have been the only moment of reality in this book. ;)Murakami always sends me off to listen to music, not just by work but certain performances of a work. I spent the afternoon listening to the Archduke Trio (Beethoven) as performed by the "Million Dollar Trio." Great stuff.

On my second read, I loved it less. There is great inventiveness and whimsy of course. The story also derives much power from the way it mixes a mythic form of story telling with matter-of-fact depictions of modern life. But without the constant surprise that the book gave me on my first read, when so many things were unexpected, I began to notice that the story is empty of any human happenings that matter. I felt a little pushed-around as I read, rather than feeling that the story happened organically. I prefer After the Quake where the mystical happenings seemed to draw me into a new perspective on the 1995 Kobe earthquake rather than what I felt here--not connected with anything real about the world.

This book like many of the novels of Haruki Murakami is about a young man discovering about himself. This time it is through the eyes of a fifteen year old who has run away from his dad in the city of Tokyo to the small town of Takamatsu, where he spends his time at a local small private library where he meets Oshima who looks after him, and the owner of the library, Miss Saeki. This is the story of how he finds about the past, and discovers something magical.

I’m so sad I didn’t love this book as much as I thought I would. I really wanted to love it but for some reason I just couldn’t connect with the story and the characters felt shallow. I might just be in a Murakami-writing-style-reading-slump but this book felt so ugly
