Murakami: The Philospher of Fiction
This is my third Murakami book. This first was Norwegian Wood, followed by The Wind Up Bird Chronicle. I actually thought my Murakami days were done after the later mentioned, I really had finished with Murakamis style of writing and weird ambling metaphysical plots. However, after forgetting to bring a book whilst staying at a friend's house for a three day job in central London, I found this classic in my hands.I say 'classic' as this has already been dubbed one way before I ever even knew the author exsisted. Unfortunately this is my least favourite of the three I've read. This may be down to the fact I never actually picked this up with the intention to finish (a foolish thought, as any goodreads follower would know) and as such everything beyond the first twenty pages or so was a struggle. Keeping this short- seeing as there's only a couple of hundred reviews or so on this book already- I had only one major gripe with the book. I acknowledge Murakamis plots aren't meant to make sense in the traditional way. His novels read more as philosophical outings into various topics, mostly seen through the eyes of some paradoxically normal-yet-oh-so-weird character. That's what I loved about his previous novels and what made them very refreshing when first reading them. However, I always grasped the core message throughout these reads. This wasn't the case for Kafka on the Shore. It's obviously an adolescents journey to adulthood (with one Hell of an Oedipus complex inbetween), but also a discussion on politics, gender identity, mythology, conspiracy theories and mental health as well. None of these topics gel particularly well though, and at times it feels as though Murakami is trying to fit a character story within a statement, within a coded message, about contemporary society. The result being quite a rambling plot. Coupled with a few awkward sex scenes and some slightly off character interactions, this makes for a jarring read. Perhaps I wouldn't be saying this if were my first round with the author but it certainly didn't captivate my attention as the previous novels did. In other words, the fictional aspect of this story and cogs that fit together to make a fluid plot didn't really come together.So why the four stars? Because despite this problem, Murakami is a genius writer. This is an author who has even admitted he doesn't really hold meetings with himself and make up plots (Think JK Rowling, on a train, creating the world of Harry Potter) so much as he sits down and just starts writing whatever comes to his head. He is the ultimate off-hand author with a knack for connecting with people from different backgrounds all over the world, in subjects we can all understand, and as such his work utter reflects this nature. His stories ask for patience from his readers and a reflective, almost meditative outlook on life. Not to mention his complete rejection of any traditional beginning, middle and end, three-point structure (at least to some degree). He is the antithesis to what western writers and readers expect from an author. Instead of taking his readers on a classical Odysseus style journey, he makes contemplative stories that without the plot or fictional aspect, really could be notes from meditations by Marcus Aurelius. As such, I just feel Murakami missed the mark slightly with this one. That's it. Nothing more, nothing less. Considering this is a veteran author with many, many books under his belt, it's quite a surprise he doesn't have more misses than hits with the above described style of writing.But then it wouldn't be Haruki Murakami if that were the case.Put with your books under philosophy, not fiction.

6/5/2010 review:If you want to get swept away and really dive into a story, stop whatever you are doing and find a way to get your hands on a copy of this book. This is an excellent book. I am not a fast reader. I read relatively slowly and I always read each and every word, taking it all in (kind of like Kafka himself). I don't think that there is any other way to read this book. Every word is important. Every sentence means something. If you are someone who likes to get to it, this book might not be the one for you. You have to be someone who kind of doesn't mind hanging on and on and just going along for the ride. I could see how someone could get frustrated with this book. But not me. I loved every page. I loved EVERY character! I'm not sure that has ever happened before... I really, really love Kafka and Oshima and I LOVED Colonel Sanders and Hoshino. Okay, I loved every character. There were so many great lines in this book, I wish I marked them all down, but that can get distracting. But I did manage to underline these that I really loved:"Being really clean is sometimes the most important thing there is" (Kafka)"Oshima told me people can't be in two places at once, but I think it's possible. In fact, I'm sure of it. While people are alive, people can become ghosts." (Kafka)"I'm appearing here in human form, but I'm neither god nor Buddah. My heart works differently from humans' hearts because I don't have any feelings. That's what it means" (Colonel Sanders)"Listen up - there's no war that will end all wars" (Crow)I really got this book. I loved this book. I'm so glad that some very nice person was willing to translate this great book for English readers. Thank you!!!6/15/2014 review:Every time I read this book I go deeper into the story. This just may be my favorite book in the world. THIS time I really enjoyed and appreciated the characters of Hoshino, our unsung hero, and Colonel Sanders, our abstract concept. As always, I love Oshima. When I look at the cover of my edition, I see Oshima: serious, intelligent, introspective, compassionate, and mysterious, at least at first. The mystery of Oshima fades as the story is told, and by the end of the book, Oshima is our dearest friend. I think I first fell in love with this book because of what Kafka does: he runs away and goes to live in a little room in a small, private library. The library is peaceful, wonderful, quiet, unique, special. Oshima works there, and I want to know Oshima. I want him to talk to me everyday in the same way he talks to Kafka. I could listen to Oshima go on for hours. I never get tired of this book. I already feel like starting again from page one. I love it.6/22/2017: I never get tired of reading this book. I loved Hoshino so much this time.

42nd book of 2020.This Murakami is one of the ones I've been wanting to read since getting into him (previously it was this and The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle, review here), but I kept my promise of reading him in order of publication starting from the very beginning - I've fought my way here. Actually, fought makes it sound like it's been hard, it hasn't. It's been joyous. Kafka on the Shore has many words surrounding it, Messy, Inconclusive, Confusing, Weird, Boring...only some of which are true. Firstly, boring? I didn't think so, at all. Messy? Possibly, in a wonderfully scattered Slaughterhouse-Five kind of way: controlled messiness. Confusing? Well, that's Murakami, simple but also confusing, but that's why we keep reading. Weird? Of course. Inconclusive? That's an interesting one - because, yes.Things are tied up, but also not at all. There's a nice ending, in fact, one of my favourite new last lines from Murakami, but there's much still unclear. Even the central question of the novel is left as 'You already know the answer' to our protagonist, Kafka Tamura. We can guess, as readers, but we don't know - only Kafka does. In fact, there are several main characters and I wonder what was their purpose, or else where did they fit in the story? They did, somehow, but it is not overtly clear. Things are not overtly clear in this novel. Is it frustrating? No, oddly. At its heart is a runaway 15 year old and an Oedipus curse. I won't spoil anything. We've a sentient (possibly non-existent) crow, a lorry driver, an old man who can talk to cats, flutes made from the souls of cats, fish raining from the sky, leeches raining from the sky, a (magical?) stone, a philosophy student whore, Colonel Sanders the KFC guy (or is it?), WWII soldiers, un-aged, a cabin in a forest like some Kerouac scene, lots of music and books and Beethoven. A little bit of Radiohead. Sex, sure. A library. A cross-gender librarian. A UFO... There are two story-line strands that are seemingly unconnected and the whole novel is hinged on the feeling that somewhere and somehow these strands are inevitably coming closer and closer together and will meet at some climax. It's enough to keep us going, a spell. I can't say why I loved this book as I often can't with Murakami. I rate this below The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle, and maybe that is still even below Dance Dance Dance (review here). Not many people share my stance but I think the latter is still my favourite Murakami. So far. I don't have many left. I'm rushing towards the end, inevitably. But what happens when I get there?

امسال برای بار سوم خوندمش. نه چون رمان موردعلاقمه یا دوبارِ قبلی خیلی دوستش داشتم، بلکه به خاطر یه جور احساس دلتنگی. دلتنگی برای ورژنی از خودم که تو تجربه‌های قبلی خوانش این کتاب بودم و دلتنگی برای زمان از دست رفته‌ای که کیفیتش هرگز توی زندگی‌م تکرار نمی‌شه. این‌بار اما برخلاف دوبار قبلی خیلی دوستش داشتم و تونستم باهاش ارتباط برقرار کنم. لحظاتی بود که فکر می‌کردم «موراکامی» نابغه‌ست و این داستانْ معجونی از عناصر واقعی و فراواقعیه که با هم مخلوط شده‌ن و دنیای جادویی خیال‌گونه‌ای ساخته‌ن که خواننده رو درون خودش می‌کشه؛ و راستش، لحظاتی هم بود که فکر می‌کردم بیشتر از یه معجون جادویی با یه آش شله‌قلم‌کار طرفم که آشپز هر چی دستش اومده توش ریخته! ولی وقتی کتاب رو دستت می‌گیری و شروع می‌کنی به خوندن، داستان انقدر جذاب و پرکششه که چاره‌ای جز همراهی باهاش و پذیرفتن منطق و خصوصیات خاصش نداری! به همین خاطر، در نهایتْ معجونِ جادویی رو انتخاب می‌کنم.«کافکا در کرانه» تا زمانی که دست از خوندنش نکشیدید، مسحورتون می‌کنه! بعداز کلی فکر کردن راجع به معماهای کتاب و تلاش برای کنار هم گذاشتن سرنخ‌ها، بعد از تلاش برای سر درآوردن از همه چیز و درآوردن معنای تک‌تک اتفاقات و انواع فرضیه‌بافی‌ها و در نهایت افتادن به جون تعبیر و تفسیرهای موجود توی اینترنت و مواجه شدن با کلی فرضیه‌ی دیگه، می‌خوام معماها و سوالاتم رو رها کنم. به نظرم مهم نیست که دقیقن چه نوع ارتباطی بین «جانی واکر» و پدر کافکا وجود داره یا منظور «موراکامی» از فلوت ساخته‌شده از روح گربه‌ها چیه و … . چون برای لذت بردن از داستان دونستن جواب هیچ‌کدوم از اینا مهم نیست. این‌جا جهان موراکامیه؛ شخصیت‌ها همونی هستن که می‌گن و نشون می‌دن و درش اتفاقات عجیب‌وغریبی می‌افته که با منطق دنیایی که ما می‌شناسیم توجیه نمی‌شه.چیزی که درباره‌ی این کتاب برای من مهمه مسیریه که کافکا پشت سر می‌ذاره تا با واقعیت‌های گریزناپذیر زندگی‌ش مواجه بشه و مسئولیت‌شون رو بپذیره، حتا اگر انتخاب خودش نباشن. این کتاب درباره‌ی اهمیت قصه‌هاست توی توان ما آدم‌ها برای تاب‌آوردن زندگی. روایت متفاوتی از پسری ترک‌شده و دوست‌داشته‌نشده در بستر خانواده‌شه که مجبوره خودش به تنهایی آدم‌هاشو پیدا کنه و بهشون مرتبط بشه.نمی‌خوام توی این ریویو از نقاط ضعفی که درش دیدم بگم، چون این‌بار از خوندنش خیلی لذت بردم و انگار تمام مدت تو یه دنیای مه‌آلود اسرارآمیز پرسه می‌زدم و این برام کافی بود و چیزی اذیتم نکرد. بار اول و دوم ترغیب نشدم برم موراکامی بخونم اما این‌بار، چرا؛ احساس می‌کنم دلم مقدار بیشتری از ذهن عجیب موراکامی رو می‌خواد! فلذا اگه پیشنهادی برای دومین رمانی که می‌خوام از موراکامی بخونم دارین، ممنون می‌شم بگین.

Normally, I'm skeptical of the word metaphysical and how that word is often misused. In the case of Haruki Murakami's brilliant Kafka on the Shore, the word metaphysical correctly suits the overall mood and fancy of this novel. Murakami paints a surreal yet easily identifiable Japan in which a 15-year-old boy named Kafka is dead set on running away as fast as he can from a gruesome and hideous prophecy - he ends up on a seaside town far from his Tokyo home - all the while looking for the mother and sister he never knew. Meanwhile, an illiterate simpleton named Nakata, who has the uncanny ability to speak with cats, is suddenly drawn against his will towards Kafka. Much like the works of Franz Kafka - and the use of the name "Kafka" in this novel is by no means coincidental - Murakami places his characters in situations that are far beyond their control, for reasons they can't fathom or understand. The metaphysical odyssey both Kafka and Nakata undertake is rife with strange occurrences: fish falling from the sky, a quest for a specific entrance rock, an apparition posing as a pimp disguised as Colonel Sanders, 2 soldiers who went AWOL during WWII and yet are still alive and hiding in a forest, just to name a few. Yet none of these occurrences will have you questioning the implausibility of it all; Murakami weaves a magical, tender, bittersweet, often gruesome, ultimately very funny tale of the hidden things outside of our understanding that sometimes take control of us. This was my first venture into the works of Haruki Murakami, and it won't be the last. I now have a new favorite author, and I consider myself very privileged to have read the great master. Kafka on the Shore is easily one of the best novels I've read, and it's quickly assumed a high position as one of my favorites.

تا الان 3 مجموعه داستان و 2 رمان از موراکامی خوانده ام که اگر قرار باشد به ترتیب علاقه مرتب کنم، کافکا در کرانه-کتابی که آن را اکثرا شاهکار موراکامی می دانند- در آخر قرار میدهم. + تعلیق بسیار قوی ست و اتفاقات کاملا غیرقابل پیش بینی.+ موراکامی نویسنده مورد علاقه من است پس با وسواس سراغ این شاهکار رفتم و هیچ عجله ای برای تمام کردنش نداشتم. سعی کردم جوری بخوانم که ذره ذره اش را زیر زبان حس کنم و از آن لذت ببرم،‌ پس از حجم بالای کتاب شکایت�� ندارم.+ داستان پر است از استعاره، کنایه و اشاراتی به اسطوره ها که باعث شد حس کنم کتاب را تمام کرده ام در حالی که نیمی از مطلب را از دست دادم. بین ریویوهای گودریدز گشتم اما کسی از اشاراتش چیزی نگفته. در مقدمه کتاب مصاحبه ای دارد با موراکامی که در آنجا نویسنده توصیه میکند، به یکبار خواندن اکتفا نشود و فکر میکنم کلید درک و حل معماها همین بار دومِ خواندن باشد، پس دوباره یک روز میخوانمش.+ وقتی یک داستانی ژاپنی میخوانی یا انیمه میبینی باید اطلاعاتی داشته باشی از تناسخ، جهان موازی، روح ها و هیولاهای شرقی. فکر میکنم با این پیش زمینه فهمیدنشان کمی آسان تر شود.+ و دیگر این که، سانسور آثار موراکامی بسیار آزاردهنده است. لحنش گاهی کاملا آروتیک می شود و تو میدانی اینجا چیزهایی را نویسنده نوشته که تو نمیخوانی و نمیدانی و معما حل نمیشود. ای کاش توان و همتش را داشتم و با ترجمه انگلیسی می خواندم.

Kafka on the Shore: One of Murakami’s BestHoshino: You know, I'm not really big on reading and fancy words. I'm just getting by every day, and if I can work, eat, drink, maybe get laid, then I'm pretty happy. I don't know what the big deal is about this Murakami guy. People act like he's some kind of genius, but when I ask what his books are about, they can't explain it! Do you get it, Nakata?Nakata: I'm sorry, Mr. Hoshino, Nakata is not a very smart person and he doesn't understand difficult books. So I can't answer your question. But I do know lots of cats who are smarter and might be able to help you. Should I ask them?Hoshino: Cats? Ask them about Murakami? What's the point of that? Cats just like to do their own thing and skulk around at night. They couldn't care less about books or famous authors. Neither do I.I respect they way you live, Nakata. You're an interesting guy, different but I like that. And what's the point of discussing a book? Either you liked it or you didn't. That's all that matters.Nakata: I don't know about all that, but I do know Nakata loves to have a bowl of eel sometimes, that makes me very happy. Would you like to go have some eel together?Hoshino: I thought you'd never ask. Let's go.

وأخيراً أقرأ لهاروكي موراكامي سمعت كثيرا عن جنونه وها أنا ذا أقرأ أكثر الأعمال سيرالية في حياتي .الرواية تشبه الحلم أحداث غريبة لا منطقية الخط الفاصل بين الواقع والفانتازيا مفقود ،ولكن مع ذلك لم أستطع أن أترك الكتاب أنهيه في وقت قياسي وأسأل نفسي ماذا فعل بي كيف يستطيع أن يجذبني بهذه الطريقة العبقرية ،السرد عبقري لا شك مستفز لا شك أيضاً،لن أكذب وأقول بأنني قد فهمت ماذا حدث في الرواية بعض الأشياء استنتجتها وبعض الأشياء علمت بعض نظريات تفسرها ، هاروكي نفسه قد قال في لقاء سابق بأنه ليست كل الاحداث لها تفسير داخل الرواية وأنه قد ترك بعض الأمور لخيال القارئ . أنا سعيدة بهذا لأنه طالما كانت تستهويني الروايات ذات النهايات المفتوحة.جانب آخر أعجبني في الرواية هو حديث هاروكي الممتع عن الموسيقى وخاصة الكلاسيكية منها ،لدرجة أنني كنت أستمع لبعض المقطوعات التى ذكرها كسوناتا شوبرت وثلاثية ارشيدوق لبيتهوفن ولا أصدق أنني أصبحت أستمتع بالموسيقى الكلاسيكية كهوشينو تماما .أحببت كثيرا حوارات أوشيما وكافكا عن الكتب والفلسفة كانت رائعة .كتاب من أجمل ما قرأت وسأبدأ قريبا في عمل آخر لموراكامي💜💜

این طور که معلومه کم پیش میاد که اثری در سبک رئالیسم جادویی توجه من رو به خودش جلب کنه و خب، این کتاب هم در این سبک نوشته شده...کتاب با ماجرای سفر یک نوجوان پانزده ساله که سرنوشتش با اسطوره ادیپ پیوند می خوره آغاز می شه که طبق روال چنین ماجراهایی انتظار داریم طی اون به کشف و شهودی برسه. بعد با ملغمه ای از خطوط داستانی مختلف رو به رو هستیم که طی اون ها نویسنده ضمن استفاده از عنصر تخیل و به هم ریختن قواعد زمانی و مکانی، گذری هم به فرهنگ ژاپن و موسیقی و ادبیات می زنه و من تا آخر کتاب منتظر بودم این ماجراها با چفت و بست محکم تری به هم مربوط بشن، ولی همچنان سست و حتی گاهی اوقات بی ربط و اضافی باقی موندن...توی سیر خوندنم به بعضی از ایرادهای ترجمه هم اشاره کردم که گاهی با ممیزی قابل توجیه بودن و گاهی هم نبودن.

"هر يك از ما چيزي را از دست مي دهيم كه برايمان عزيز است. فرصت هاي از دست رفته، امكانات از دست رفته، احساساتي كه هرگز نمي توانيم برشان گردانيم. اين قسمتي از آن چيزي است كه به آن مي گويند زنده بودن."* حالا هر اتفاق معمولي و ساده برايم معني رمزآلود جذابي دارد، ميتوانم بيش از پيش غرق هزارتوي خاطراتم شوم، رنج اين گم شدن را به جان بخرم و همه نابخشودني ها را ببخشم.حالا با روياهايم مهربان ترم، چرا كه "مسئوليت از رويا آعاز مي شود" و واقعيت و رويا ارتباط دو سويه اي دارند انكارنشني.پس ٤ ستاره براي تو كافكاي عزيزم، يك ستاره ي باقيمانده بمونه توي جيبم براي وقتي كه دوباره خوندمت و دليل وجود بعضي توضيحات و شرح و بسط ها و اطلاعات اضافي رو فهميدم :)

ضجة غريبة سمعتها عن هذه الرواية الفلسفية الغير مفهومة و لا أعرف لماذا كل هذه المبالغة في الإعجاب بها . أحداث و ألغاز كثيرة غريبة لم يقدم لها الكاتب تفسير و مواقف لا تعرف إن كانت حقيقة أو أحلام و نهاية بدون أي مفاجآت. لكني في نفس الوقت لا أنكر روعة أسلوب هاروكي و خفة ظله الملفتة بالإضافة إلى قدر كبير من المعلومات في القصة سواء تاريخية أو فلسفية ، و في النهاية لا أنصح بقرأتها .

Ah, Murakami-san. I've quite liked some of your work, but the more surreal of your novels have always seemed to fall flat for me.Kafka on the Shore is perhaps the most surreal novel of his I've read, and it's trash. I'm sure that statement will ruffle some feathers, and I'm sure some will simply retort that I 'didn't get it', but in my opinion Kafka on the Shore is utter nonsense with very little substance and almost nothing beyond some unique imagery to make it a worthwhile endeavor to carve through its near-500 pages of bullshit.Reading Kafka on the Shore is like meeting an oddball at a party. A skinny fellow at the snack stand with dyed blue hair and wearing a smart blue blazer and tie, sipping a non-alcoholic selzer-water and eating fritos dipped in honey mustard. What a curious fellow, you think, he must be interesting! You chat him up about all manner of things; turns out he's actually a lepidopterist. Whoa, never met one of those before! He doesn't drink, nor use recreational drugs, because he believes they're poison and wants to keep his body and mind sharp. He has incredibly deep knowledge about things you've never even considered. His job is to manage inventories of cold film storage for classic TV shows, so he spends his days around golden age television cans and regales you with odd stories about Car 54 and Gunsmoke and how TV just ain't how it used to be. You take down his number and want to hang out with him to hear more about these things you've never thought about; to learn more about the dark corners of life experience you've never even considered.You hang out with this individual a few more times, learning more and more. But eventually, something starts to bother you. Beyond these oddball pursuits, you begin to get a sense that there's just not much there. You eventually learn he simply hates the taste of beer, and he actually does smoke marijuana every so often. He doesn't actually collect butterflies yet, though he is interested in the hobby. At the moment he just likes to read a lot of Nabokov and finds the hobby a fascinating affectation, so he seeks to emulate it. His vocation is not something he's actually passionate or romantic about—he simply works part time on contract at a warehouse that happens to store these classic TV film canisters, and he's caught a glimpse of them before.You realize he's just a guy. A regular dude. There's really not all that much special about him. He goes to work, he comes home, he pays his bills. The things he recognizes as being cool are pretty interesting, you admit, but he doesn't have such a deep, compelling knowledge of them after all.He has nothing to say beyond, "Hey man, check this out. Isn't this pretty cool?".That's Murakami's fiction to me.On the surface Murakami's work seems profound, different, fresh, compelling. But when you dig a bit deeper, there's very little actual substance there. Murakami's fiction is very light on story and humanity, and very heavy on imagery that doesn't actually say much at all. The more I read his stuff, the more I suspect he's an utter charlatan, carefully crafting his fiction so that what you're reading appears to be the tip of the iceberg when, in reality, it's a cardboard prop painted blue floating along on the sea, depthless.Writing fiction is a strange beast. In my experience, it feels almost like reverse-dreaming. Instead of sleeping and passively experiencing random imagery from your brain, you are drawing that imagery from your brain and putting it down in order to augment whatever story you're planning on telling. You're actively sorting through your own lived experience and pulling pieces from your subconscious to shape your story and your characters in a compelling, genuine manner. Murakami does this exceptionally well. He's completely honest with himself, and the imagery which seems to fascinate him is often quite enchanting. Often times the quirks he's depicting are enough to carry the scene, alone, and his workmanlike prose facilitates this perfectly by getting out of the way and letting the images take center stage.But there's just not much else there. Murakami is a poor storyteller. His characters are frequently flat and seem to make arbitrary, nonsensical decisions. Many of his novels feature contrived conflict that isn't really all that interesting, or (as is the case in Kafka), no conflict at all. His pacing is often too blown out because he needs to give himself such space to indulge in these episodes of wading into the odd imagery and scenarios he finds so fascinating. Further—and perhaps most egregious—at times he treats his fiction as if it's little more than an avenue from which to explore his fetishistic interests; eg. young girls' breasts, or being masturbated by your sister. If you're hitting me with your kinks, you better be saying something important with them. If you're not using them as a means to a storytelling end that's going to make your fiction more thematically impactful, then you're just engaging in literary masturbation. It's leaving me feeling dirty, like the writer is pulling a Louis C.K. and sitting in the corner jacking off and I'm standing there in the locked room, forced to watch.The more I read Murakami, the more it feels like his fiction is just a vehicle from which he imparts ideas he finds interesting. That's not a problem, really. The best writers also do this—George R.R. Martin cannot stop depicting romantic hearts stuck in cynical worlds, Ernest Hemingway is utterly entranced with the idea of death and how each mortal person and beast faces it, James Joyce is obsessed with Catholicism and Irish politics. What Murakami lacks, though, and what's so severely damaging to his work, is that there's no storytelling foundation on which all of this imagery might sit, rendering such imagery ultimately meaningless. Martin's characters are so human you'll swear they're standing right next to you, Hemingway's devastating plotting will break you for a full week, Joyce's prose and humor will make you feel the love and the passion of his characters' so deeply your chest cavity will burn with their fervor. Murakami, however, only has his imagery and not much else. His books are a set of really nice windows and skylights sitting on a lawn, with no house into which they might be installed. While they might have augmented a proper story enough to propel it into the realm of profundity, they have zero utility. Yeah, those are some great windows, but who the hell needs just a window? Alone, they're useless. Just like Murakami's imagery.Kafka on the Shore is a nonsensical story with vast pretentions of grandeur. Murakami gives us two empty vessels to follow; an angsty, horny teenager and a developmentally disabled old man. The teenager reads as if he's written to be intelligent and interesting, though I found him mostly petulant and boring. The old man was the more likable of the two, and his quirk was something I found endearing and interesting, but ultimately not much is done with it. The real problem is that neither of these characters have any concrete conflict driving them forward. There's very little forcing them to change, and so we meander through the plot with them, never fully invested in their struggles, never fully caring about who they are. Murakami hits you with some shit, sure—an incest fetish, some shocking depictions of violence against animals, and various bits of nonsense I find impossible to take seriously (building a magic flute, oh my!)—but without a concrete story to carry it along, it all felt meaningless and silly, like a Jackson Pollock, except it's just random house paint spilled on a driveway rather than something constructed on an actual canvas.If you enjoy the surreal and aren't a big stickler for, you know, actual storytelling? Maybe you'll like this book. I hated it and I'm eager to move on from it to something else.

I generally liked reading this. The tone is so straightforward, casual, goodnatured, stable, melancholic, with plenty of dramatization and long stretches of easy dialogue. At times it feels like young adult writing, albeit with regular instances of surprisingly descriptive sex, including non-consensual dream intercourse with someone who may be one's sister. The main ingredients include fantasy, detective story, ghost story, erotica, realism. Mentions common brands on one page and fantastic elements on the next, such as a talking cat or a stone that relates to parallel world where life and death and the past and present intertwine, inhabited by two WWII deserters and a woman with porcelain skin and a Mont Blanc pen who may or may not be the mother of the narrator of the sections in first person (it alternates between first and third), at times fifty years old, other times fifteen. Early on there are some official governmental-type interviews about a mysterious aerial event that knocked a bunch of children out, including the illiterate star of the third-person sections. I am otherwise incapable/unwilling to summarize everything in this. “It has a persistent, inward-moving spirit that’s filled with a pliant, youthful sort of curiosity.” That’s a line on page 329 about a Haydn piece that seemed self-referential, the only page I dogeared, although every once in a while there was a comment, usually about music, for example Coltrane's solo on My Favorite Things, that directly/obviously related to the novel, which I always like -- as a former English Lit major I suppose I look for those self-referential lines, which come in handy when writing papers in college or GR reviews these days. At times I thought it was shoddy, especially when I read it out loud to my wife upon her request just to read what I was reading and we both agreed the page or so I read was really clunky. I often found myself zoning out, daydreaming, which generously you could say is totally intentional, that Murakami tries to get you back on your heels as a reader, to sort of lower your guard and then once you're lulled/semi-hypnotized, suddenly you realize you've been reading about a ghost woman having sex with a fifteen year old or an old guy who seems sort of touched/special conversing with a cat. I sometimes felt like I had missed transitions or had somehow skipped some pages, the borders between worlds often seeped without me noticing until later, in part because my reading wasn't always super-attentive and immersive -- and again, generously, I feel like this is engineered to a degree and after a while it works its magic. The straightforward superficial aspects of the language, mixed with plentiful musical recommendations like the Archduke Trio and the aforementioned Haydn cello piece, easy dialogue, and well-processed genre melange made for a generally pleasurable reading experience, with enough philosophical and poetic moments/images to qualify as "literary." At first I was disappointed that I wasn't really all that into it but now that I'm done I'll read more Murakami in 2021, definitely, although won't attempt to achieve completism. It's good to know these books and these worlds are available, the way it's good to know that baseball, at least in the summer, is always available when you need it. It seems like it's not trying to do too much on any given page but then when you look back at the sweep of it it's impressive how much it's actually done and how completely it's amounted to its own thing. At first I rated this three stars to reflect my casual kinda disengaged enjoyment but now that I write about the book I've decided to knock my general admiration up to four-star-style respect.

"Hoću da se sjećaš mene. Ako se ti budeš sjećao mene, onda me nije briga ako me svi drugi zaborave."Ovako nešto može samo Murakami da napiše. Da ti zareže već postojeći ožiljak i napravi još veći. Kafka na obali mora je jedno magično putovanje u najveće dubine čovjekove duše, a vi ćete na kraju sami da birate ako se ikada želite vratiti u ovaj naš svijet.Napisano onako kako samo Murakami to može, ova knjiga je divan sklop moderne kulture, magičnog realizma, fantastično napisanih likova, čudnih trenutaka i filozofije. Kao slagalica koju silno pokušavate sastaviti, a uvijek vam fali onaj jedan dio. Knjiga koju će mnogo voljeti, ali koja će svima na kraju imati drugačiju poruku. Ovo je knjiga koja nema kraj. Ovo je knjiga koja počinje davno poslije kraja. Ova knjiga je dio duše koji ste ostavili u knjižari onog trenutka kada ste je uzeli sa police. Ova knjiga je vaša karta u spokoj.Prelijepa vista čudnih trenutaka koji svakom stranicom postaju sve zabavniji. Dva lika koja su tako upečatljivo unikatni. Dječak imena Kafka i starac imena Nakata koji ne zna da čita i piše, ali zato može da priča sa mačkama. Njihovi životi, način na koji su povezani ili nisu i svi ljudi koji prolaze kroz njihove živote. Prijateljstvo, ljubav, samoća, porodica i duh - sve ovo je samo površina ove knjige.Silovanje, incest i polovi, sve ovo izgubljeno u rukama magičnog realizma. Zaštićeno u magiji koja nikako neće dozvoliti da najgore stvari ove knjige okrenete protiv nje. I baš tu leži njena prgava prefinjenost. Onda na ovo sve dolazi jedna stranica knjige koja će još dugo ostati kao nešto što samo Murakami može da napiše. Trenutak u kom žena koja dok zadovoljava muškarca pokušava da objasni udvostručenu samosvijest kod Hegela. Erotično, realno i čudno. Opet, Murakami. Pročitajte ovo. Samo zbog toga što vrlo vjerovatno nikada ništa neće biti kao ovo. Kao iskustvo koje ćete imati dok budete čitali ovu knjigu. I zapamtite, ako vam u bilo kom trenutku nešto nije jasno, onda je to zato što tako upravo treba da bude. Snimio sam video na temu ove knjige, više detalja možete saznati tamo:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xy50Y...

First, the few things I didn't like about the book:1. Everyone talks like a philosopher, regardless of who they are. A truck driver delivers a lecture on capitalism and a prostitute literally delivers a philosophy lecture with a dick in her mouth. The book can sometimes approach self-parody. 2. A couple of chapters felt a little bit too much like wheel-spinning. For example: one of Hoshino's chapters near the end, where he basically just kills time so the rest of the plot can catch up. Now, the many, many things I loved about the book:1. If you want to read a myth that captures modern life, values, love and struggles the way say, a creation myth captured the ancient way of life, it doesn't get better than this book (And you may find that life isn't fundamentally different now than it was then).2. In an age where most stories are interchangeable and nearly-identical and boring, this one blazes with originality.3. You can reread this book a hundred times and still find new meanings and opinions.4. Almost all of the main characters feel like pleasant people that you'd want to hang out with. I especially would love a cup of coffee with Oshima.5. The imagery is as vivid as a painting. The prose has a beautifully poetic flow to it, which shouldn't be surprising considering this is a Murakami book. 6. Despite all the nuance and depth, the book is still structured like a mystery story, which manages to keep you coming back for more. 7. The book packs a huge emotional punch, and by the end you feel exhausted and elated at the same time. If you're reading it properly, it might even help you to get rid of some of your own demons.Conclusion: this isn't a perfect book, but it's certainly a magnificent one.

Warning: all characters are unusual and eccentric. Don't expect anything normal from them.Another wonderful book by Murakami. This book is more into magical realism and metaphysical theorizing as compared to The Windup Bird chronicles and Norwegian Wood - the other books of this author which I've read. Kafka, a 15 year old boy runs away from home, perhaps in search of his mother and sister, who deserted him when he was a mere boy of 4. His father seems cold natured and elusive. He has an imaginary companion, Crow, whose advice he follows in times of internal and external strife. Nakata is a brain damaged man who has the ability to talk with cats. One day he is forced to kill a man, who in turn is a cat torturer. Nakata is in search of something, which he himself doesn;t realize fully. He meets Hoshima, a truck driver, who soon becomes his friend. Meanwhile Kafka meets Oshima and Seiki, managers of a small, private, rural library, who give him place to stay. In the final third, all these characters come together, lots of mysterious and unexplainable things happen, and finally we are left with a sense of wonder and awe, though there is an incomplete feeling.I thoroughly enjoyed the prose, the ideas, the irony and the seemingly impossible events narrated so as to seem almost possible. It is the soothing prose and narrative style, not the story, that matters in Murakami books.

Ever read something that you half got and half was like WTF?This book is so weird but has some great moments, pacing at times is all over the shop and characters arent very likeable. I honestly nearly gave up at the cat killing scene as I found that part particularly disturbing but glad I powered through.I wasnt a fan of the way the book was written with it being about the two characters and how the pacing of the stories was offbeat with each other. Sometimes the Kafka storyline had me hooked waiting to find out what happened next whilst the Nakata story was really slow and vice versa.This is in no way a bad book its just weird and very surreal in places, I hated both the main characters where as in the previous Murakami books I could relate to them in some way these two to me didn't seem human.It might be that I am not in the right place to be able to understand if this book had a deeper meaning or what the author was trying to achieve so maybe I am being harsh on the book. It is one that I will try to re-visit in the future perhaps when I am not under so much stress and try to enjoy the book more. One thing is clear though after reading this I need to take a step back from Murakami for my next few books and come back to him with an open mind in a few weeks time.

Em boa verdade, não posso dizer ter compreendido alguma coisa do que se passou neste livro. Ao mesmo tempo, e estranhamente, devo dizer que mesmo achando a história um mistério completo - não conseguindo sequer aventar uma hipótese quanto ao que poderia significar - ainda assim foi uma leitura apaixonante. O meu consolo é que muitíssimas outras pessoas parecem estar no mesmo barco.Murakami tem um estilo de escrita leve e fácil de ler, salpicado com momentos de verdadeira inspiração. Em pouco tempo me teve agarrado ao livro com sede de saber onde me levaria este enredo. Tem outra grande qualidade: o mistério, que nem sempre é fácil de conseguir conferir a uma história. O enredo tem a curiosa particularidade de fazer sentido se se rejeitar qualquer preconceção de lógica, e ser completamente incompreensível aceitando-se que é uma alegoria. Algumas metáforas, aqui e ali, espalhadas no livro, foi possível ir-se compreendendo, mas quanto à alegoria que subjaz a trama geral, essa permanece uma completa incógnita. Talvez só releituras sucessivas deste livro permitam descortinar o verdadeiro significado que ele pode tomar para mim. A verdade é que, com ou sem significado, foi um verdadeiro prazer lê-lo.E uma coisa é certa: fiquei com vontade de meter as minhas mãos noutro Murakami.

Ik wist niet echt wat te verwachten van een boek met een titel als “Kafka op het strand”. Van Murakami las ik enkel al “Norwegian Wood” en “With the Beatles”, dus ik dacht dat dit meer van dat ging zijn. Toch is dit een heel ander boek dan die andere. Het “magisch realisme” die doorgaans in één adem genoemd wordt met deze auteur, komt hierin toch echt naar boven, en voor mij was dit een heel fijne nieuwe kennismaking. Van de 600+ pagina’s had ik er toch wel meer dan 100 nodig om in het verhaal te komen. Er zijn verschillende verhaallijnen die vrij snel aan bod komen, maar die me aanvankelijk wat in de war brachten. Toch wou ik steeds doorgaan, bleef ik nieuwsgierig en getriggerd, en genoot ik van de schrijfstijl. Ook de vele literaire en culturele verwijzingen waren voor mij een meerwaarde en maakten me enkel meer nieuwsgierig. Hier en daar verloor Murakami me wel even (o.a. bij de pratende katten), maar achteraf gezien hoort dit wel allemaal in dit boek, en heeft alles wel zijn nut, ook al is dit niet meteen duidelijk bij een eerste lezing.Ondanks het volume leest het zeer vlot en weten ook de personages je mee te voeren en te charmeren. Na de laatste pagina moet dit boek toch even bezinken, en heb ik het gevoel dat ik niet alles meeheb wat erin zit. Ooit dus nog eens herlezen, maar eerst nog de andere boeken van deze schrijver ontdekken.

Ήταν το πρώτο βιβλίο του Murakami που διάβασα και δεν είμαι σίγουρη αν έπρεπε να κάνω το πρώτο βήμα μ’ αυτό.Ναι,μου άρεσε που καταπιάστηκε με το μύθο του Οιδίποδα με τέτοιον τρόπο,που ξεπερνά το συνειδητό και τα όρια αυτού του κόσμου και απλώνει δίχτυα σε άλλες διαστάσεις.Πιστεύω πως μάλλον ο κόσμος αυτός δεν έφτανε για τον συγγραφέα.Τσεκ και για το εκπληκτικό ψυχογράφημα των χαρακτήρων.στα συν του βιβλίου,ότι υπήρχαν σημεία που φλέρταρε με το θρίλερ,μιας και το σκοτεινό δάσος είχε μια απόκοσμη ατμόσφαιρα.Όμως,με κούρασαν οι συνεχείς αναφορές στα μουσικά κολλήματα του συγγραφέα (Beethoven,Prince),που η αναφορά τους από ένα σημείο και μετά δεν προσέφερε τίποτα (νομιζω).Επίσης,ένοιωσα ότι το τέλος του,ανοιχτό σε ερμηνείες,είναι κάπως ασαφές,όχι για να αφεθεί ο αναγνώστης να βγάλει τα δικά του «πορίσματα»,αλλά είχε μια νότα επιτήδευσης.Μπορεί να ήταν και η ιδέα μου,βέβαια.Και έτσι,ένα βιβλίο από τα 4* πέφτει στα 3*.Πάντως,μου κίνησε το ενδιαφέρον ο Murakami και σίγουρα θα διαβάσω και άλλα βιβλία του.

“Memories warm you up from the inside. But they also tear you apart.”“Silence, I discover, is something you can actually hear.”“In everybody’s life there’s a point of no return. And in a very few cases, a point where you can’t go forward anymore. And when we reach that point, all we can do is quietly accept the fact. Kafka on the Shore is a tale of quests, a retelling of Oedipus, a story of the looping karmic cycle of life and death, and an utterly unique expression of Haruki Murakami's soul.Fifteen-year-old runaway Kafka Tamura has a boss named Oshima at his job in a private library. Oshima tells Kafka:"What you're experiencing now is the motif of many Greek tragedies. Man doesn't choose fate. Fate chooses man. That's the basic worldview of Greek drama. And the sense of tragedy—according to Aristotle—comes, ironically enough, not from the protagonist's weak points but from his good qualities. . . . irony deepens a person, helps them mature. It's the entrance to salvation on a higher plane, to a place where you can find a more universal kind of hope. . . . everything in life is metaphor. People don't usually kill their father and sleep with their mother, right? In other words, we accept irony through a device called metaphor. And through that we grow and become deeper human beings." (199–200)And later on, after Kafka sees a girl ghost who is a young version of the older woman who runs the library, he asks Oshima if it's possible that a living person can also exist as a ghost. And Oshima tells Kafka of such a story in The Tale of Genji, followed by this explanation:"The world of the grotesque is the darkness within us. Well before Freud and Jung shined a light on the workings of the subconscious, this correlation between darkness and our subconscious, these two forms of darkness, was obvious to people. It wasn't a metaphor, even. If you trace it back further, it wasn't even a correlation. Until Edison invented the electric light, most of the world was totally covered in darkness. The physical darkness outside and the inner darkness of the soul were mixed together, with no boundary separating the two. They were directly linked." (225)I think it's wonderful that Kafka on the Shore has found an audience of people who are not necessarily versed in Eastern spiritual traditions, shamanism and indigenous wisdom, or string theory. I marvel at the fact that Murakami seems to communicate to people of all kinds. But for me, his work is a modern-day classical expression of all of the former traditions. The literature of indigenous and Eastern traditions is filled with anecdotes of realized beings who often appear in more than one place simultaneously, helpers who drop into our world from other dimensions, people who lose their souls and retrieve them, others who reincarnate within a lifetime, and explanations about karmic packs of people who incarnate to work things out together. String theory (which I don't pretend to understand scientifically, but whose broad concepts make sense to me) with its multiverses (parallel universes) explains such phenomena, delineating connections that are beyond our normal time-space construct.Briefly, Kafka on the Shore is the story of two people's instinct-driven pilgrimages (similar to walkabouts). The main characters are a fifteen-year-old run-away boy who names himself Kafka (Crow in Czech), and an old man named Nakata who became dumb (or "hollow") after a bizarre happening that left him in a coma when he was a child. Also playing important roles are Kafka and Nakata's respective helpers, Oshima and Hoshino. Add to that a delightful cast of subsidiary characters including Johnnie Walker (a cat-killer/famous sculptor), Colonel Sanders who talks about time warps and living in three dimensions versus other ways of living, and a magnificent philosopher prostitute whose casual conversation includes her thoughts on consciousness: "Hegel believed that a person is not merely conscious of self and objects as separate entities, but through the projection of the self via the mediation of the object is volitionally able to gain a deeper understanding of the self. All of which constitutes self-consciousness." (274)The book is a stunning, romantic construction—a meditation metaphor—weaving the threads of converging, merging, and separating lives from different times and spaces into a fabric of oneness, acceptance, and forgiveness. Both Kafka and Nakata have a dedication to meticulous personal and housekeeping cleanliness, and this same cleanliness characterizes Murakami's style. His clean, simple sentences both seduce and kind of mesmerize you—perhaps explaining why readers who have none of the aforementioned foundation can enjoy and feel the truth of the book without completely understanding it. The style is so simple, yet through the simplicity, Murakami creates the most complex story about the true nature of existence. ". . . there's a spot they call the Toilet Bowl [says Oshima's surfer brother as he conveys Kafka home after his pilgrimage]. There're these huge whirlpools because it's where the incoming and outgoing tides meet and crash into each other. It goes around and around like when you flush a toilet. If you wipe out there, you get pulled underwater and it's harder to float up again. Depending on the waves you might never make it back to the surface. So there you are, underwater, pounded by the waves and there's nothing you can do. Flailing around's not gonna get you anywhere. You'll just use up your energy. You've never been so scared in your life. But unless you get over that fear you'll never be a real surfer. You have to face death, get to really know it, then overcome it. When you're down in that whirlpool you start thinking about all kinds of things. It's like you get to be friends with death, have a heart-to-heart talk with it." (460)[This review also appears on my Notes from a Crusty Seeker blog with an introduction about my personal interest in this subject.]

The overall experience of this book was so satisfying for me. We can’t forget about the writing style loved it!! The characters kept talking about a lot of life’s things which I found amusing.

از تخیل می‌ترسی. حتی بیشتر از آن از رویاها. از مسئولیتی که با رویاها شروع می‌شود می‌ترسی. اما ناچاری بخوابی و رویا هم جزو خواب است. بیدار که شدی، می‌توانی تخیل را سرکوب کنی. اما رویا را که نمی‌شود سرکوب کرد. خوندن کافکا در کرانه، مثل قدم زدم داخل یک هزارتوی پر رمز و رازه...اصلا باز کردنش مثل قدم گذاشتن داخل این هزارتوئه...نمیدونی پشت هر دیوار چه جادویی منتظرته، پشت هر پیچ چه چیزی قراره حیرت زدهت کنه... پره از پیچیدگی... پره از سوال و سردرگمی...اما نکته اینجاست که وقتی تو هزارتوی این کتاب قدم میزنی، دنبال مرکز هزارتو نیستی... سردرگم پیدا کردن راه نیستی، کتاب تو رو جلو می‌بره و تو از این مسیر لذت میبری...این همه پیچش و خمشِ قصه، کم کم تو رو درگیر خودش می‌کنه و همراه خودش میکشه...موراکامی قصه گوی خیلی خوبیه و همین باعث میشه توی این قصه‌ی طولانی و لایه لایه، توی این هزارتوی تو در تو، راهت رو پیدا کنی و گم نشی... و باز همین هنرش باعث میشه از روند همزمان دوتا قصه که معلوم نیست ممکنه به یک جا و یک نقطه ختم بشن یا نشن، خسته نشی و ادامه بدی...من دوست داشتم این همه سوال، این همه استعاره و نماد پردازی رو، این همه حرفای فلسفی رو... این همه فرو رفتن تو عمق و به سطح رسیدن رو... ولی منصفانه اگه بخوام بگم یکم طولانی بود...طولانی بودنش مانع از این نشد که من دوبار پشت سر هم این کتاب رو نخونم... ولی کندم کرد...چه بار اول، که به انگلیسی خوندمش و چه بار دوم که ترجمه رو خوندم، هر دفعه کند پیش رفتم...این قصه از اون قصه‌ها نبود که من توش ذوب بشم... ولی به عنوان یه ناظر خارجی، از همه‌چیز لذت بردم...از تمام شخصیت‌ها، از استعاره‌ها، از تمام سردرگمی‌ها... از تمام سوال‌هایی که برام بی‌جواب موندن... شخصیت ناکاتا برام خاص بود، و کافکا با تمام پیچدگی‌هاش برام قابل درک بود... من، قدم زدن توی جنگل رو حس کردم، پسرزاغی‌نام رو حس کردم... میس سائه‌کی رو با چشمای خودم دیدم... اوشیما رو دوست داشتم...خوندن کافکا در کرانه، فقط خوندن یه کتاب نیست... لذت یه موسیقی زیبا و تماشای یه تصویر آشناست... یه لذت چند برابر...همین.پ.ن: دوتا نکته درمورد کتاب ترجمه خوندن و ترجمه، اول این‌که، ترجمه از یک زبان به زبان دیگه بخشی از هویت اصلی کتاب رو ازش میگیره و هویت مترجم رو بهش اضافه می‌کنه، وقتی از زبان دوم به زبان سومی ترجمه میشه، هویت مترجم دیگه‌ای هم بهش اضافه میشه، و من حس می‌کنم کافکا در کرانه‌ی انگلیسی کتاب متفاوتی بود نسبت به فارسی؛ و اما نکته دوم، دو دسته مترجم داریم، اونایی که تلاش می‌کنن تا جا داره چیزی رو از قصه حذف نکنن و اونایی که اصلا تلاشی نمی‌کنن، فقط به دلخواه حذف می‌کنن... متاسفانه به نظر میاد مترجم این کتاب از دسته‌ی دوم باشه...شانزده شهریور نود و پنج06 September 2016

رواية كافكا على الشاطيء للمؤلف الياباني هاريوكي موراكامي من الروايات العالمية التي تم ترجمتها للغات عديدة منها الإنجليزية والعربية. وقد وفقت سابقا لقراءة روايتين للمؤلف وهي اي كيو 84 و رواية ما بعد الظلام وكلتاهما على مستوى عال من الإبداع والخيال. وتدور أحداث رواية كافكا على الشاطيء عن ولد يسمى كافكا يهرب من منزل أبيه ويلجأ إلى مكتبة يعمل فيها ويشبع فيها حبه للقراءة و عن رجل مسن يسمى ناكاتا فقد ذاكرته وهو صغير ولكنه يستطيع أن يجعل السماء تمطر سمكا وعلقا كما يمكنه الحديث مع القططً. لدى هاذين الشخصين القدرة على الانتقال من الخيال إلى الواقع والعكس صحيح . الرواية تدور حول عقدة أوديب حيث تتحول أمنية الولد في قتل أبيه إلى حقيقة وذلك انتقاماً لهروب أمه وأخته من البيت وتركه لوحده مع الأب القاسي . ويصل كافكا في نهاية الأمر الى التصالح مع نفسه وفهم ذاته والآخرين بصورة أفضل. وتتخلل أحداث القصة الكثير من المفاجآت والأحداث المتتالية التي تدل على خيال المؤلف الواسع. كما يوظف المؤلف الثقافة الفنية المتعلقة بالموسيقى والرسم ��دعم القصة ويثري معلومات القارئ من جوانب متعددة. رواية رائعة بمعنى الكلمة ولكنها تحتاج إلى جهد وصبر لفهم معانيها الغامضة.قراءة ثانية للرواية بعد سنتين ربما .. كافكا على الشاطيء الشاطيء لبحر مخاوفه، قلقه، حزنه، تساؤلاته كافكا يريد أن يكون الشخص الأقوى لشدة شعوره بالضعف. يسعى من خلال هذه الرحلة الوصول لاجابة لتساؤلاته المتعلقة برحيل أمه واخته عنه عندما كان في الرابعة من عمره. يتعلم في نهاية الرحلة أن القوة هي القدرة على التسامح. النبوءة كانت رغبته في الانتقام من أبيه وأمه وأخته. ناكاتا الشخصية البريئة البسيطة والذي رغم جهله بالقراءة والكتابة إلا أنه قادر على أن يعلم الآخرين دروسا قيمة في الحياة قصة مس سايكو وصراعها مع الذكريات الحزينة وقدرتها على التخلص منها بالنسيان الفتحة ترمز الى صراع الانسان مع الماضي والأسرار القديمة المطمورة  المكتبة هي مهرب الانسان من أحزانه الماضية وفيها يفتح صفحة جديدة للمستقبل ربما كل القصة هي مجرد خيال كافكا منذ دخوله المكتبة حتى خروجه منها ..قراءة ثالثة لرواية في 2022 كافكا على الشاطئ للمؤلف المبدع هاروكي موراكامي. في كل مرة أقرأ الرواية أشعر وكأنها المرة الأولى. بطل الرواية الفتى كافكا الذي يهرب من بيت والده ويلجأ لمكتبة غريبة حيث تنكشف معاناته من عقدة أوديب. البطل الآخر هو العجوز ناكاتا الذي يعيش بنصف ظل، ويقدر على الحديث مع القطط ويأمر الغيوم بأن تهطل الأسماك والديدان. القصة تتضمن جوانب فلسفية ونفسية كثيرة، كالمعاناة والعزلة والتعلق بالماضي والصور النمطية. أوصي بقراءتها وتستحق خمس نجوم.

این صرفا تجربه و نقد من درباره این شاهکار نیست، بلکه تنها دل‌نوشته‌ی من هست............اگر بخواهم تنها از یک‌چیز نام ببرم که توانست مرا در طول تمام این شب‌های‌تاریک، بیدار نگه‌دارد، پاسخم نه یکی‌ در میان آمریکانو و موکا‌های گاه و بیگاه کافه‌ی نزدیک خانه‌ام، با آن ‌پلی‌لیست‌مزخرف‌ است که این اواخر تبدیل به یک ‌‌جور اعتیاد شده بود و نه هیچ چیز دیگری که‌بتوانم هم‌اکنون آن را به یاد آورم. پاسخم تنها و تنها یک‌ چیز است، "کافکا در کرانه"! اگر بخواهم کلی‌تر جواب این سوال را بدهم، کتاب‌های نویسنده‌ی محبوبم، این پیرمرد لعنتی، که هربار بیش‌ از پیش مرا با قلم جادویی‌اش مسحور و مبهوت خود می‌کند. هربار که می‌گویم: "من خودم را در داستا‌ن‌های موراکامی پیدا می‌کنم، نفس می‌کشم، زجر می‌کشم و زندگی می‌کنم"، خنده‌ام می‌گیرد! مگر می‌شود تا این حد همذات‌پنداری احمقانه؟ مگر می‌شود تا این حد غرق‌شدن در این دنیای موهومیِ لذت‌بخشِ فوق‌العاده؟ مگر می‌شود تا این حد دقیق، کلماتِ در ذهنم و جمله‌ها و نصیحت‌های خسته‌کننده‌ی دیگران به خودم، شبیه به جملات و نوشته‌های کتاب باشد؟!ای‌کاش می‌توانستم راز این همذات‌پنداریِ لعنتی، که یک سال‌تمام، مرا درگیر خودش‌کرده بفهمم، ای‌کاش می‌توانستم بفهمم که در ذهن عجیب‌غریب این پیرمردِ‌ لعنتی چه‌می‌گذرد! ای‌کاش می‌توانستم بفهمم و اگر این موضوع را می‌دانستم، هیچ نمی‌خواستم.کافکا در کرانه را درست همانند دیگر کتاب‌های این پیرمرد، در شرایطی‌خواندم که در وضعیتی‌کاملا نومیدانه به سر می‌بردم! شرایطی که دیگر برای من غریب نیست، به آن خو گرفته‌ام و دیگر آن را از خودم نمی‌رانم! شاید بهتر باشد برای تمام این فعل‌ها از زمان گذشته استفاده کنم! کافکا در کرانه را در شرایطی خواندم که در شرف فرار بودم، فرار از خودم، از رویاها و آرزوهایم، از دیگران و از زندگی. البته که چندروزی‌ست که این فکر احمقانه‌ی فرار و این فکر احمقانه‌ی پشت‌کردن به‌تمام آن چیزها که دلیل زندگی‌ام بودند و هستند و این فکر احمقانه‌‌ی دست‌کشیدن و ناامید شدن، رفته و جایش را به احساسات دیگری داده. اما چیزی که هنوز درک نمی‌کنم هم‌زمانی حال بد من با موثرترین تلنگرهایی‌ست که در این موقعیت‌ها دریافت می‌کنم! موراکامیِ عزیزم، می‌دانم که هر حرفی بزنم، چیزی جز یک‌مشت حرف‌های شعارگونه‌ای که پتانسیل فراموش‌شدن‌‌شان از به یادآورده‌شدن‌شان، بیشتر است، به زبان نیاورده‌ام اما می‌خواهم بگویم تا بدانی که همچون "شکار گوسفند‌ وحشی"، "برقص‌برقص"، "سوکوروتازاکی‌بی‌رنگ‌ِ" لعنتی و همچون تک‌تک جملاتت و تک‌تک سطرهایت، می‌دانم که باید کلاف‌های سردرگم زندگی‌ام را از هم جدا کنم و در مسیر درست‌ قرار دهم، همین...
